text:
(Ah, So I Can Read Already?!: Chalk Stories). Published 2001. Author, Bob Ong (pseud.). Makati: Visual Print Enterprises. Twelfth anniversary edition, Pasay: Visprint Inc, 2013.

The capital letters that make up this book’s title phonetically form the words “Aba nakakabasa na pala ako” (Ah, so I can read already). It is about the stages in a man’s lifelong education, which begins with the child’s first foray into the alphabet. Written by an unidentified author using a pseudonym, the book reads like a cross between a bildungsroman and a memoir.

The preface establishes the narrator’s family background as well as the novel’s theme and tone: The seven-year-old, who is a seaman’s son, has his first bewildering brush with injustice in second grade. Having impressed the whole class, including the teacher, with the imported toy he brings for Show-and-Tell, he brings another one the following day and gets smacked for it. The anecdote is comically rendered, helped by hyperboles and a dialogue between the fearfully stuttering boy, unnamed, and the thundering Miss Uyehara with the heavy hand.

The novel is a satire on school mores and manners, but it is a microcosm of Philippine society as well. Thus, the novel presents contrasts and parallels between the school milieu and Philippine society to satirize various forms and degrees of social inequality, political corruption, and abuse of power.

The child’s initiation into social inequality occurs in first grade, when he apprehends the stark contrast between his schoolmates’ school supplies: a branded pencil case versus an ice-tube plastic bag, or a candy-scented eraser versus a rubber band knotted into a ball. Corruption is illustrated by the teachers feeding the students the answers to the National Achievement Test to upgrade their school’s status, and a class president stealing answer sheets and going on to an affluent life in adulthood. The imbalance in the power structure is manifested in the students’ constant fear of their teachers’ mood swings and their own constant desire to please. These themes, despite their gravity, are not didactically conveyed but are anecdotally presented so as to coax a smile or even the occasional chuckle from the reader.

The story grows grimmer and poignant as the narrator grows older: what the child narrator faced as amusing, or even entertaining challenges become merely tedious obstacles to acquiring the college degree. Over three semesters, he becomes a delinquent student until he drops out. He finally becomes content in a vocational school, where the population is more caring and friendly.

In the last third of the novel, the narrator becomes, with great reluctance, a substitute high school teacher. The chapters here are a mirror image of the book’s first half, as the role of teacher and students are now reversed: the students are his tormentors and he, the tormented. He emerges out of this two-week stint with a great appreciation for the teaching vocation.

The book is a mine of psychological insight, besides cultural and ethnographic details of a specific period in Philippine history—all couched in a breezy, freewheeling style. Almost every chapter is structured like a joke: it begins in a low key; gradually leads up to the anecdote, which is vividly told, with fast-paced action and even sound effects like “BAGAAAM!”; and ends with a punch line.

The chapters, passages, and side comments that have been added to this revised edition are more informative and somber. A chapter on the K-12 system is straight exposition. In another chapter, the narrator’s computation of the total cost of his education is plaintively told.

The novel has become something of a publishing phenomenon in the Philippines because it has attracted a huge readership, of various ages and across sectors of society: high school and college students, professional and nonprofessional wage earners, corporate executives, and the religious of various denominations. Hence, it has opened up a space for literary works by unknown authors who are bending the rules of literary form and tradition with a light hand.   Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 2002. Author and illustrator, Arnold Arre. Quezon City: Anino.

After Eden is a black-and-white graphic novel in five acts. The first act pertains to two childhood friends—Jon and Celine—who meet again after 21 years. Before their reunion, both characters have settled into comfortable but boring lives. Jon owns a comic book store and hangs around with his friends Greg and Mike, while Celine works at an ad agency and rooms with her friends Cathy and Lea.

The opening act uses a technique that, in filmmaking, is called the split screen. The two characters’ lives are juxtaposed, and their thoughts are eerily similar. This search for more meaningful lives sets up the fateful encounter that Jon and Celine needed to have—an encounter, which, for a while, completes their existences but, owing to their insistence that their friends need to experience it too, actually makes the lives of the “supporting cast” miserable. This then becomes the story arc for the next two acts.

Jon and Celine’s romance continues until Lea and Greg finally decide to play the snake in the garden by breaking them up. Thus begins the fourth act, where friendships are waylaid, and the “will-they, won’t-they” story line gains steam, culminating in the town’s centennial celebration during the final act.

The Celine-and-Jon love story is actually an extension of the war between the angels and the devils. The angels here are represented as women rockers who wear wings and skimpy clothes, while the devils are represented as policemen who wear black leather. In small ways, these two groups interfere in the Jon-Celine affair in order to prove their theories about love: one states that love is nothing but trouble and is the real fruit of the Garden of Eden; the other states that love is worth the pain and suffering because it will make persons better in the end. Jon and Celine are made to experience troubles so that they become the persons they need to be at the end. Their eventual understanding of this truth also affects their friends, who end up pairing up and so prove the notion that love transcends all barriers.

This graphic novel was written and produced at the height of the popularity of Japanese manga, and the illustrations show evidence of manga’s influence. The story line, often simple in premise but drawn-out for dramatic effect, is reminiscent of the rising influence of young adult fiction that would dominate the literary scene.

After Eden will be best remembered for finally bringing Filipino comics into the mainstream, something that its predecessor, The Mythology Class, was unable to achieve. Beneath the love story that the graphic novel uses as a frame is a retelling of the story of the fall, with the message that it is probably the best thing to have happened to humans.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(Mass Uprising 1763). Published 1996. Author, Bernardino Alzate. Serialized in Bannawag, 1 Jan–25 Mar 1996.

The short novel chronicles a fictional Ilocano uprising in 1763 in Tayum, Abra, the province where Alzate was born. A week before it began serialization, Bannawag notified readers that the work is a tribute to the centennial of the 1896 Revolution, the culmination of sporadic revolts against Spanish colonization.

Alsa Masa 1763 follows Anastacio Saavedra, called Tacio, a man tasked to deliver ammunition from Gabriela Silang. Tacio leads an uprising together with other male residents amid the continual suffering of the townspeople from harsh colonial policies, such as forced labor and excessive tributes. Shown as the embodiment of oppressive Spanish rule is Kapitan Peña, the town’s gobernadorcillo (mayor) and Abra’s highest-ranking military official.

While transporting the arms and ammunitions from Gabriela Silang to the local revolutionaries, Tacio rescues Mei Ling, a Chinese woman, from drowning in a river. The budding romance is thwarted, however, when it is revealed that Kapitan Peña is also interested in Mei Ling. In one instance, Peña humiliates Tacio in front of her. To exact revenge, Tacio, along with his best friend Irineo Tabulan (called Inio), ambushes Peña’s two closest military aides. The killing of the two becomes the signal for the uprising in Tayum to commence.

Alsa Masa 1763 consciously aims to link the local uprising within the larger canvass of the 1896 Revolution. It presents and imagines the fictional uprising as a national undertaking, specifically locating it within the context of Diego Silang’s Ilocos. By dramatizing the grievances of the people of Tayum against Spanish rule, it identifies the objectives and psychological bases of the local peasant rebellions outside the conventional Tagalog narrative and asserts that these constitute the chains of events that culminated in the revolution.

However, as a novel that claims to engage history, Alsa Masa 1763 suffers from glaring historical anachronisms, including a reference to Ilocos Sur: the division of Ilocos into Norte and Sur would not take place until 1818. The novel’s conception of “Filipino” has also been cited as incongruent with the 18th-century setting. Some critics, however, point out these inaccuracies are due to the novel’s nationalizing tendency, which freely appropriates the past for the present and future in order to achieve the work’s overall project of nation-formation. This direction should also be seen in the context of broader attempts by other Ilocano scholars and writers to rewrite Philippine history, particularly the nationalist historiography that privileges the Tagalog’s role in the country’s struggle for freedom.

Other lenses through which aspects of the novel can be read include gender and race. There are the psychosexual dynamic that undergirds Tacio’s motivation for leading the revolt, the novel’s critical appropriation of Gabriela Silang and pointed exclusion of the women of Tayum from the titular revolt itself, and the treatment of the Chinese as allies and indirect supporters of the uprising.  Written by Roderick Galam

text:
(Amapola in 65 Chapters). Published 2011. Author, Ricky Lee. Quezon City: Philippine Writers Studio Foundation Inc.

The eponymous hero of this, Ricky Lee’s second novel, is a loud, gay impersonator who is a manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul). Amapola is a Kagumay, a manananggal who chooses not to eat humans. The manananggal who eats live human flesh is a Tungkab. A Talukbang is the lower half of the body that has learned to be ambulatory.

Amapola’s body carries two other personalities: Isaac, the macho whose sweetheart is Giselle, an anorexic low-class model; and Zaldy, the closet gay who likes to speak in English. Amapola is in love with Homer, a widower and a single parent to Truman; he is a waiter in the bar where Amapola performs. Homer harbors a deep hatred for aswangs, because he believes that they turned his wife into a manananggal, and this is what caused her death.

Emil, a dwarfish policeman and an ardent Noranian (a fan of actress Nora Aunor), introduces Amapola to his great grandmother, Lola Sepa, who is also a manananggal. She tells Amapola they must find his long-lost sister, Mira, who is destined to save the Philippines by uniting manananggal and humans before the 2010 elections. The extremist, Congressman Trono, has organized an aswang-hunting patrol, but he is the more popular candidate than the liberal Macaraeg, who is supportive of aswangs.

The story line is interrupted by Lola Sepa’s backstory, which goes thus: Living during the revolutionary period, she falls in love with Andres Bonifacio. She supports the revolution as a manananggal, killing friars and indio (Christianized native) traitors. Bonifacio learns what she is and accepts her anyway, and this makes her ecstatic. But she becomes jealous of Bonifacio’s wife, Oryang, and, because of her vacillation, she arrives too late to save him from execution by Aguinaldo’s faction. Guilt-ridden, she stops being a manananggal and marries, although her heart belongs only to Andres.

Sepa has prophetic dreams about Amapola and Mira. Before she can act on them, she is betrayed by a fellow manananggal and left for dead, only to pop out of Emil’s toilet bowl the next century. She trains Amapola to be a strong manananggal and requires him to read Philippine history, remarking that Bonifacio and the Katipuneros were avid readers.

Amapola and Lola Sepa discover that Mira died in a plane crash a year earlier; in her stead, Amapola becomes the Fated One. Giving himself the epithet of Grandiosa, he proclaims that what the people need is not food but a way to root out the cause of their hunger.

A battle ensues between the Kagumays, led by Amapola, and the Tungkabs, led by Montero. Amapola defeats Montero and is reunited with his loved ones. Homer confesses his love for Amapola. Realizing that no one is destined to be the Savior, after all, Amapola decides to be a normal human being.

Amapola is a novel in many modes: political allegory, satire, fantasy, psychological realism, metafiction, historical fiction, and pop culture. Humor—visual, verbal, situational, and self-reflexive—abounds in many scenes. Thus, while the novel raises historical questions and addresses serious contemporary issues, it can be entertaining to readers junior and senior.  Written by Edgar Calabia Samar

text:
Published 1946. Author, Carlos Bulosan. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Co. Reprinted, with an introduction by Carey McWilliams, Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1973; and with a foreword by Bienvenido L. Lumbera, Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2006.

Though subtitled A Personal History, this book is actually a group history, a story of what it was like to be a Filipino in California in the 1930s, the years of the Great Depression.

The book chronicles the rise in consciousness of the immigrant Allos. Driven by poverty at home, he goes to the United States, seeking a better life. He arrives in the United States full of the optimism of his Thomasite education, but he sinks into fear and depression as reality hits him in the face. From the white folk, he encounters prejudice and racial violence. From his country folk, he encounters a benumbed despair in some and a cynical, ruthless opportunism in others. The turning point in Allos’s consciousness comes after a gambling incident in which he cheats a whole group of Filipino workers out of their wages. He suddenly recognizes his own part in the degradation. He makes amends by buying groceries for the men he cheated, and then gets drunk on cheap wine and starts writing a letter to his brother Macario. Realizing he can now write understandable English, he rejoices, shouting, “They can’t silence me anymore. I’ll tell the world what they have done to me.” He then moves into the labor movement, uses his writing talents to explore the interrelationships of the forces of oppression, the history of labor in the United States, race relations in California, and the effects of oppression on the individual. However, he soon finds out that he has tuberculosis, at that time an incurable disease, and he has only a few more years to live. Still, he works in earnest until he has to be hospitalized. He returns to active organizing after recovering partially. The novel ends with his brother Amado joining the US Navy after the fall of Bataan and his other brother Macario enlisting in the army.

Bulosan’s book deals with real events which can be chronicled and documented from outside sources, although some difficulty arises from the fact that the book has no dates and Bulosan has taken liberties with time sequence and place names as well. However, there are clear references to the Watsonville riots of 1930, the Imperial Valley Lettuce Strike of 1934, and the massacre of the leadership of the Seattle-based cannery union. We also witness the issues, organizational problems, and heartfelt triumphs of the Filipino worker movement of the times.

The book is written for an American, as much as for a Filipino, audience. The references to a faith in the America of the heart—Bulosan’s luminous ideal of democracy and socialist brotherhood—are highlighted precisely by the negative reality. Bulosan touches the violence with moments of tenderness, as when, after being set upon by railroad detectives with blackjacks and his friend Jose almost getting killed, these Filipinos find solace and refuge in an American hospital; or when after being beaten up blind by white vigilantes, an American woman gives him shelter.  Written by Susan P. Evangelista and Lolita R. Lacuesta

text:
(Uncle Sam). Published 1990-91. Author, Reynaldo A. Duque. Serialized in Bannawag, 27 Aug 1990–15 Jul 1991.

In constructing an allegory of US-Philippine relations, this historico-political novel draws on two historical events, the 1896 Candon Revolt and the Tinggian victory over multinational company Cellophil in the 1970s.

It begins with the arrival of American PhD student Samuel Wright, who comes to the barrio of Bagani Ubbog to conduct research for his dissertation. Over time, Wright, or Angkel Sam (Uncle Sam), as he is fondly called by the locals, becomes increasingly involved in the affairs of the barrio. Soon he is appointed political adviser and consultant and given a seat in the barrio council, which begins adopting all his decisions. He also becomes instrumental in the establishment of an elementary school and successfully changes the date of the barrio fiesta to the fourth of July.

Firmly planted in Bagani Ubbog, Angkel Sam develops an interest in Luzviminda, the barrio’s most beautiful maiden, who is also being courted by the radical Romeo Komunista. The American impregnates Luzviminda but shirks his responsibilities. Depressed, she tries to commit suicide. Meanwhile, news spreads that multinational corporation Cellocos has been granted a government permit to reopen despite strong opposition from residents of the barrio. A violent and bloody struggle between the people and Cellocos ensues.

The allegorical attempt of Angkel Sam can be readily gleaned from the characters’ names and the novel’s central plot. Bagani Ubbog itself is a microcosm of the nation. The events in Bagani Ubbog, such as the gradual intrusion of American control into the various spheres of Filipino life—from politics to education and the economy—to the “personal” trespass against Luzviminda, are undisguised allusions to many facts of Philippine history.

The novel’s anti-imperialist spirit, embodied in the residents’ struggle against American incursion, is mirrored in many details of the novel. The school, which Angkel Sam helped to build, becomes a site of contending perspectives when a history textbook alleges that Gregorio del Pilar was buried and honored by the Americans. The claim is disputed by a pupil’s grandfather, a former insurrecto (insurgent) who fought alongside the hero in Tirad Pass and was in fact the one who buried him. Even a game of spider wrestling between a white and a brown spider reverberates with the anti-imperialist discourse. An allusion to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund is also made when Angkel Sam, through Filipino collaborators, starts lending money to residents in return for concessions in the future, a setup that leads to cyclical indebtedness. The 20 dollars that one character donates for the construction of a steel flagpole to replace one made of bamboo is a reference to the 20 million dollars that the United States paid Spain for the Philippines as part of the Treaty of Paris.

There is also an allusion to precolonial Philippines. Apong Akkos derives his name from the man who pieced the bones of Ilocano epic hero Lam-ang back together. Because it is Apong Akkos’s grandson Salacnib Guerrero who narrates Duque’s novel, Angkel Sam constitutes a new Ilocano epic undertaking.  Written by Roderick Galam

text:
(Shadow of Yesteryears). Published 1906. Author, Francisco Laksamana. Serialized in Muling Pagsilang. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Limbagang McCullough, 1907; Manila: Pamana ng Panitikan ng Pilipinas, 1971.

This novel exposes the roots of the Filipinos’ oppression, symbolized by the dreaded Spanish guardia civil (constabulary) and the friar. The first group figures as the narratives’ villains, whereas the second is held responsible for the people’s blind adherence to superstition; both stand as the agents of destruction and violent death. The novel centers on how Modesto Magsikap decides to take the law into his own hands with dire consequences. What initially starts out as a colorful narrative of love and courtship becomes a tale of murder and pursuit. Enraged by Sergeant Cruz’s arrogant behavior as the suitor of his sweetheart Elisea Liwayway, Modesto stabs the soldier dead and flees. He eventually finds himself behind bars with Fabian, accused by his wife of having been responsible for the death of their child, who has died with countless others during a stampede inside a church.

Modesto and several other prisoners are subsequently freed by bandits who attack the town. He comes home when he finds out that his father, Kabesang Angel, is dead. During the wake, Modesto stabs Lieutenant Rosca, another ardent suitor of Elisea; he flees, and his two brothers are imprisoned instead. The hunt for Modesto intensifies. He is betrayed by a close friend, but he manages to escape and decides to go to the United States. He writes Elisea to inform her of the many wonderful opportunities that democracy affords the people in the United States. In 1896, five years after the series of events, Modesto returns to his country.

The novel’s tightly nuanced evocation of community life in a small town in Luzon, with its rituals of birth, love, and death, is contextualized in an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty. All the major characters, especially the impulsive Modesto and the courageous Elisea, are drawn with attention to fine details of character. The result is a narrative that paints a broad canvas of life in the dying years of Spanish colonial rule. Laksamana’s skillful manipulation of the narration lays bare the reasons for the people’s continued oppression, with a humor that borders on the satirical and the grotesque.

After depicting the past as one terrible nightmare, it seems easy for the novelist to hail the Americans as magnanimous, benevolent, and just. Where Spain represents darkness, the new conquerors symbolize light. This novel is one of the few pro-American texts in the first decade of American rule, a dissenting note in the overwhelming anti-American feeling characterizing most of the novels at the time. Laksamana uses historical data as material for fiction intelligently and probingly. The book shows a deep understanding of the historical processes that drove Filipinos, like the novel’s hero, to turn their backs on the law and lead a fugitive’s life: the system was harsh and unjust to indios (Christianized natives) like him. History, an interpretation of the nation’s past, propels the novel’s dynamism.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(What Now, Ricky?). Published 1971. Author, Rosario de Guzman Lingat. Serialized in Liwayway, 5 Apr 1971–23 Aug 1971. Published as a book, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1996. English translation, What Now, Ricky? by Soledad S. Reyes, Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2013.

Ano Ngayon, Ricky? won first prize at the Liwayway annual contest in 1971, a year before the declaration of martial law. A product of Lingat’s participation in the Palihan, a writing workshop conducted at Ateneo de Manila University in 1970, the novel shows Lingat at her most political.

Set in Jan 1970, the novel depicts a world rife with corruption and conflict, represented in microcosm by Tondo. A number of characters, like Mang Teong and his wife, take to vice and violence; others, like Ricky’s father and his cronies, engage in empty rhetoric; still others, like the wealthy Vilma and Paulina, are indifferent and pursue pleasure at all cost.

For some of the young male characters, like Danny and Tony, education is a solution to both personal and national problems. Only Ricky chooses to be an activist. Ricky understands how the personal shapes the political and vice versa. His decision to take the activist’s path to correct a terribly faulty system dominated by brute force comes from a personal trauma: the sight of his dying father, who was protecting the sanctity of his ballot, being mauled by Leong Buldog one election day.

Ricky meets the charismatic Professor Alba, a former government official who has resigned in disgust from government and whose reputation remains untarnished. Buoyed up by this new friend and by a newly awakened feeling of love for Diana, the professor’s daughter, Ricky embraces the cause more fiercely.

Ricky and his group join the demonstrators massed in Congress to hear the president’s address. The demonstrations eventually spill over into a bloody siege of Malacañan Palace, leading to more bloodshed. In the melee, Ricky catches a glimpse of Leong Buldog egging the students on to a murderous rampage. Ricky pursues his father’s murderer and learns from him that the financier of his group of infiltrators is Professor Alba.

As Ricky turns his back on the duplicitous professor, he also gives up the illusion that love can be an equalizer. He returns to Tondo and sees its denizens: the drunk, the gamblers, the indolent, the loudmouthed gathered at the plaza. In the darkness he makes out the huge house of Paulina, with its door locked, as if to bar out what is troubling and destructive in the outside world. As he walks down the streets of Manila, he realizes that the sun is rising and that he and his loyal friends have survived the chaos of the previous night.

Ano Ngayon, Ricky? is a narrative of initiation, a profoundly disturbing and complex journey of a young man in search of meaning and purpose. This has been a universal theme of bildungsroman, but in this novel, the personal journey is grafted onto specific and significant chapter of Philippine history. Lingat’s novel was one of a number in Liwayway that, in response to the tumult that the country was undergoing, affirmed the vitality of the tradition of protest that the generation of novelists writing in the first two decades of the 20th century had demonstrated as they critiqued the American colonial regime. In this sense, Lingat joins the company of Lazaro Francisco, Amado V. Hernandez, and Brigido Batungbakal, all writers who bravely confronted injustice and violence in a country described as a “volcano about to explode.”   Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum
text:
(The Dog, the Flea, the Bonsai and the Colorum Movement). Published 2000. Author, Jose Rey Munsayac. Quezon City: Philippine Centennial Commission and University of the Philippines Press. Centennial Literary Prize, first prize co-winner for the novel in Filipino, 1998.

The novel is set in the first half of the 20th century, covering the period from the Filipino-American War to post-World War II. Kapitan Ento, a farmer, fights in the Fil-Am war; and his son, Victorio, born during the revolution, fights for the farmers in the 1930s, becomes a guerrilla in World War II, and finds himself, as the novel ends, wondering why the struggle of the poor against oppression never ceases.

As Aguinaldo’s followers surrender to the American forces, Kapitan Ento continues the fight. He is largely uneducated but endowed with intelligence and fired by an intense love of country, especially for the downtrodden masses of which he is a part. He leads his armed men against the Americans until he is captured, tried, convicted, and executed. Earlier, his wife Julia has died in an encounter.

The embodiment of greed, duplicity, and ruthless power in the lives of Kapitan Ento and his men is Kabesang Pakong, one of Aguinaldo’s generals and a proprietor of vast tracts of land. When Kapitan Ento looks up to him for leadership, he is sorely disappointed. Kabesang Pakong willingly collaborates with the Americans.

Kapitan Ento’s son Victorio is then raised by Mulong, who sympathizes with Kapitan Ento. As Victorio grows up, he witnesses how tenants continue to suffer at the hands of such landowners as Don Chioco and Kabesang Dwardo. The henchmen of the landlords and the military terrorize the villages, including Bagong Nayon where Victorio lives. The dissident peasant movements—the Colorum and the Huk—gain numerous adherents as the years wear on.

Victorio fights in World War II as a guerrilla, only to come back disillusioned yet again. He sees how the miners, with the help of the military, are depriving countless farmers of their means of livelihood and are destroying the mountains.

Meanwhile, Mulong, sowing terror among the landlords as Kumander Buhay, is accused of being a member of the Colorum and a communist. He is eventually captured and imprisoned. His son, Juan Lazaro, decides to become a soldier instead of remaining a farmer in a system that keeps him in bondage forever.

The novel ends when Juan Lazaro, together with soldiers tasked to quell a riot initiated by furious farmers, sees Kabesang Dwardo’s cruelty at its most despicable. Realizing that he has been reduced to being the landlord’s paid henchman and is not a free man as he had hoped to be when he joined the military, Juan guns down Kabesang Dwardo and flies to Bagong Nayon.

When Victorio asks Juan what the latter intends to do, he says that he will join the dissidents. Juan Lazaro, whose name signifies the common man rising from the dead, finally admits his solidarity with his kind, who for centuries has been betrayed by a corrupt system.

 

Principally a novel of ideas, Munsayac’s novel comes straight from the tradition constituted by the first generation of Tagalog novelists like Faustino Aguilar, Lope K. Santos, and Juan Arsciwals, whose works unarguably manifest their socialistic framework. History is here fused with fiction as historical figures—from Emilio Aguinaldo to Macario Sakay, from Artemio Ricarte to various presidents—walk side by side with and interact with various characters who personify sociopolitical forces wrestling for power in society. Kabesang Pakong and Kabesang Dwardo’s murderous rampage keeps the country’s elite firmly in control. Constituting a foil are Kapitan Ento, Mulong, Victorio, and Juan—three generations of Filipinos who remain committed to the abolition of the tenancy system. Clearly, the novel’s bias is for those who have sought to address the nation’s festering agrarian problems throughout its long colonial history.

Munsayac’s novel shared the Centennial Literary Prize, given by the Philippine Centennial Commission to commemorate the centenary of Philippine independence, with Jun Cruz Reyes’s Etsa-Puwera (Outsider).  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Social Dawn). Published 1910-11. Author, Pedro Paterno. Manila: Imprenta La Republica.

In 1910, nearly 30 years after the publication of his Ninay, known as the first Filipino novel, Paterno put together narratives that he called novelas under the general name of Aurora Social. Included in the collection are El Alma Filipina (The Filipino Soul), Amor de un Dia (A Day’s Love), Boda a la Moderna (Modern Wedding), Maring: Amor del Obrero Filipino (Maring: A Filipino Laborer’s Love), Los Heraldos de la Raza (The Heralds of the Race), and Los Amores de Antipolo (The Loves of Antipolo).

El Alma Filipina is about Elena (Nena), a beautiful but poor girl. Jose (Pepe) Sandoval, the manager of the factory where she works, courts her. After some initial hesitation, Elena accepts him. She rises to affluence and soon has a son. But some four years later, Pepe turns unfaithful. He decides to marry a Señorita Isabel Saavedra at the Santa Cruz Church. Brokenhearted, Nena bids a sentimental farewell to her son, puts on a black dress, takes a dagger, and goes to Santa Cruz Church in time for the wedding. As Pepe and his new bride come from the altar, Nena suddenly stabs him to death.

In this story, Paterno depicts some painful facts of Filipino society: extreme poverty and the corruption of the rich. Paterno accentuates the melodrama of the Spanish sense of outraged honor more than national problems; however, one can also read the story allegorically as the ilustrado (educated native) betrayal of the ideals of the Philippine Revolution for the charms of American promises.

Paterno’s tendency to romanticize is also strongly present in Maring: Amor de Obrero Filipino, the story of the brave, strong, and noble laborer Berto who demonstrates his defense of his class and his sweetheart Maring by braving the flames of a fire at the factory to kill the abusive capataz or overseer and to save his beloved from the clutches of dishonor. As he emerges out of the burning building with Maring safe, the laborers burst into applause.

Los Heraldos de la Raza, 1911, is the story of Ramon Kawit from Batangas and Luis Totlay from Misamis. They are students at the Liceo de Manila. One night, Luis dreams of flying so high the eagles disappear from sight below him. Ramon says he has also dreamt of flying, but he flies so high the stars fade out of sight beneath his feet. Luis goes to America to study further and later returns as a lawyer. Ramon, on the other hand, becomes a humble professor. When the two are reunited, a rivalry over Leonor, a cousin of Luis, ensues. She chooses the wealthy Luis who becomes a Speaker of the Philippine Assembly. Later, however, by force of wisdom and uprightness, Ramon really rises much higher than Luis. He wins the presidency of the country, while Luis becomes a fallen politician. When Luis visits him, he orders Luis to kiss the three stars on the flag, which he claims he has brought from the heights, never to be taken away from where they are now.

The most immediate difference between Ninay and the novelas in the Aurora Social is the absence of the pedantic footnotes found in the earlier novel. Paterno’s poetic quotations replace what in Ninay were lengthy authorial intrusions into the narrative. His love for the romantic and sentimental plot is still there. However, Paterno certainly has become nationalistic in a way he was not in Ninay, as he pays more attention to political problems, which he sees as questions of ethical righteousness.  Written by Florentino Hornedo

One night, Luis dreams of flying so high the eagles disappear from sight below him. Ramon says he has also dreamt of flying, but he flies so high the stars fade out of sight beneath his feet. Luis goes to America to study further and later returns as a lawyer. Ramon, on the other hand, becomes a humble professor. When the two are reunited, a rivalry over Leonor, a cousin of Luis, ensues. She chooses the wealthy Luis who becomes a Speaker of the Philippine Assembly. Later, however, by force of wisdom and uprightness, Ramon really rises much higher than Luis. He wins the presidency of the country, while Luis becomes a fallen politician. When Luis visits him, he orders Luis to kiss the three stars on the flag, which he claims he has brought from the heights, never to be taken away from where they are now.

The most immediate difference between Ninay and the novelas in the Aurora Social is the absence of the pedantic footnotes found in the earlier novel. Paterno’s poetic quotations replace what in Ninay were lengthy authorial intrusions into the narrative. His love for the romantic and sentimental plot is still there. However, Paterno certainly has become nationalistic in a way he was not in Ninay, as he pays more attention to political problems, which he sees as questions of ethical righteousness.  Written by Florentino Hornedo

text:
(New Christ). Published 1932. Author, Franco Vera Reyes. Manila: National Publishing Corp.

This is perhaps the only novel in the 1930s which dared to tackle various sociopolitical issues with candor and forthrightness. It suggests civil disobedience as the means by which the country could liberate itself from foreign control: refusing to pay taxes, boycotting foreign goods, boycotting all elections, living simply, and striving to reclaim the land seized by the friars.

In the novel’s opening, Corazon Apacible, a rich woman, meets Amando Sandoval, a newspaper reporter noted for his courage. When he finds out that Senator Apacible, Corazon’s father, has accepted a bribe of 30,000 pesos from an American businessman, he writes an exposé for his newspaper Palihan, and this causes a sensation. He traces the web of corruption that has enabled foreign entrepreneurs to invest huge amounts of capital to build ships and radios in the country. An investigation is conducted in the Senate, but instead of being punished or sanctioned, Senator Apacible is exonerated and is even appointed as court justice. As a result of the exposé, Amando loses his job. He initiates a movement to hold a national congress for liberation in December. Thousands of concerned Filipinos choose to get involved. Among them are Tandang Sebio, an old philanthropist; Justo, a labor leader; Santillan, a close friend; and Corazon, the representative of the students. In the face of the tremendous support snowballing for this movement, Amando is charged with sedition and rebellion. Justice Apacible, who has slowly realized the justness of the cause Amando is fighting for, refuses to accept jurisdiction of the case in his court. Amando is brought to trial, and he is sentenced to serve four years in prison. He marries Corazon before he starts to serve his term. As the novel ends, it is clear that the floodgates of protest have opened and that the congress being organized will pull through as planned.

More than any other novel written in the 1930s, this novel is deeply immersed in history. It includes an account of the Colorum rebellion in Tayug, the manipulation of these events by politicians, the Sakdalista revolt, and the bloody fight with the friars over their vast lands. Towering above all the characters is Amando, the new Christ willing to suffer and die so that his people might live in a just and peaceful society. Like Christ, Amando suffers in the hands of his own country folk. Toward the end, the reader is made to understand that the movement he has organized is opening the eyes of more Filipinos to the realities of colonialism.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(The Cloak of God). Published 1975. Author, Rosario de Guzman Lingat. English translation, The Cloak of God by Soledad S. Reyes, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 2013.

The novel revolves around Felino Paras, a stage actor now down on his luck after locking horns with his director, Gonzalo Adriano, and after betraying his paramour, the aging actress Paquita Madrid. Forced to look for a place, he presents himself as one Dante Parreno and swindles a man. He leases a one-room unit in the house of Mang Asyas, a vegetable vendor, and his lovely, innocent daughter, Luding.

With the authorities still in pursuit of “Dante Parreno,” Felino disguises himself as a hermit, whose mission is to help the faithful. His training as an actor comes in handy as he spouts messages that seem lifted straight from the Bible. He mesmerizes thousands, tapping into their hidden fears and desire to be saved. Working with his former cohorts, Gonzalo Adriano and Paquita Madrid, Felino, now known and revered as Maestro Felino, founds a church. The coffers overflow, and a huge mansion is built for the maestro.

His luck turns when he seduces Luding. He discovers that he has an incurable disease. He looks for Dr Lorenzo, the only doctor who might help him prolong his life. On his way to the doctor’s hospital, however, he has an accident and is brought to the hospital by Father Arriola, a Catholic priest. Felino informs the doctor and the priest that he is a minister with a yet unfinished mission to save the faithful.

On his way to his convent, Father Arriola has an accident that, however, does not damage his brain. Desperate, Felino begs the doctor to perform a brain transplant. The man who wakes up after the operation is the priest, aghast to find himself in Felino’s body. The doctor explains that Father Arriola remains who he was, and his mission is to preach the word of God: any man who wears the cloak of God partakes of the mission, regardless of his religious affiliation.

Finally accepting his fate, Father Arriola leaves the hospital with Gonzalo Adriano. As Father Arriola learns not only about the workings of the organization but also about the perfidious and lascivious acts of Gonzalo and Paquita, he resolves to put an end to the scam and the perpetrators’ immoral acts. In the final chapter, he denounces them, Jeremiah-like, and exhorts them to repent. He speaks not as the hypocritical Felino but as a true pastor of God. Gonzalo and Paquita approach him to ask if it is still possible for them to be saved despite their lives of debauchery. Dr Lorenzo expresses his confidence that the priest will fully minister to the needs of the flock and reveal the secret to no one.

On the surface, Ang Balabal ng Diyos is a variation of the Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde motif, the raging battle between good and evil in each human being. Lingat’s novel, however, also examines how a carefully packaged image of a religious leader can resonate with the masses, fearful of the unknown and desirous of certainty. Such fears are exploited by the cunning and the opportunistic bent on satisfying their monstrous egos by acquiring wealth and power.

In its masterful deployment of the resources of fiction and especially in its refusal to offer pat explanations of the puzzling questions—on identity, duality, the church and the nature of salvation, the role of science in the world, the interplay between human beings as they are and human beings as they want to be—it is, in retrospect, one of the most intriguing novels of the 20th century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(House by the River Bank). Published 1971. Author, Conrado J. Norada. Serialized in Hiligaynon, 2 Aug 1972–13 Jun 1973.

A story of crime and justice, this Ilonggo novel portrays the theme of a hero’s discovery and transformation. Dario Barrientos, a young engineer, discovers gold in the land of Mayor Philippe. He schemes with his brother Max to get the gold by marrying Philippe’s daughter Cecilia. They stage a mock kidnapping and Dario pretends to rescue her. Now Dario, Philippe’s son-in-law, has a change of heart, but Max is determined to kill the family of Philippe and acquire their fortune. In the final encounter, Dario is killed by Max, but not before he elicits Cecilia’s forgiveness for having brought about the death of her parents.

Balay is a departure from Norada’s usual works because the hero is not idealized, nor is the ending contrived and happy. The novel’s strongest quality is its characterization, followed by the use of supernatural elements and inclusion of some folk practices to combat evil spirits. Unlike Norada’s earlier novels, which are essentially romantic, Balay is sociopolitical.  Written by Cecil Locsin Nava

 

Source

Morales, Alfredo. 1989. F. Sionil Jose and His Fiction: The Filipino Journey to Justice and Nationhood. Quezon City: Vera-Reyes.

text:
Published 1959. Author, N. V. M. Gonzalez. Serialized in Sunday Times Magazine, 8 Sep 1959–20 Sep 1959. Reprinted, Diliman Review, Jan-Jun 1959. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Benipayo Press, 1960; Denver: Allan Swallow and Sons, 1961; Manila: Republic Book Supply, 1977; Makati City, Bookmark Inc, 1993. Republic Cultural Heritage Award for Literature, 1960.

As Gonzalez himself explains in a letter to a critic, the novel is about Filipinos coming to terms with themselves and with the roots of their loneliness and emptiness. Ernie Rama, an ambivalent and alienated Filipino intellectual, attempts to break away from his culture and his country’s traditions, only to find himself lost and alone in a strange cosmopolitan world. On a fellowship grant, Ernie travels to New York, Vermont, Tokyo, Hiroshima, Taipei, and Manila. In each place, he meets new people or renews old acquaintances, but he avoids getting involved in their lives. However, he arrives at subtly significant realizations that gradually add up to his self-discovery.

The novel opens with a “Prologue by Post,” consisting of correspondence between Ernie and some of the other characters, written after he gets back from Manila. The narrative proper is a flashback after the prologue and is divided into six sections: “A Lament,” “The Mountain Visit,” “Fall,” “After the Cloudburst,” “The Mainlanders,” and “In Sipolog.” In New York, Ernie meets Reggie Samonte, who introduces him to a small circle of Filipinos, and to a childless American couple, once exchange professors at a Philippine university. Ernie renews a friendship with Helen Reyes, an acquaintance in college. He has a passing affair with her, but reluctant to make any commitments, he flees New York and Helen. In San Francisco, Ernie discovers that his brother Pepe has been living a bachelor’s life, in spite of a family back in the Philippines. At a rest house in Japan, Ernie is unmoved as the A-bomb victims of Hiroshima recount their harrowing experiences. In Tokyo, he meets Helen again, who is on her way to Taipei with her American fiancé, Herb Lane. In Taipei, Ernie encounters a Filipino dance troupe and attends a consul’s party held in the group’s honor. The following morning, he discovers that Herb, while drunk, ran over a Chinese girl the previous night, prompting a demonstration by some Chinese in front of the hotel. Herb is later shot dead and Helen, who was with him that night, is protected by Ernie and the consul from being implicated. Ernie returns to the Philippines and stays aloof from family problems. Later, however, he joins his mother and sister-in-law who have gone to Sipolog. In the concluding portion, he figures in an accident that almost kills him, and he is sore and resentful that nobody seems to be aware that he has just had a brush with death. An epilogue consists of Ernie’s reflections on his experiences abroad.

The novel exemplifies Gonzalez’s well-known craft. But more than technique, the novel’s value lies in its having found a “name” for the Filipinos’ problems. For Gonzalez, this is the ultimate business of fiction: “to identify, to define.”  Written by Ma. Teresa Wright, with notes from Bienvenido L. Lumbera and Cynthia Nograles Lumbera 

 

Sources

Bernad, Miguel, SJ. 1961. Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree: Essays on Filipino Literature in English. Manila: Bookmark.

De Jesus, Edilberto Jr. 1967. “On This Soil, in This Climate: Growth in the Novels of N. V. M. Gonzalez.” In Brown Heritage: Essays in Philippine Cultural Tradition, ed. Antonio G. Manuud, 739-64. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Gonzalez, N. V. M. 1960. “N.V.M. Gonzalez to Father Bernad.” Philippine Studies 8 (Third Quarter): 622-28.

Lumbera, Bienvenido L., and Cynthia Nograles Lumbera. 1982. Philippine Literature: A History and Anthology. Manila: National Book Store.

text:
Published 2002. Author, Azucena Grajo Uranza. Makati City: Bookmark Inc. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1990.

The novel follows a group of friends and their families, who find themselves caught in the impending danger of military rule. Andy and Connie are the rebellious children of a senator, whose grasp on power is being threatened by the looming dictatorship. Ramon, the son of a respected judge, joins the protest movement against the government. Sylvia, a mother of two, becomes inadvertently involved in the actions of her estranged husband’s friends. She represents the bystanders who also got caught up in the violence leading up to martial law.

Uranza’s novel shows us that the social position of the middle and upper classes did not always exempt them from military abuse. The idealistic and socially privileged Ramon becomes disillusioned with the government when he personally witnesses the brutal dispersion of a protest rally at Mendiola, which he has organized himself. Andy, the senator’s son, is a young Jesuit priest who secretly organizes “study” groups in the poor communities. He represents the many men and women of the cloth who were active against the Marcos regime.

On the other hand, Andy’s sister Connie is gradually awakened to the plight of women in the country. While her first foray into the women’s movement is met with scorn and skepticism, she fully embraces their causes and defies her father at every turn. Her husband, Larry, is the son of a wealthy businessman and plantation owner. Despite his initial reluctance, he is thrust into the struggle and finally goes to Bacolod to help the sugarcane workers who have gone on strike.

Each episode in the novel is overshadowed by the specter of a rising dictatorship. The First Couple makes a surprise appearance at Larry and Connie’s engagement party—more out of mistrust and suspicion than out of friendship. Certain scenes dramatize the turbulent events of the First Quarter Storm, such as the military’s violent demolition of the poor community in Sapang Bato, and the protesters’ burning of the fields of Laguardia as a way of preventing the government from taking advantage of the farmers.

The novel ends with the members of the opposition movement being captured or killed by the military or going up to the mountains. This ending hints at the continuation of the protest movement and the awakening of resistance even in the people serving the government, such as Lieutenant Magtibay, who becomes disturbed by the savagery of the people he serves.

The title of the novel alludes to an oft-used analogy between the Filipino people’s resilient character and that of the bamboo, which bends even with the strongest of storms but never breaks.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(Glimmer and Light). Published 1905. Author, Lope K. Santos. Serialized in Muling Pagsilang. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Limbagang McCullough, 1906; Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co., 1970.

This novel is widely considered a landmark in Philippine literature for being the first Tagalog novel to treat romance, familial conflicts, and the socioeconomic issues of the day from the viewpoint of a writer with an emergent socialist consciousness. Set in Manila in 1904, Santos’s novel portrays a society in crisis in the tradition of social realism. In the process, it prescribes a way out of the problem by infusing his work with the ideas of his newfound ideology of the working class.

Santos creates Delfin and Felipe, two characters representing a new world outlook of dialectics, scientific thinking, and hope. They interact with an array of characters that embody the varied ideas, values, and norms in a decaying colonial and superstitious society. There is thus the constant tug-of-war between old and new, progress and retrogression.

Delfin is a low-salaried journalist of poor origins, who nurtures socialist ideas regarding trade unionism, class struggle, and nationhood. Felipe, on the other hand, is born rich; his budding radicalism borders on anarchy. Delfin, calm and deliberate, is engaged to Meni, whose father is among Manila’s richest. Felipe is paired off with shy Tentay, a poor worker’s daughter. Their lives intersect, but the focus is definitely on Delfin and Meni. The social gap between the lovers serves as environment for the basic narrative. Delfin and Meni’s love affair reaps the ire of the elite. When Meni gets pregnant, her proud and self-indulgent father Don Ramon is driven to shame. He disinherits Meni and flees to America, where he is killed by Tikong, an enraged servant. The family overrules the dead patriarch’s decision and gives back Meni’s share of the wealth on the condition that she abandon her husband. Meni rebuffs them. As love proclaims another victory at the novel’s end, Felipe delivers an impassioned warning about the doom of the bourgeoisie.

Curiously, there has been no serious challenge regarding the validity of Santos’s socialist cause. The criticisms have been directed at the “non-artistic” integration of its political ideas. While the novel’s conflict is raised from the level of the social custom to that of a political issue, the political dimension is presented in an inorganic fashion; the discursiveness of the novel tends to get in the way of swifter pacing. However, defenders of the novel contend that the “essayistic” speeches are spoken in character, and enliven and promote the action of the narrative.

“Banaag at Sikat": Metakritisismo at Antolohiya (Banaag at Sikat: Metacriticism and Anthology), 2010, by Maria Luisa Torres Reyes is a study of the critical reception of the novel from its initial publication to the 1980s.  Written by Vina Paz

article.value: (Glimmer and Light). Published 1905. Author, Lope K. Santos. Serialized in Muling Pagsilang. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Limbagang McCullough, 1906; Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co., 1970.

This novel is widely considered a landmark in Philippine literature for being the first Tagalog novel to treat romance, familial conflicts, and the socioeconomic issues of the day from the viewpoint of a writer with an emergent socialist consciousness. Set in Manila in 1904, Santos’s novel portrays a society in crisis in the tradition of social realism. In the process, it prescribes a way out of the problem by infusing his work with the ideas of his newfound ideology of the working class.

Santos creates Delfin and Felipe, two characters representing a new world outlook of dialectics, scientific thinking, and hope. They interact with an array of characters that embody the varied ideas, values, and norms in a decaying colonial and superstitious society. There is thus the constant tug-of-war between old and new, progress and retrogression.

Delfin is a low-salaried journalist of poor origins, who nurtures socialist ideas regarding trade unionism, class struggle, and nationhood. Felipe, on the other hand, is born rich; his budding radicalism borders on anarchy. Delfin, calm and deliberate, is engaged to Meni, whose father is among Manila’s richest. Felipe is paired off with shy Tentay, a poor worker’s daughter. Their lives intersect, but the focus is definitely on Delfin and Meni. The social gap between the lovers serves as environment for the basic narrative. Delfin and Meni’s love affair reaps the ire of the elite. When Meni gets pregnant, her proud and self-indulgent father Don Ramon is driven to shame. He disinherits Meni and flees to America, where he is killed by Tikong, an enraged servant. The family overrules the dead patriarch’s decision and gives back Meni’s share of the wealth on the condition that she abandon her husband. Meni rebuffs them. As love proclaims another victory at the novel’s end, Felipe delivers an impassioned warning about the doom of the bourgeoisie.

Curiously, there has been no serious challenge regarding the validity of Santos’s socialist cause. The criticisms have been directed at the “non-artistic” integration of its political ideas. While the novel’s conflict is raised from the level of the social custom to that of a political issue, the political dimension is presented in an inorganic fashion; the discursiveness of the novel tends to get in the way of swifter pacing. However, defenders of the novel contend that the “essayistic” speeches are spoken in character, and enliven and promote the action of the narrative.

“Banaag at Sikat": Metakritisismo at Antolohiya (Banaag at Sikat: Metacriticism and Anthology), 2010, by Maria Luisa Torres Reyes is a study of the critical reception of the novel from its initial publication to the 1980s.  Written by Vina Paz

text:
(Bankruptcy of Souls). Published 1910. Author, Jesus Balmori. Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica.

This is Balmori’s first novel, which he wrote when he was 22 years old. Written in Spanish, the novel revolves around a love triangle. Angela Lima, born to an affluent family, falls in love with Augusto Valvidia, a poet known not only for his art but also for his penchant for liquor and women. Angela, however, is having an affair with Ventura Ruiz, an orphaned cousin who has been living with her family. Aware of Angela’s interest in the poet, who charms her through letters and poetry, Ventura decides to stay away from her to have the quiet he sorely needs for his studies in law. Angela convinces him to return, but his jealousy intensifies as Angela continues to receive letters from Augusto. A duel follows in which Augusto leaves Ventura with a bleeding nose. Perturbed, Angela visits a priest and confesses her sexual relations with both her suitors. Angela’s troubles are compounded when Augusto, afflicted with tuberculosis, dies, leaving her doleful and pregnant. Initially, she thinks of committing suicide, but then she follows her family’s advice that she marry her cousin Ventura, who does not know that she is pregnant. On their honeymoon, Angela, whose thoughts are still filled with memories of Augusto, feels no love for her husband.

The novel insinuates the presence of the author Balmori in the character Augusto Valvidia, who is depicted in a positive, if not approving, light. The similarities between character and creator can be detected in their common skill in poetry, their alcoholism, and even in their curly hair and frivolity. Balmori’s romanticism comes across through his use of different motifs typical in a love story: the tubercular poet-lover, a passionate love triangle, a duel between rivals, and a forced marriage of convenience.

In depicting the conflict between conventionality and unorthodoxy, Balmori explores the role and position of women in society. They are allowed to participate in very limited social activities, and they are taught to develop a very timid and inhibited personality. In this novel, Angela thinks and acts ahead of her time, ahead of the moral norms of society. Although the society’s moral codes pressure her into marriage as a sign of acquiescence in the social system, Angela continues her defiance of norms by refusing to love her husband. Her marriage, perhaps, is an even greater form of rebellion than her sexual liaisons with her poet-lover, for she is operating within a conventional system to protect the product of her illicit affair, her baby.  Written by Reynaldo D. Coronel Jr

text:
(The Graveyard Caretaker). Published 1925. Author, MagdalenaJalandoni. Mandurriao, Iloilo: La Panayana.

This Ilonggo novel is generally considered as Jalandoni’s best work. Set in Iloilo, it is a love story within a story; the frame is set at the turn of the century, and the old caretaker of the graveyard tells the narrator his sentimental tale, which begins 45 years before, in 1863.

Maria, an orphan, grows up together with Ines and Jacinto, who are brother and sister. Their houses, along with Uyong Pedro’s, stand side by side along a quiet street near the plaza and the church. Jacinto is 10 years old; Ines and Maria are both seven. Having completed their catechism lessons given by Jacinto’s mother, the boy goes for further study in the seminary, and the girls to the convent school. When Jacinto comes home for vacation, he learns that Maria’s mother wants her betrothed to Emilio Olivares, belonging to one of the rich families in Salog Jaro, and she even asks him to convince her daughter. Maria refuses to be convinced for the simple reason, she tells Jacinto, that it is he she has loved since they were children. When he tells her mother of this, Tiya Silay turns on him, declaring she would rather see Maria die a laon or unmarried than have him as son-in-law. Maria chooses not to marry and promises herself to Jacinto.

During a cholera plague, Jacinto’s father dies, and Jacinto has to stop his studies to take over his father’s smithy, which he fails to make a success of. He is forced to sell everything and to go to faraway Camarines, promising Maria that when he comes back he will have enough money to start their life together. But he meets Leonor, a rich man’s daughter, with whom he gets engaged to be married. Ines writes to him and reminds him of his promise to Maria. At a fiesta, Jacinto overhears two men talking of Leonor’s past relationship with a married man that the whole town knows about. He breaks off the engagement and returns to Iloilo only to find Maria on her deathbed; and the grieving man promises to take loving care of her tomb to his dying day.

The sedate pacing, feminine imagery, and sentimental temper are all of a piece with the idealist treatment of the themes of love and fidelity. The poetic style of the first pages, set in a melancholy tone befitting the cemetery opening scene, immediately foreshadows future tragedy. Salog streets echo with the cloppety-clop of horse-drawn carretela or carriage and church bells ringing out the everyday rhythms in the Ilonggo’s lives: the fiesta in February, Holy Week in the summer months, weddings, and deaths.

In “Ang Akon Maragtas” (My Life Story), Jalandoni reveals that the characters in the novel are based on herself, her cousin Basilisa Gonzaga, and her brother Luis. Written by Victoria S. Calizo and Resil Mojares

Source

Velasco 1952.

text:
(Foreigner: A Song of War). Published 2006. Author, Charlson Ong. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The novel follows four Chinese immigrants who struggle to survive and thrive in their adopted country, the Philippines. Ah Puy, Ah Sun, Ah Tin, and Ah Beng become sworn brothers on the boat ride to Manila, a pact that is strained and worn and almost broken as they work, love, fight, and fall apart in the roller coaster of 20th-century Philippine history. Growing up, they must cross cultural, political, and linguistic gulfs between the Chinese enclave in the Philippines and a nation that is itself still just starting to form. Most of all, they must live with the all-shattering alienation known only to those whose sense of home has begun to shift and disintegrate.

These conflicts are explored in a mostly straightforward realist narration with some flashbacks and flashforwards. Supernatural elements occur occasionally in the text, but their presence is minimal. Chapters are told from different points of view.

The novel is divided into four parts that correspond to four historical periods: the American occupation, the Japanese occupation, the early Third Republic, martial law, and post-EDSA. These historical events propel the narrative forward. Thus, the novel invites alternate readings of history from the eyes of the Chinese minority, at different times tolerated and hated, abused and abusive. Well-known events are given greater depth and complexity (e.g., the dynamics of negotiation during the Chinese kidnappings), while lesser-known events, effaced in traditional historiography, are in this novel emphasized (e.g., the 1954 Retail Trade Nationalization Act or the Filipino-Chinese guerrillas fighting the Japanese).

Banyaga: A Song War intertwines the lives of its protagonists with Philippine history, showing that the Chinese have been active participants in its development. Fragment by fragment, Ong controls the dramatic tension so that every chapter ending is explosive and poignant. While this leads occasionally to scenes of melodrama, the writing is captivating, humorous, and human. No character is simplified or reduced to flat allegory. This polyphony highlights diversity in the Chinese community and resists the caricatures common to both Filipino stories about the Chinese and Filipino-Chinese stories about themselves and Filipinos.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
(Child, Child … How Were You Made?). Published 1983. Author, Lualhati Bautista. Manila: Emiro Printing. Second edition, Mandaluyong: Cacho Publishing House, 1991. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1984. Screenplay adaptation, Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa?: The Screenplay, Mandaluyong: Star Cinema and Cacho Publishing House, 1997.

The novel, composed of 32 chapters, is a celebration of the liberated woman who deviates from the conservative, Filipina paragon of virtue long upheld by conventional society. The protagonist, Lea Bustamante, is a human-rights worker and a mother to two children: Ojie and Maya. The first was fathered by Lea’s legal husband, Raffy, and the second, by her current live-in partner, Ding. At Parents-Teachers Association meetings, Lea’s patience and principles are tested against orthodox beliefs about being a mother, a wife, and a woman. Her children bear different surnames. Both men in her life, Raffy and Ding, blame Lea for all the family’s trials. Lea has a fling with Johnny, a married man who is her confidante and colleague.

The novel starts with Maya’s graduation, where she is awarded third honor and named Miss Kinder ’83. In the same ceremony, she recites a poem about reproduction. This irks the school principal, Mrs Zalamea, but she changes her mind when she learns that the mother, Lea, holds a meaningful job. At the graduation party, Lea’s feminism is manifested when she refuses to have her daughter join a beauty contest.

Lea’s character represents the quandaries of a single mother: Ojie is beginning to question their family arrangements. Ding walks out on them, leaving the children without a guardian while Lea must go to work. Meanwhile, Raffy has remarried and he and his wife are expecting a child. He asks to see Ojie, and he takes Lea and both children out.

After Ojie’s circumcision, Raffy invites him over to his home. When Lea and Ojie arrive, only Elinor, his wife, is in. Tension rises between the two women. Lea comes home to an angry Ding, who objects to Ojie’s stay at Raffy’s. Ding leaves again, and Lea is forced to take Maya to her workplace, where her daughter is exposed to human rights cases.

Raffy wants to take Ojie with him to the United States. Confused and angry, Ojie turns to gambling, and Lea hesitates to reprimand him, afraid that this will push him toward Raffy. But when Lea explains to him the difficulties of being a single mother, they arrive at a tearful understanding.

Lea flirts with her officemate, Johnny. A community project that involves the two living under the same roof is at hand, but Johnny exchanges places with Sister Anna, thus frustrating Lea’s fantasies. The two fathers meet when the two children are taken to a hospital after a bike accident, and they both blame Lea.

Lea confides in Johnny, who, after his initial hesitation, gives in to Lea’s advances. Chona, Johnny’s wife, visits Lea but, contrary to Lea’s apprehensions, it is to tell her that Johnny has been arrested without a warrant.

The death of Ninoy Aquino occurs, and political repression worsens. Sister Anna joins the underground movement. Children are not spared the regime’s long arm: Maya has a classmate whose father dies in a labor strike, and the family suffers as a consequence.

Meanwhile, Ding marries someone else and wants Maya to join him. Though Lea is stricken, she gives her children freedom of choice. Both Maya and Ojie choose her. The story, which begins with a graduation ceremony that puts Lea in trouble ends in another graduation ceremony the following year, with her delivering an inspirational talk about her nonconformist views on parenting.

Lea’s unconventional attitude influences her children, who express and act on their principles as they react to martial law. The exchanges between the innocent but outspoken children and their iconoclastic mother are the author’s means of analyzing the truths that they stand for. These fragmented truths are not resolved, though Lea’s speech at the novel’s end articulates them.

The book is a landmark in the history of Philippine fiction for its use of colloquial Taglish (Tagalog English), which is sustained through the novel. Thus, while it creates an impression of being an easy read, it dramatically and accurately captures the atmosphere of grim foreboding and constant fear that prevailed during the martial law era. In 1998, the novel was adapted to film with the same title.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

text:
(Story of Udan). Published 2009. Author, Telesforo S. Sungkit Jr. Quezon City: Central Book Supply Inc.

Written in Tagalog and Binukid (the author’s mother tongue), the novel is an intricate web of adventure, violence, romance, treachery, sacrifice, and love of banuwa (region/village/nation). Because this banuwa has resisted centuries of foreign invasion, indigenous myths and legends remain intact.

The central character is Udan, a young man from Hanapulon, who frees his people from the clutches of the evil Kalibato, Tium hu Gaun, and other malevolent tagbaya (supernatural beings). Udan’s adventure starts when his father, Datu Maghusay, tells him to join a caravan bringing manggad (dowry) to Impasug-ong. The journey will lead him, his tribe Hanapulon, and its neighboring banuwa—Lantapan, Yandang, Kimambong, Dalwangan, Impasug-ong, and Sumilaw—into a series of pangayaw (tribal wars) that will take the lives of almost all of his loved ones.

On the way to Impasug-ong, Udan loses his way. He follows a secret passage that leads to Lidasan, a world thought by his kin to be imaginary. Here Udan encounters various creatures—aligasi (giant), bakesan, tagbusaw, and mantianak, among others—that feed on humans. He suffers great misfortune and faces death eye to eye.

Lidasan, however, is also the place of Udan’s transformation. Here he attains the full realization of his power and discovers his place in the grand design of life, as bagani (warrior). He also meets Hapoy ha Tagkalegdeg, Bolak ha Mahumot, which means “blazing flame, fragrant flower,” or Ananaw, also an adept bagani, with whom he falls in love.

In his final encounter with the fiercest of his foes, Tium hu Gaun, the wind, whispers to Udan that he faces an enemy much stronger than he is; therefore, he must perform the saut (war dance). He knows that the message comes from the same tagbaya that has helped him defeat the aligasis, but aware by then of what befell his forebears when they accepted Tium hu Gaun’s help, he refuses to pawn his heart and liver for power that he knows he himself possesses and can muster.

Udan refuses to perform the saut. Enraged by such irreverence, the tagbaya summons a great whirlwind to subdue Udan. Udan, however, has already attained his full humanity “because everything that resides in his body has united and become one.” He fuses with the whirlwind. When the wind settles, the tagbaya is seen kneeling, pleading that Udan kill him as the vanquished deserves. Udan, however, orders the tagbaya to drift away with the breath of trees and gain strength instead. He commands the tagbaya to guard the land of his ancestors against typhoons (and that is why typhoons never visit Mindanao).

Then Udan beheads Tium hu Gaun. As the head rolls, lightning flashes and a thick black smoke envelops the place. When the air clears, the livers and hearts of all the humans eaten by Tium hu Gaun lie scattered. Beside each pair of liver and heart floats the gimokod (soul) of their owner. Udan has freed his ancestors from the curse of indebtedness and fulfills his destiny to be the greatest bagani of his people.

Batbat hi Udan is written by a lumad (indigenous people) of the Higaonon tribe, the first writer from Bukidnon to pen a literary piece of this kind, one rooted in the precolonial past. The novel uses the devices of the epic, as critic and novelist Edgar Samar notes. Parallelism is used, as it is in epics, not only as a mnemonic device but also as a means to enliven description. For instance, the author seals off most battle scenes with “Pingkian ng talim sa talim. Ng talim sa kalasag. Ng kalasag sa kalasag.” Such rendering does not only attest to the author’s storytelling prowess but also raises the novel to the level of fine poetry.  Written by Emmanuel V. Dumlao

On the way to Impasug-ong, Udan loses his way. He follows a secret passage that leads to Lidasan, a world thought by his kin to be imaginary. Here Udan encounters various creatures—aligasi (giant), bakesan, tagbusaw, and mantianak, among others—that feed on humans. He suffers great misfortune and faces death eye to eye.

Lidasan, however, is also the place of Udan’s transformation. Here he attains the full realization of his power and discovers his place in the grand design of life, as bagani (warrior). He also meets Hapoy ha Tagkalegdeg, Bolak ha Mahumot, which means “blazing flame, fragrant flower,” or Ananaw, also an adept bagani, with whom he falls in love.

In his final encounter with the fiercest of his foes, Tium hu Gaun, the wind, whispers to Udan that he faces an enemy much stronger than he is; therefore, he must perform the saut (war dance). He knows that the message comes from the same tagbaya that has helped him defeat the aligasis, but aware by then of what befell his forebears when they accepted Tium hu Gaun’s help, he refuses to pawn his heart and liver for power that he knows he himself possesses and can muster.

Udan refuses to perform the saut. Enraged by such irreverence, the tagbaya summons a great whirlwind to subdue Udan. Udan, however, has already attained his full humanity “because everything that resides in his body has united and become one.” He fuses with the whirlwind. When the wind settles, the tagbaya is seen kneeling, pleading that Udan kill him as the vanquished deserves. Udan, however, orders the tagbaya to drift away with the breath of trees and gain strength instead. He commands the tagbaya to guard the land of his ancestors against typhoons (and that is why typhoons never visit Mindanao).

Then Udan beheads Tium hu Gaun. As the head rolls, lightning flashes and a thick black smoke envelops the place. When the air clears, the livers and hearts of all the humans eaten by Tium hu Gaun lie scattered. Beside each pair of liver and heart floats the gimokod (soul) of their owner. Udan has freed his ancestors from the curse of indebtedness and fulfills his destiny to be the greatest bagani of his people.

Batbat hi Udan is written by a lumad (indigenous people) of the Higaonon tribe, the first writer from Bukidnon to pen a literary piece of this kind, one rooted in the precolonial past. The novel uses the devices of the epic, as critic and novelist Edgar Samar notes. Parallelism is used, as it is in epics, not only as a mnemonic device but also as a means to enliven description. For instance, the author seals off most battle scenes with “Pingkian ng talim sa talim. Ng talim sa kalasag. Ng kalasag sa kalasag.” Such rendering does not only attest to the author’s storytelling prowess but also raises the novel to the level of fine poetry.  Written by Emmanuel V. Dumlao

text:
(The Nation That Destroyed Itself). Published 1931-32. Author, Lazaro Francisco. Serialized in Alitaptap. An excerpt reprinted as Ang Pagbabangon (The Awakening) in Pipit-Puso, 1932. Reprinted as Ilaw sa Hilaga (Light in the North). Serialized in Liwayway, 1947-48. Reprinted as a book, Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co., 1980; Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1997.

Set in the 1920s in a town called San Carlos, the novel begins with the town’s wealthy capitalists, led by Don Benigno and Don Alejandro, plotting to destroy Heneral Masangkay. Masangkay’s bus company, Kalahi Transit Company, is a rival to the Philippine Transit Company, owned by Jewish-American Ishmael Hanzen and managed by his son, Ishmael Hanzen Jr. Don Benigno allies himself with Hanzen, and they use their power to cripple their business rivals.

The principled Masangkay is a hero in two revolutions. His adopted son, Javier Santos, educated at the University of the Philippines, is heir to the money left by his biological father, another revolutionary, and mother, a victim of the Spaniards. Masangkay and Javier are against any form of Western intervention, the infusion of foreign capital into the economy, and monopolies detrimental to the people’s interests. Together with Tomas, a teacher, they spearhead the move to preserve the local heritage from Americanization.

A romantic subplot is that of Javier and Anita, the daughter of Don Alejandro. Anita’s parents send her to Hong Kong, where she gives birth to a baby boy. Heneral Masangkay’s daughter Binyang, who is a personification of the ideal Filipino woman, rears the child. Binyang later assumes the leadership of the movement to propagate native ideals and protect the people’s interests.

The conspirators defeat Heneral Masangkay, and only the timely intervention of Javier saves the Kalahi Transit Company. Javier, too, eventually gives up, but first sets fire to his building and the buses. When a badly burned corpse is discovered, the people think it is Javier’s. Javier returns to San Carlos disguised as a mysterious and affluent foreign businessman named Rey Vajt Ossan. He parades a fleet of brand new buses, builds a rice mill, and soon lords it over San Carlos as a successful and benevolent businessman. The businesses of Don Benigno and Hanzen flounder.

The townspeople—rich and poor alike—gradually realize that they must bond together for the common good. As the movement gains more followers, Ossan initiates a series of moves—charging higher fare, raking in huge profits, and running down other businesses—that incense the people. Led by a now reformed Don Benigno, they offer to buy him out but are unable to raise the whole amount. Ossan relents, stipulating that half of what they owe him be given to Heneral Masangkay and Binyang, and the other half to Anita and her son, Froilan. In the final scene, Javier, his friends, and family are reunited.

The novel addresses crucial issues then prevailing: monopolies, the oligarchy, and the feudal system. Driven by poverty and desperation, for example, 400 tenants on Don Benigno’s farm are forced to migrate to Hawaii to be cheap labor. The novel also criticizes the landlord class’s shift from basic food production to an export economy. In one section, a landowner decides to stop planting rice and cultivate sugar instead because Hanzen plans to build a sugar mill.

Jose Rizal’s two novels are clearly the main source of this work. The fictional town of San Carlos is like Rizal’s San Diego, a microcosm of Philippine society. Like Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1886, Francisco begins his novel with a banquet to reveal the personalities of the major characters. Javier is a combination of Ibarra and Simoun. His attempts to conduct business aboveboard fail because the people themselves are uncooperative. Like Simoun, he comes back in disguise and uses more forceful means. Not by accident, the resolution happens on Dec 30, the anniversary of Rizal’s execution.  Written by Soledad Reyes
