text:
Published 2010. Author, Criselda Yabes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press. Gawad Likhaan: The UP Centennial Literary Prize for fiction in English, 2008.

Set against the backdrop of the burning of Jolo in 1974, the novel covers a momentous time in Zamboanga and Jolo history. The Muslim rebellion and the burning of Jolo, it reveals, wound not just the people directly involved but also the entire nation.

The novel is divided into two parts. The first concerns Rosy France Wright, a young mestiza from Zamboanga, and her fatal romance with Prof Omar Hassan, a Muslim. Despite the forbidden nature of their love, Rosy France abandons her comfortable home in Zamboanga City and elopes with Hassan to Jolo, then a city where Christians and Muslims live in harmony. The ambitions of Hassan, however, and his mysterious trips to Sabah soon put an end to that peace: he leads a rebellion against the government.

The second part of the novel details Rosy France’s escape to Zamboanga City, her eventual return to Jolo, now a ghost of its old self, and her long wait for her rebel husband to come back. She endures the difficulties of living in a city now governed by fear, but she can never move past her sense of responsibility to her missing husband. When Hassan returns, he too is but a ghost of the man she used to know. The firebrand and idealist in him have been replaced by a scheming, bitter failure of a man. Rosy France, however, remains loyal to him until the very end.

The novel also tells the story of Rosy France’s friend Nahla, a Tausug, and her ill-fated romance with Captain Rodolfo. Nahla dreams of leaving Jolo to become an actress in Manila. But Captain Rodolfo’s duties prevent them from leaving Mindanao, and Nahla finds herself trapped in a life she yearns to escape from and a lover who has suddenly become cold to her. In the end, she decides that there is no escaping who she is.

These stories are woven together by the unnamed omniscient narrator, a woman who has a deep connection to Rosy France but whose own story and whose obsession with Jolo remain a mystery.

All the characters are wounded: Nahla by her frustrated desire to be other than who she is, Captain Rodolfo by his inability to protect the woman he loves, Professor Hassan by his failure to establish the Bangsamoro Republic, Rosy France by Hassan’s abandonment of her, and the narrator by her displacement from Jolo early in her life. The silent witness to all the drama is Bud Datu, the Crying Mountain, so-called because it is always surrounded by mist. Watching over Jolo, it is the repository of the people’s glory and shame.

Rosy France is given a second chance to build a new life, an ending which suggests that life can go on in the wake of tragedy. Rosy France’s wounded heart will heal, just as the burned city can be rebuilt, and the ugly wound festering in Mindanao can be salved.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Benjamin: Novela con Panuguiron nga Binisaya
text:
(Benjamin: Visayan Novel or Tale). Published 1907. Author, Angel M. Magahum. Mandurriao, Iloilo: La Panayana. Reprinted, 1918.

This first known Ilonggo novel was written, according to the author, in 1894. The preface of the book laments the state of native literature where the only “literary” works available to those who cannot read Spanish are novenas and vidas, which are “far from the truth and becloud the mind and imagination with empty fantasies.” Thus, the preface says, the importance of Benjamin lies in its function, which, in the nature of novels, teaches manners and morals.

In the novel, old Benjamin tells the story of his life to the author. A spoiled youth, Benjamin goes to Manila to study and there falls to bad ways. He gets a woman, Inocencia, with child and causes the death of the woman’s mother. Incurring heavy gambling losses, he deserts Inocencia and returns to his hometown. Here he marries Margarita who turns out to be headstrong, jealous, and ill mannered. He begins to appreciate in retrospect Inocencia’s worth. A letter, however, informs him that Inocencia and the child have died. Margarita begins to be addicted to gambling and has an affair with Pepito, a family friend, who fathers her child. Benjamin later learns about it all through a letter in which Pepito reveals that this has been his way of exacting revenge: he is in truth Serafin, Inocencia’s brother. He also tells Benjamin that he has kidnapped Benjamin’s son, Margarito.

Benjamin goes in a vain search for his son. Margarita becomes mad and dies. In grief, Benjamin sells all his properties and goes to Sugbu. On the boat, he witnesses a mutiny: a man who turns out to be Serafin has the captain and his wife killed and their three children cast ashore. Later, the boat sinks in a fire and Serafin dies. Benjamin and the three children are later rescued by another vessel. In Sugbu, Benjamin devotes himself to good works. He is, however, robbed of all his belongings and is forced to go back to his hometown. Here, the novel comes full circle, with the poor old Benjamin finishing the recounting of his story.

The novel warns against the sins and excesses of heedless youth, and teaches nobility and generosity of heart. In the manner of didactic narratives, lessons are conveyed in proverbial form and analogies. For example, the fish in the trap is Benjamin caught in the snares of the world; Margarita is a fruit smooth and red on the outside but bitter inside.

Belonging to the Philippine literary tradition of “books of conduct” and the didactic korido or metrical romance, the novel sheds light on the impulses behind the first Philippine novels. On the one hand, it is supposed to be taken from the account of “an old man,” narrating what “has happened or is likely to happen.” It is a larauan or mirror of “true happenings of life … things we can see with our eyes from day to day.” On the other hand, it is intended to be an “example” so that bad ways can be avoided.  Written by Resil Mojares

text:
Published 1997. Author, Gina Apostol. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 1998.

A work about love, lust, and literature, Bibliolepsy follows the early life of Primi Peregrino, a self-identified bibliolept, or a person who fawns and falls over writers and their books. Her story is divided into two parts. Part 1 details her family history and the childhood roots of her condition. Part 2 sweeps through her turbulent adolescence, her love affairs and identity crises, as the Marcos era comes to a close.

The novel is constructed in fragments of various styles and sizes, and one must piece the story together from lists, interpolations, confessed contradictions, and other narrative techniques. Although the novel unfolds mostly chronologically, the narrator frequently digresses to explicate other topics, more often than not about bibliolepsy itself.

The novel problematizes the narrative truth in both personal and national identity. What seems at first to be its mere bourgeois indifference to oppression and social change is in fact informed by postmodern skepticism about the construction of narratives via fictional devices. The biblioleptic condition is one that is consistently expressed vis-à-vis the sexual, the seismic epiphanies of passion. Its opposite—abstract intellectual discourse and categorizations of text and world—is considered distasteful and untrustworthy to Primi. Thus, the novel itself avoids the neat, linear, and forced connections of the typical traditional plot. Thus, also, the EDSA Revolt is constructed primarily through two nondominant lenses: a stereotypically rendered folk religious movement emphasizing faith and feeling (which is again couched in the sexual) and Primi’s own detached and biblioleptic skepticism.

Naturally, however, Primi’s self-image is itself treated as unreliable in the text: while making decisions in life, the bibliolept intentionally tries to follow the examples/images of canonical authors, implying a subscription to the scripts and plot structures used to construct those authors’ biographies. Primi’s life is therefore already suffused with fictional devices and constructions. At the same time, it is revealed that Primi is unsure of her own memories—in one instance, readily admitting the possibility of fabrication; in another instance, clinging desperately to her memory. Underlying all this is a subconscious yearning for reconciliation with her past and with something which she does not even recognize yet, but which seems to affect her every decision.

Bibliolepsy intersects sex, literature, and history to deconstruct the ways in which people structure what they perceive to be their realities. Above all, however, the work is as its title says: boldly biblioleptic. Apostol’s writing crackles with poetry, originality, and wit. Not a line is lazy, not a word is used without care. Whatever one thinks of its politics, it is nonetheless a novel artfully crafted, a work in love with literature.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
Published 1984. Author, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga. With a foreword by Virgilio S. Almario, a Filipino translation by Romulo A. Sandoval, and illustrations by Ludwig Ilio. Quezon City: New Day Publishers. Philippine Writers’ Foundation writing grant.

Salanga’s only published book of fiction, deftly translated into Tagalog by Sandoval, is a novella with a near epic scope; it covers the period of the 1896 Revolution until the Americans’ return to the Philippines in World War II. The prologue describes the portentous birthing of Hannibal Valdez at an American camp on a stormy night. The delivery by a drunk American doctor costs Hannibal his left eye and his mother her life. Only his grandfather, Colonel Valdez, is pleased with this turn of events, seeing Hannibal as the one to inherit his place as a legendary officer of the Philippine Revolution, an aspiration which Hannibal’s father, Antonio, failed to live up to.

The subsequent sections of the novel consist of the colonel’s recollection of his personal history, tracing the events of his rise from being a son of a poor man to becoming the town’s revolutionary leader and most powerful landowner: his initial foray into the local resistance movement; his leading a victorious charge against a handful of Spanish guards in the poblacion (town); and his eventual appointment as a colonel by a retreating Emilio Aguinaldo, who needed someone to delay the Americans running after him.

All this he recounts to the American Major Weepingwillow, commander of the camp, whom he holds in high regard, while also expressing his resentment at the lack of recognition he has suffered.

Salanga renders the colonel’s character as different from that formed in the usual mold of heroes. Shifting skillfully between the colonel’s retelling and the events unfolding at the wake, Salanga exposes the colonel as a vacillating nationalist, a domineering, misogynistic patriarch, and a ruthless landlord, who, driven by his ambition and cunning, will do anything to achieve his goal. His moral ambiguity is underscored by the colonel’s casual admission to Weepingwillow of his own acts of betrayal of his fellow revolutionaries.

More significant is how the novella demonstrates how individual acts, regardless of their moral and historical ramifications, are intertwined with larger social forces. Colonel Valdez’s dubious deeds are framed within Philippine colonial realities like the feudal system, patriarchy, and uneven racial relations. Colonel Valdez justifies his acts by implying that he has merely prevailed over social structures imposed by Spanish colonialism and the American occupation.

Colonel Valdez’s narration concludes with a disturbing confession. In the epilogue, the reader is again made aware of this dark legacy which Colonel Valdez wants Hannibal desperately to inherit.

In the introduction, Almario emphasizes how the novella avoids “mystifying history.” Using the bloodstained Colonel Valdez as chronicler, Salanga poses the challenge of how one may resolve historical contradictions. In The Birthing of Hannibal Valdez, Salanga offers a critique, not just of personalities that make Philippine history, but of the ways in which history itself is written and perceived.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

The subsequent sections of the novel consist of the colonel’s recollection of his personal history, tracing the events of his rise from being a son of a poor man to becoming the town’s revolutionary leader and most powerful landowner: his initial foray into the local resistance movement; his leading a victorious charge against a handful of Spanish guards in the poblacion (town); and his eventual appointment as a colonel by a retreating Emilio Aguinaldo, who needed someone to delay the Americans running after him.
All this he recounts to the American Major Weepingwillow, commander of the camp, whom he holds in high regard, while also expressing his resentment at the lack of recognition he has suffered.

Salanga renders the colonel’s character as different from that formed in the usual mold of heroes. Shifting skillfully between the colonel’s retelling and the events unfolding at the wake, Salanga exposes the colonel as a vacillating nationalist, a domineering, misogynistic patriarch, and a ruthless landlord, who, driven by his ambition and cunning, will do anything to achieve his goal. His moral ambiguity is underscored by the colonel’s casual admission to Weepingwillow of his own acts of betrayal of his fellow revolutionaries.

More significant is how the novella demonstrates how individual acts, regardless of their moral and historical ramifications, are intertwined with larger social forces. Colonel Valdez’s dubious deeds are framed within Philippine colonial realities like the feudal system, patriarchy, and uneven racial relations. Colonel Valdez justifies his acts by implying that he has merely prevailed over social structures imposed by Spanish colonialism and the American occupation.
Colonel Valdez’s narration concludes with a disturbing confession. In the epilogue, the reader is again made aware of this dark legacy which Colonel Valdez wants Hannibal desperately to inherit.

In the introduction, Almario emphasizes how the novella avoids “mystifying history.” Using the bloodstained Colonel Valdez as chronicler, Salanga poses the challenge of how one may resolve historical contradictions. In The Birthing of Hannibal Valdez, Salanga offers a critique, not just of personalities that make Philippine history, but of the ways in which history itself is written and perceived.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

text:
(A Strand of Ester’s Hair). Published 1911. Author, Aurelio Tolentino. Manila: Faustino Pineda Gutierrez. Reprinted, 1914 and 1931.

The text of the first edition of Ester is prefaced by an open letter to Tolentino from Felino Simpao, a prominent writer of that period. In it, Simpao expresses hearty approval of the novel’s didacticism and admiration for its lyrical use of Kapampangan. Simpao’s enthusiastic endorsement of the novel helped boost its circulation. Faustino Pineda Gutierrez, who prepared the third edition, was the editor-publisher of Ing Catimawan, a magazine regarded as the Kapampangan counterpart of the Tagalog Liwayway. The title page refers to Ester as “ing novela ring anggang novela” (the novel of all novels), no doubt an exaggerated claim but one that testifies to its high reputation among Kapampangan readers.

The longest Kapampangan novel, Ing Buac nang Ester is unique in Kapampangan fiction because, while most novels recount the twists and turns that a love affair takes, Ester’s love story is merely an excuse for the main plot. Gerardo, the adopted son of Don Luis Gatsalian, is jealous of Ruben, Don Luis’s real son. The latter, home from medical studies, is being feted at a dinner where there is talk about his entering politics. He is engaged to be married to the beautiful Gloria, with whom Gerardo is also in love. With the assistance of Dimas, a bandit, Gerardo abducts Gloria. He then kidnaps Ruben and frames him for both the abduction and Gloria’s murder. Gerardo does this by staging a scene where he, disguised as Ruben, actually poisons his mistress Quintana, who is disguised as Gloria. On the basis of the testimony of several eyewitnesses, Ruben is tried in absentia and is sentenced to hang.

The resourceful Oscar, Ruben’s best friend, devises an elaborate ruse to capture the real villain. He advertises a reward for the return of a folded handkerchief bearing a strand of hair belonging to Ester, Ruben’s sister and Oscar’s sweetheart. Ester had given Oscar the strand of hair as a pledge of love, but later asked Ruben to retrieve it from Oscar. Having earlier seen Ruben put the handkerchief in her breast pocket, Oscar hopes that whoever claims the reward will lead him to Ruben’s whereabouts.

But before the avaricious Gerardo can claim the reward, the police find Ruben and arrest him for murder. Oscar tries to save Ruben from the gallows by falsely confessing to the crime. He hopes in this way to call for a reinvestigation of the case. In the meantime, Gloria’s rape by Gerardo is prevented by Juaning, Dimas’s wife who is later killed. Dimas repents and confesses the whole truth to Gloria, pointing to Gerardo as the mastermind of the sinister plot. Gloria returns to town in time to prevent the hanging of Oscar, publicly accusing Gerardo of the crime. When Gerardo calls her a liar, Gloria grabs from his coat pocket the handkerchief with a strand of Ester’s hair wrapped in it. Thus, at the end, it is a simple strand of Ester’s hair that incriminates the guilty Gerardo.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

text:
(Wildflower). Published 1955. Author, Conrado J. Norada. Serialized in Hiligaynon, 1955. Reprinted in Hiligaynon, 1993.

This is one of Norada’s most popular novels. Its critique of society is made within the framework of a love story. Edgardo Nufable, a medical student in Manila, receives the disturbing news from his father in his hometown Santol that his townspeople are being exploited by the Cardoces. Although Edgardo wants to help the townsfolk, his friend Arturo advises him to finish his studies first. When Edgardo visits his father in Santol, he discovers how the Cardoces have been manipulating the people. The Cardoces have forced the people to sell their fishing boats and to rely on Cardoce-owned vessels; they have also isolated the area so that the people are forced to buy medicine from them at high prices. Moreover, Bruno Cardoce, the mayor, has allowed the public school to rot. But following his friend’s advice, Edgardo returns to Manila to finish his studies. He comes back to Santol a doctor.

In contrast to his professional success is his love life. Rodora, the daughter of a ranch overseer, hesitates to accept him, unconvinced that Edgardo could love a woman of her class when there are other more sophisticated women swooning for him. To complicate matters, Bruno is also in love with Rodora. The rivalry between Edgardo and Bruno culminates in a near fistfight. A typhoid epidemic strikes Santol. Rodora’s father and Bruno’s mother die; Rodora herself is stricken but is saved by Edgardo. Meanwhile, the Philippine Constabulary discovers Bruno’s treachery. He is implicated in the disappearance of a suitor of Rodora and an engineer sent by the governor to supervise the public school, which Bruno had neglected. Bruno escapes the authorities and tries to take Rodora with her. The girl refuses him. Bruno is later found dead. Edgardo falls ill, physically enervated by work and emotionally wounded by unrequited love. Rodora learns from Tia Meding how Edgardo stayed by her bedside during her illness. Realizing that he sincerely loves her, she nurses him. Arturo arrives, now also a doctor, and cures Edgardo. The epidemic is stopped; and the lovers are happily united in each other’s arms.

The novel makes good use of foils to highlight character. Bruno’s corruption is contrasted with the governor’s earnest efforts to improve Santol. The governor, well intentioned and committed to serve, is aptly named Fidel. But Norada does not oversimplify his characters. Among the evil Cardoces is a good daughter, Adelita, who remains unspoiled by her family’s greed.

This novel marks a shift in Norada’s career as a novelist. Read avidly for his detective thrillers and romantic plots, Norada, in this novel, focuses on the ills of the ruling class, on political corruption and economic exploitation, symbolically represented by the epidemic. That the Cardoce matriarch dies from the epidemic is a sign that evil is, in the end, self-destructive. That Edgardo and Arturo, both young doctors, succeed in controlling the plague seems to point to Norada’s optimistic belief that the youth can make a difference.   Written by Jonathan Chua

 

Source

Morales, Noemi T. 1980. “The Novels of Conrado Norada.” Master’s thesis, University of the Philippines.

text:
(The Skull). Published 1946. Author, Alberto Segismundo Cruz. Manila: Palimbagang Tagumpay. Reprinted, Piling Nobela: Lakandula, Halimuyak, Ang Bungo (Selected Novels: Lakandula, Scent, The Skull), Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1997.

Ang Bungo became for post-World War II readers a recreation of some facets of a momentous event that they had only just experienced. Like the writer’s other novels, Ang Bungo provides historically specific details of time and milieu that help one reconstruct various events in the war.

The novel’s protagonist is a guerrilla fighter, Ricardo Lakandula, who sows fear in the hearts of the Japanese soldiers. When a Japanese soldier attempts to lob a grenade at a platoon of Filipino soldiers, Ricardo throws himself at the Japanese. His body is badly burned, but he survives, his nose blown away and his cheeks turned into cavernous holes.

Thus, it is as the terrifying “Skull” that he attacks enemy camps and ambushes truckloads of Japanese soldiers. He dons an attire that makes him, in the darkness, look like a skeleton on a warpath. Although a sharpshooter, Ricardo’s favored weapon is his bow and arrow by which quietly and stealthily he can execute his enemies. He thus appears both as a vicious killer and as a symbol of death.

Ricardo fights incessantly in the company of his fellow guerrilla fighters until the end of the war in 1945. But the damage has been done not only on his face but also on his psyche: he thinks that with his hideous appearance he is less than human. Despite the pleas of his friend Demetrio, he decides not to return to barrio Balimbing where Sinang, a teacher he loves, still lives. The novel then shifts to the end of the war. The returning guerrilla soldiers are hailed by a grateful community. Ricardo, however, is declared missing in action, a fact that causes Sinang great sorrow. Demetrio meets an American soldier who speaks excellent Tagalog, has the build and complexion of a Filipino, but otherwise looks like an American with reddish hair. The soldier falls in love with Sinang.

In the denouement, where Demetrio is being accused of lying about Ricardo’s fate, the soldier explains that he is really Ricardo Lakandula, taken to Australia by an American officer as the war ended, where he had plastic surgery. Sinang and Ricardo, no longer the man with the repulsive appearance, are married.

This slight volume, like numerous novels published in weekly magazines, advanced a thesis: Filipino men never lack courage and fortitude, while Filipino women are gentle, caring, and faithful. In 1946, the racial stereotypes abounded and were mirrored in popular consciousness. Thus, the Japanese soldiers are symbols of cruelty, savagery, and barbarism, while American soldiers are generally perceived as benevolent and compassionate, true friends of the Filipinos. Ricardo takes on some qualities of the American—his physical appearance, his American accent—but he never loses his essential Filipino-ness. It would take more time before these taken-for-granted notions regarding race and identity were problematized.

Cruz’s depiction of both Ricardo and Sinang as exemplars is set against one of the most trying periods in history—the war and the process of reconstruction. Ang Bungo derives its significance from its graphic depiction of interrelated events in the nation’s history.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Destroyed Fish Corrals). Published 1928-29. Author, Biyan Torinoy, pseud. of Sulpicio Osorio. Serialized in Bag-ong Kusog, 28 Jun 1928–25 Oct 1929. No copies of the book edition can be found in Philippine libraries.

Published under the pseudonym Biyan Torinoy, the novel is one of Sulpicio Osorio’s most popular novels. The work is an attack against commercialism and immorality in the church and, as such, it stirred much controversy.

The protagonist Federico returns to Luonon after over a decade in the United States and is dismayed at the lack of progress in the community. He is especially indignant over the increase of the kapilya, or makeshift chapels, which he compares to bungsod, or fish corrals, set up by the priests to draw in the people’s money. With a group of young friends, he leads an association to expose the malpractices of the clergy, especially Pari Pedro, the town’s lecherous and greedy priest. The youth association steps up its campaign for the abolition of kapilya and devotional associations, the ouster of Pari Pedro, and for religious tolerance in the town. But sensing the entrenched power of the priest and his influential friends, the young men decide to adopt another approach. They feign accommodation with the priest when they run for the town council to gain leverage in the fight against the cleric. The young men get elected and declare their true aims. Eventually, they succeed in their campaign against blind veneration and clerical abuses, and Pari Pedro himself changes his ways.

The novel has a polemical intent. All through the work, the novel attacks and satirizes blind and wasteful religious “devotions” on the part of the people and the moral turpitude of the clergy. It criticizes ignorance, fanaticism, and the collusion of the priest with the caciques who live off the difficulties of a people driven to indebtedness because of their backward beliefs.

The allusions in the book—Jose Rizal, Konde sa Monte Kristo (The Count of Monte Cristo), Guzzoni, Marcelo H. del Pilar, Graciano Lopez Jaena—indicate the anticlerical tradition with which the novel identifies itself. However, the novel lacks the breadth of this tradition, for it misses the vaster ramifications of protest that one finds in Rizal and del Pilar. Nevertheless, compared to other Cebuano novels of its time, Osorio’s work is a faster-paced, better-knit, and more engrossing story. In plain narrative qualities, it is a superior work; but it is conceived for popular serialization as topical fiction, and herein one also finds an explanation for the laxity of thought and execution to which it is prone, such as the sudden conversion of Pari Pedro.  Written by Resil Mojares

text:
(Pure Gold). Published 1931. Author, Serapion Torre. Iloilo: Balhagan Kabisay-an.

This Ilonggo novel is a landmark in the history of literature in Ilonggo because of its extraordinary affective quality. After its publication, the novel of sensibility, characterized by impulsive heroes and fainting heroines, gained wide popular appeal. Torre’s popularity was such that newspapers carrying his novels were quickly sold out. His reputation as the best of the early Ilonggo novelists was supposed to have started with Bus-ug nga Bulawan and another sentimental novel, Mater Dolorosa.

A convoluted romantic plot—of two scheming women, treacherous letters, misunderstanding between couples passionately in love, long-lost loves, and coincidental meetings—is interwoven with social issues like the gap between the rich and poor, the labor problem, and government corruption. Carlota causes the estrangement of the married couple, Adela and Pedro, by arranging a compromising situation between Adela and another man. A jealous husband, Pedro walks out on Adela, who is pregnant. Twenty years later, Adela moves with her daughter Inocencia to Manila under an assumed name. At the university, Inocencia and Ramon fall in love but Ramon’s guardian disapproves. He is Pedro, who does not recognize Inocencia as his daughter. Again, interference causes the young couple’s separation. A fire accident finally brings the two ill-fated couples together.

Although a romantic novel, Bus-ug also addresses a number of social issues, such as Filipino complacency and laziness, or the government’s lack of vision and planning regarding the exploitation of natural resources in Mindanao. Written at a time when literature was expected to “teach and delight,” this novel satisfied both critics and readers with its lengthy digressions on social issues and its linguistic coinages.  Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

text:
(Slave of Fate). Published 1909. Author, Faustino Aguilar. Manila: Manila Filatelica.

This Tagalog novel was among the first to deal with the subject of the prostitute as a fallen woman victimized by society. Celso, scion of a rich family, chooses to be a writer rather than to be a professional, as his father would wish him to be. He learns that for the right amount of money, he could have the most sought-after prostitute in a popular brothel. The description of the woman reminds him of his sweetheart Rita who mysteriously disappeared two years ago. He lies to his mother to get the money, and goes off to get the woman who, it turns out, is Rita.

How Rita has become a prostitute is told in a lengthy narrative flashback about trust and betrayal. Pepe, husband of Berta, relative of the couple who adopted her, rapes her, and gets her pregnant. He later sells her to the owner of the brothel, where she is repeatedly raped by all kinds of men. To add insult to injury, she even ends up indebted to the owner in the amount of 200 pesos.

Shocked by this revelation, Celso decides to take her away from the brothel. His friends and parents condemn him for loving a notorious prostitute. Celso is utterly devastated by this turn of events. He realizes that Rita is the only person left who cares anything about him. They share a brief period of togetherness. Celso goes on with his job as a writer while Rita, physically and emotionally spent, stays in their love nest. But one day she falls severely ill. A priest comes to minister to her, but to his outrage, Rita condemns society, which has done her much injustice. Instead of penitence, she expresses joy over the love shared between her and Celso. After Rita dies, Celso is confined to an asylum for the insane.

The love story is tragic, contextualized within larger social issues, such as gender relations, society’s pervasive role in forming values and influencing relationships, as well as the role of a benighted religion and its ministers in the lives of people. Rita is fully fleshed out as a developing character: from a timid and demure girl to an adult woman forced into a life of sordidness to a human being with the moral courage and fierce will to defend herself and her love. Celso, her lover, is the sole exception in Rita’s unjust surroundings. Like her, he possesses moral courage to fight for what he loves and cherishes.

The novelist succeeds not only in portraying the gross injustice that people, particularly men, can bring upon their fellow human beings, but also in indicting social institutions such as the church. In the novel, Aguilar turns sarcastic in his descriptions of the religiosity and piety manifested by Celso’s mother, and in his caricature of the sanctimoniousness of the priest listening to Rita’s tirades against society’s hypocrisy and self-righteousness.   Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

article.value: (Slave of Fate). Published 1909. Author, Faustino Aguilar. Manila: Manila Filatelica.

This Tagalog novel was among the first to deal with the subject of the prostitute as a fallen woman victimized by society. Celso, scion of a rich family, chooses to be a writer rather than to be a professional, as his father would wish him to be. He learns that for the right amount of money, he could have the most sought-after prostitute in a popular brothel. The description of the woman reminds him of his sweetheart Rita who mysteriously disappeared two years ago. He lies to his mother to get the money, and goes off to get the woman who, it turns out, is Rita.

How Rita has become a prostitute is told in a lengthy narrative flashback about trust and betrayal. Pepe, husband of Berta, relative of the couple who adopted her, rapes her, and gets her pregnant. He later sells her to the owner of the brothel, where she is repeatedly raped by all kinds of men. To add insult to injury, she even ends up indebted to the owner in the amount of 200 pesos.

Shocked by this revelation, Celso decides to take her away from the brothel. His friends and parents condemn him for loving a notorious prostitute. Celso is utterly devastated by this turn of events. He realizes that Rita is the only person left who cares anything about him. They share a brief period of togetherness. Celso goes on with his job as a writer while Rita, physically and emotionally spent, stays in their love nest. But one day she falls severely ill. A priest comes to minister to her, but to his outrage, Rita condemns society, which has done her much injustice. Instead of penitence, she expresses joy over the love shared between her and Celso. After Rita dies, Celso is confined to an asylum for the insane.

text:
Published 1970. Author, Wilfrido Nolledo. New York: E. P. Dutton.

An extreme response to the Filipino writer’s obsession with the question of identity, this novel would seem to sum up the motifs and themes of the search for identity as the writer in English had pursued it for an entire decade. The subject matter of the novel is Philippine history; in particular, the history of Filipinos during the Japanese occupation. The novel, however, is less interested in historical events per se than in the meaning that those events evoke from the phantasmagoric plot unreeled by the author. The action swirls cinematically around a delicately beautiful young woman who is nameless for the greater part of the novel until we are told she is Maria Alma, a name that identifies her as the symbol for the inviolate spirit of the Filipino. Maria Alma has a male alter ego, an ugly young man named Molave Amoran who stands for the colonized native as brutalized by a succession of masters. The novel is peopled by a gallery of character types representing various aspects of the colonial history of the country, many of them grotesque parodies of mythological figures from the Philippines and from Europe. The major characters represent the Philippines and its foreign colonizers: Spain, America, and Japan.

The story is set in Tira Colombo’s boarding house, which embodies the confusion of cultures that is Filipino life and represents a cross section of the lower classes. It begins with Hidalgo finding Alma and ends with the surrender of the Japanese forces in Manila. All the major characters—except Alma and Amoran—die in the last air raid of the “Liberation.” There are Hidalgo, the proud but dying relic of the Philippines’ Spanish past; Jonas Winters, the American pilot turned Savior by the Filipino people; Shigura, the ambiguous Japanese major who constantly trails Alma on a white horse; and Amoran the Filipino scavenger, soul of pragmatism, who in the end saves Alma’s life.

Hidalgo lives in an idealized memory of the Spanish period; in his reminiscences Intramuros lives with its “smoky, winding streets, the cobblestones, the mosques and cupolas, all of it pulsing and polychromatic.” He takes Alma under his wing, and jealously guards their relationship. Captain Jonas Winters is America ingratiating itself into the Philippines with the subtlety of seduction. To him, Alma bestows a kiss, and to him she is sexually attracted. However, the complementarity between Amoran and Alma is symbolized, not only by their names, but by their equal appreciation of music, Alma dancing to Amoran’s guitar playing. Amoran, toward the war’s end, carries Alma to safety on his back, Aenas-like. As a symbol of the Filipino identity, he wins out in the end.

A work of epic proportions and intention, the novel celebrates the grace and hardiness of the Filipino people in a literary language that is recognizably English but heavily interlaced with Tagalog and Spanish epithets and puns, making for a truly awesome display of verbal splendor.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero, Bienvenido L. Lumbera, and Cynthia Nograles Lumbera

text:
(The Champion). Published 2013. Editor, Salvador Garcia. With an introduction by the editor, and notes by the editor and Luisa Young. Author, Antonio M. Abad. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press for the Embassy of Spain, Instituto Cervantes de Manila, School of Humanities, Ateneo de Manila University, and Colegio de San Luis (Mexico). Commonwealth Literary Contests, novel in Spanish, 1940.

This novel is an expansion of “El Dolor del Viejo Campeon” (The Anguish of an Old Champion), which won in a short story contest sponsored by the newspaper La Defensa in 1928, then managed by Enrique Fernandez Lumba.

The dramatis personae of the novel include roosters, hens, and the recurring characters in Abad’s works: the politicians of his time, priests, journalists, and the Cebuano. The story is an autobiography of Banogon, an aging champion fighting cock. Crippled from his last fight, the ex-fighter is now confined in the chicken coop to help in the propagation of first-rate fighting roosters. For such a noble end, he is spared the usual luck of losers—the frying pan. However, he is so disabled that any attempt of his to embrace his beloved causes excruciating pain. He consequently becomes impotent. However, his luck holds, for the caretaker, especially fond of him, spares his life. But a more tragic fate awaits him in the coop. He finds, to his anguish, his long-lost sweetheart, who broke his heart when she eloped with a Don Juan of a rooster. In his autobiography, Banogon expresses his joys and anguish, his philosophy of life, his Solomonic observations on human behavior and attitudes. He deliberates with wit and humor, giving us a “rooster’s view” of the human world.

Abad, who has a tendency to be encyclopedic in the tradition of costumbrismo, a manner of writing which details local mores and customs, provides the reader with a virtual treatise on the art and science of breeding fighting cocks, a topic he expounds on in another novel, La Oveja de Nathan (Nathan’s Sheep), 1928.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

text:
Published 1972-73. Author, Liwayway Arceo. Serialized in Liwayway, 13 Nov 1972–21 May 1973. Reprinted as a book, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1985.

Published soon after the declaration of martial law in Sep 1972, it became a victim of editorial censorship, with many of its sections dealing with activism and political issues deleted. Even in emasculated form, however, Canal de la Reina departs from Arceo’s earlier works which deal mostly with domestic family relationships. The world of her numerous novels is usually devoid of social context, focusing on private suffering and pain, the sense of loss felt by women, who find themselves overwhelmed by traditional values which often stifle individual initiative and creativity.

The novel takes its title from a place in Tondo, Manila, which used to be a scenic spot, when the estero or canal was still a clean and living waterway. As the story begins, the place has lost much of its beauty and charm. It is an area inhabited by the poorest of the city’s poor. Lording it over them is Nyora Tentay, whose ownership of the place is contested by Caridad. Nyora Tentay ruthlessly sucks the blood of those who, out of desperation, run to her for usurious loans. She does not spare even her own family. She has caused her son Victor to separate from his wife Gracia. One day, a big flood comes, sweeping away everything in its path, including the shanties built precariously along the dried-up, clogged estero. The floodwaters show no mercy for the house of Nyora Tentay, who loses all of her money and jewelry. The usurer goes mad, unable to cope with the loss of all her material possessions. The really unlucky ones, and there are many, perish in the flood. As the novel ends, there is promise of change. The squatters are moved to a safer place. On the lot they will vacate, a hospital is to be built to service the needs of the poor. This project is initiated by Gerry, the activist son of Gracia and Victor, and by Leni, the daughter of Caridad. After undergoing treatment, Nyora Tentay regains her sanity. She reforms and helps in the restoration of the ugly and evil-infested Canal de la Reina to its original beauty for people to enjoy.

Canal de la Reina may be viewed as a microcosm of Philippine society ravaged and ruled by people like the pre-flood Nyora Tentay, which only radical processes can change. The novel is a good example both of Arceo’s craft and her widened social perspective. She is able to construct a world where the poor become the narrative’s focus, and where crucial issues of the time, such as corruption, cruelty, poverty, and activism, constitute the essential aspects of the narrative. Canal de la Reina manifested a new level of social awareness, and brought itself in tune with the dominant literary movement of the 1970s—the writing of socially engaged works exposing and protesting the many ills plaguing the country.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

text:
Published 2010. Author, Nick Joaquin. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Originally published as a short story in Philippines Free Press, 11 Dec 1965, and included in Tropical Gothic, 1972.

This novella is a coming-of-age story with the classic techniques the author Nick Joaquin is known for. The stream of consciousness allows the reader to inhabit the sometimes chaotic thoughts of the characters. There are gothic elements, such as the main character’s ability to literally see through the people around him. Most important of all, the story presents several themes at the same time, allowing a reader to see the layers of meaning in what simply starts as a story of a stowaway.

Bobby, the main character, becomes Candido, who seems to have the gift of true sight. Suddenly, Bobby, or Candido, has X-ray vision, literally seeing everybody’s nakedness. This condition sends him careening through the streets of Manila as he tries to find people whom he can still see as they usually are. Bobby realizes that he cannot handle the naked truth no matter how much he tries to act true to himself. Next, he sees people only as skeletons. Unlike the panic induced by his previous visions, this one triggers in him a profound sadness.

The author Joaquin deftly weaves into this story the consequences of being confronted with the truth about the people around us. It is in human nature to deceive, but humans also have a propensity to seek the truth. “Overacting,” as Bobby calls people’s acts of self-deception or cover-ups, is necessary in keeping human society intact. Humans are merely machines—skeletons, useful and reliable—but ultimately, soulless.

One of the best scenes in the story takes place when Bobby returns home and his Tita Menchu goes to his room to check up on him. In Bobby’s new vision, he sees only her skeleton, and, as she tarries, Bobby comes to realize that this is not the world that he wants. Everyone is “overacting” to cover up their secrets. Suddenly, he longs only for sincerity and authenticity, none of middle-class hypocrisy and self-righteousness. In a feverish state, he sees something else beyond the skeleton—something that might even be God.

For Bobby, though, the bedrock of his sanity lies in his grandmother and her house. This is another one of Joaquin’s underlying themes: the past is our anchor; it keeps our lives from floating aimlessly in the concrete jungles of rapid urbanization and technological advancements. In the end, Bobby returns to his old self, refusing the continued presence of Candido. But the reader detects that a profound change has been effected in Bobby. His adolescent anger and rebelliousness vanish; he has transformed into an adult.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Canticles for Three Women: The La Merced Cycle
text:
Published 2012. Author, Rony V. Diaz. Manila: Manila Times Publishing Corporation.

This is a trilogy of novellas, published individually between 2010 and 2012, and then published as a novel. It centers on three women from Hacienda La Merced, and the problems of feudalism, oligarchy, and power in post-World War II Philippines.

At War’s End deals with the struggles of Clare Montt, the last of the Montts of La Merced. She is trying to find her brother’s killer and preserve the peace in the hacienda as landlords and peasant movements battle for land in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The Adventures of Candida follows grade-school principal Candida San Pedro as she navigates through the straits of the Japanese occupation, her family’s brutal murder, and the same landlord-tenant conflicts. The final part, Quita y Pone, focuses on the adopted Pacita Montt, as she moves from the gossip columns of Manila to the inner sanctums of the Marcos dictatorship and the Central Intelligence Agency.

Unlike much of Philippine literature in English, Canticles for Three Women directly tackles the mechanisms by which feudalism and oligarchy maintain the status quo. The novel identifies power as the root problem of the complex system of relationships between landlords and their inquilinos (tenants), and inquilinos and their tenants. They are all trying to gain or maintain power. Protagonists and antagonists alike, all of whom are from or become part of the elite, use their connections and resources to manipulate everybody else into working, and killing, for their causes. The novel also subjects to criticism the Hukbalahap and messianic peasant movements, the former for being ideologically misled; the latter, according to the novel’s protagonists, for being naive.

Structure and style contribute much to the success of the novel. The novellas are set in two of the most violent and repressive—thus, critical and representative—periods of postwar Philippines: the war with the Hukbalahap and the Marcos dictatorship. In style, Diaz writes with extreme spareness, so that dialogue, description, and exposition are cut to the minimum necessary to push the plot forward. This style allows readers the distance from which to critique the motives and actions of the characters—protagonists and antagonists alike.

However, this attempt at objectivity does not always hold. The novel subjects the elite to a holistic critique, showing them as individuals in willful conflict with a political system, whereas the non-elites are shown to be prone to the manipulation of leaders of the movements that represent them, such as the Hukbalahap’s Communist intelligentsia and the insane leader of the messianic movement. It is in its characterization of the three female protagonists that the novel succeeds greatly. These are strong, rounded, and determined women, who kill, cheat, and manipulate when necessary to achieve their goals. At the same time, they get giddy over love, like Clare, or frequent—and contribute to—the gossip columns, like Pacita.

Despite some imbalance in its depiction of social classes, Canticles for Three Women highlights the complexity of the issue of power in Philippine society and offers a much-needed critique of it while it tells an exciting story.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
(Fate). Published 1923. Author, Zoilo Galang. Ing Capalaran, volume 1; Ing Galal ning Bie (Life’s Reward), volume 2. Manila: Dizon Cia. Filipino translation, Ang Kapalaran: Isang Nobelang Kapampangan (Fate: A Kapampangan Novel) by Lourdes H. Vidal, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1991.

The novel is about two faithful lovers removing numerous impediments before reaching their happy ending. Conrado of San Fernando meets Luzing of Angeles during a picnic in Porac. He overcomes Luzing’s modesty by patiently courting her for two years. Her mother favors two other suitors: the fishpond owner, Cirilo of Guagua, and their townmate, the wily Leopoldo. The elopement plan of the unfortunate lovers is discovered by Leopoldo. With the consent of the mother, he stops the elopement by shooting Conrado. He sues Conrado for robbery after finding Luzing’s clothes and jewels in the latter’s possession. Leopoldo bribes the justice of the peace, so that Conrado is found guilty. On appeal, the Supreme Court reverses the decision. Leopoldo is found guilty of illegal possession of firearms. Before the police can capture him, he is found floating in the river in Porac. Conrado hears that Luzing is seriously ill, and he visits her in the night. Seeing her daughter’s sudden recovery and desire to live, the mother accepts Conrado as her son-in-law.

The novel follows the conventions of many literary works in the local languages: a sentimental love plot, ordinary characters, recognizable places, nature details for emotional intensity, didacticism, a plot complicated by coincidences, and suspense before the resolution of conflicts. Ing Capalaran is unlike other Kapampangan novels in its use of Spanish and English words and sayings, Tagalog idioms, and humorous characters and incidents.  Written by Lourdes H. Vidal

text:
Published 1921. Author, Zoilo Galang. Manila: By the author. Reprinted, Manila: Philippine Education Company, 1924; Manila: Bardavon Book Co., 1952; Manila: Abiva Publishing House, 1955. Filipino translation, Ang Anak ng Dalita by the author, Manila: Abiva Publishing House, 1960.

This first Philippine novel in English is a love story with a sad ending. Lucio, a young student from Fertile Valley, spends his summer vacation in Merry Town at the invitation of his friend Camilo. Here he meets and falls in love with Rosa. Their love affair does not run smoothly because of various obstacles. Lucio’s father urges his son to finish his studies so that he (Lucio) may take care of him in his old age. Rosa’s mother favors Lucio’s rival Oscar, who is the hatchet man of the corrupt Governor Ismael. Rosa also has a shadowy past. She is rumored to be the illegitimate daughter of the governor who favors his protégé Oscar. Rumors about the forthcoming marriage of Rosa to Oscar reach Lucio. He decides to give Rosa the freedom to obey her mother. One dark night, the governor, accompanied by Oscar, tries to persuade Rosa’s mother to force her daughter to marry the man she does not love. While the governor and the mother are talking a few meters away from the house, Oscar seizes the opportunity to rape the sleeping Rosa. The girl has to marry him. However, Rosa loses the will to live. She languishes and dies in sorrow. The faithful Lucio watches over the tomb of his love in grief.

This novel uses the conventions of the narratives in the romantic tradition. Its omniscient point of view is used to establish not the objectivity of a detached narrator but the authority of the writer in talking familiarly with his readers. It uses familiar characters in recognizable settings.

The author also wrote popular novels in Kapampangan. This may explain why A Child of Sorrow, although in English, reads like Kapampangan prose with its connotative repetition of key words and its poetic use of nature images. It is also strongly didactic. In many places, the moralizing impulse is direct. Moral sayings and an essay, “If Rizal Were Alive Today,” are interspersed in the novel, as are moral tales and sermons.  Written by Lourdes H. Vidal

 

Source

Galdon, Joseph, SJ, ed. 1979. Essays on the Philippine Novel in English. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
(The Seeds of Lightning). Published 1995. Author, Clesencio Rambaud. Serialized in Bannawag, 4 Sep–5 Dec 1995.

The novel follows Piling and her family, who live in the small barrio of Puritac in San Isidro, Ilocos Norte. When the novel opens, a military detachment is established in the nearby barrio of Nagtrigoan, ostensibly to counter the worsening insurgency in the province and the region. Clashes between the military and the New People’s Army (NPA) intensify, but Piling’s family stays on, upon the insistence of her husband Fredo.

When the detachment is undermanned because of a birthday party and is attacked, Fredo is framed by soldiers. They suspect that it was he, a sympathizer, who had tipped off the rebels, and killed Fredo. The detachment commander Sergeant Magarro, who investigates the matter, convinces the people that it was the NPA who murdered Fredo. Meanwhile, Piling is raped and their son barely escapes death in the hands of the military.

The new police chief Moises Coloma stages an ambush that sends the inutile town mayor fleeing to Manila and the provincial command setting up another detachment in San Isidro. This sets the stage for a final and decisive clash between the two camps. The NPA, led by Napintas, offers to avenge Fredo’s death. Piling accepts the offer. When the soldiers uncover the planned rebel offensive, the residents are evacuated, including an excited Piling and her family. The anticipated clash happens, however, when the residents have just returned to their homes. In her yard, Piling is recounting the plight of her family to Napintas when she and her eldest daughter Bising (Visayas) are shot and killed. The bloodstain on her back, where she was shot, resembles “a map of seven thousand islands.”

The rebels flee with the rest of Piling’s children—Bitti, Lucing (Luzon), and Minda (Mindanao)—who are taken to the church in accordance with their mother’s wishes. Bitti tells Father Amador that it was the soldiers who killed his father. He stays in the church during the investigation, while Lucing and Minda are adopted by Moises Coloma.

The novel might be read as an enactment of and commentary on the post-EDSA role of the military in state affairs. It writes the history of how the military worked its way back to power under and beyond the administration of Corazon Aquino, following its brief subordination to civilian authority when she assumed the presidency in 1986. But the turn of events in the novel—in particular, the emergence of a new benevolent military figure and the growing civilian alliance with the Church—points to the author’s own vision of the future.

Militarization frames the allegorical construction of the nation in Dagiti Bin-i ti Kimat. Piling’s family is caught between the armed combatants, represented by the troops of Sergeant Magarro and of Napintas. Midway through the novel, a third alternative is presented, with Moises Coloma as the embodiment of supposedly a benevolent military-state complex. In the narrative’s unfolding, this option is chosen by the succeeding generation, represented by Piling’s children who are adopted by Coloma. Father Amador’s adoption of Bitti, Piling’s eldest, may be seen as the alliance between the Church and the state, supplanting Piling’s alliance with the rebels.  Written by Roderick Galam

text:
(They Who Awaken at Dawn). Published 1956-57. Author, Constante C. Casabar. Serialized in Bannawag, 24 Sep 1956–11 Mar 1957.

The novel, within the framework of a love story, is a social commentary on Ilocano politics set against the backdrop of crime-ridden Ilocos in the mid-1950s. The hero, Salvador, is a poor fisher orphaned at an early age. He dreams of becoming a professional someday. He graduates with honors, but all his youthful dreams are shattered when his grandfather, Apo Binoy, sets out to sea one stormy night to fish, only to be washed ashore because his banca capsizes and he loses one of his legs to the sharks. The old man is hospitalized, and Salvador and his mother are forced to approach another “shark,” fiercer and more ruthless, the usurer Apo Julian Manoto, who loans them the money they need on condition that Salvador will work in the textile factory being put up by the government in the town.

Salvador is loved by Emerita Buligo, the muse of their class. However, after graduation, Salvador tries to suppress his feelings because he knows it is impossible for him to offer Emerita a bright future. One day, Emerita and two other friends decide to have a picnic at Sabangan, Salvador’s barrio by the sea. Salvador and Emerita spend the night together under the moonlight. Emerita goes to the big city to study. Meanwhile, Salvador is forced to work at the textile factory in order to be able to pay his now bloated loan from Julian Manoto. Soon, Salvador and the other workers form a union to counter the oppression of the management, which is in league with the local warlords and politicians.

Meanwhile, Emerita discovers that she is pregnant. She decides to return to the province, only to be disowned by her parents. Salvador marries her. The secret existence of a workers’ union is discovered. The members of the union now decide not to pay back their loans to the town’s loan sharks. This incurs the wrath of the local gentry, and Manoto asks Julian Buligo, Emerita’s brother and a cold-blooded killer protected by the police, to kill Salvador. Armed with a carbine, Julian decides to waylay Salvador one night. However, it is Emerita, heavy with child, who gets hit instead. With the pleadings of the wounded Emerita, Julian Buligo returns to his senses. He kills Julian Manoto and surrenders himself to the police. Emerita survives her wound. Her parents forgive her. In the end, Emerita and Salvador plan to migrate to Cagayan Valley to live in peace.

Although the novel is cloaked in romance, it is actually an attack on ruthless usurers, greedy politicians, and undisciplined military authorities. While Casabar recognizes the fact that industrialization is one key to progress, he also points out the evils of progress, which may reduce persons to mere tools of capitalists in attaining more power.   Written by Reynaldo Duque

text:
(Tidal Wave). Published 1962-63. Author, Lazaro Francisco. Serialized in Liwayway, 19 Sep 1962–11 Apr 1963.

This novel is a sequel to Maganda Pa ang Daigdig (The World Be Lovely Still). Where the earlier novel affirms nonviolence, this sequel posits that unless radical changes are made, blood will have to be shed to rid society of violence and injustice. At the novel’s beginning, Lino now owns the five hectares which used to be owned by Father Armando. The personal struggle for justice is over because Lino’s innocence has been proven. He has found in Diding a woman he would like to make his wife. The land is rich and he finds himself content tilling the soil together with his friend Bitong. Still, Lino realizes how much his unarticulated love for Miss Sanchez, because of their great class difference, has caused him much pain. Loving Lino, Miss Sanchez is aware of his agony, but she can do nothing.

The personal strand is intermeshed with the more public life of Lino as role model for the oppressed farmers. The enemy is seen in Don Tito, a rich plantation owner with a private army, and his son Benog, American educated, who wants to run for governor. Benog offers Lino a job as his bodyguard, but Lino declines and instead asks Bitong to take his place for Bitong’s own protection. As the campaign heats up, Lino sees how dangerously violent Don Tito and his son could be, and how they justify this violence. They are willing to kill to seize power. Lino’s house is burned down, and Bitong is murdered. In the ensuing struggle, Lino kills several men, including Bitong’s murderer. Benog is roundly trounced in the elections. Lino loses both Didang who decides to leave him, and Miss Sanchez who dies literally of a broken heart.

Francisco’s last novel demonstrates his deep commitment to the awakening of the people’s consciousness to the evils of the tenancy system and his belief that it is the duty of righteous people to confront this system and strive to change even only a part of it. This is the only way to stave off the impending disaster of the “daluyong” about to engulf the world. This position is fleshed out in a tightly knit plot, credible individualized characters, and a language that remains unsurpassed for its vigor and vitality.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Daylinda: The Unfortunate). Published 1947. Author, Amando Osorio. Serialized in Bisaya, 1947.

Written at a time when Westernization was beginning to make inroads into provincial life, this historical romance attempts to recreate Cebu on the eve of Spanish contact. The novel recounts the love between Daylinda, the lovely and virtuous daughter of Sumatrans who have come to settle in Dalaguete, and Omanad, the brave son of recently arrived migrants from Sumatra. Their love ends sadly when, receiving news of Magellan’s arrival, Omanad goes to Sugbo to help fight the invaders. Fighting with Lapu-Lapu’s men, Omanad successfully drives the foreigners away, but he is wounded. Brought back to Dalaguete, he marries Daylinda but dies shortly. Daylinda herself dies of grief.

The novel is noted for being one of the earliest Cebuano novels to attempt at political fiction, as seen in Osorio’s portrayal of the motives of the native resistance as well as his mixed bag of epigraphs. History, however, is subsumed under romance. Osorio appends explanatory footnotes and frequently interposes old verses and songs, details of customs in courtship and marriage, and others. All these embellish a work well within the romantic mode: idealism that animates the protagonists, the treatment of love, history, and traditional customs. There is consequently a gloss, a violation of historical events and of pre-Spanish society as it was. However, its conscious cultivation of aesthetic values and seriousness of purpose make it one of the more developed novels of its period.  Written by Resil Mojares

text:
(The 1970s). Published 1983. Author, Lualhati Bautista. Manila: Jingle Publications. Reprinted, including chapters omitted from the first edition, Manila: Carmelo and Bauermann, 1988. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1983.

This novel revolves around Amanda and her relationship with her husband and their five sons. The relative calm of this middle-class family is gradually shattered as her sons grow up to immerse themselves in experiences that go beyond family life. Amanda is not a passive, suffering mother as traditionally portrayed in Filipino novels. She engages the menfolk in lively, passionate discussions of relevant social issues. In the process, she finds herself slowly leaving behind a world where social and political issues are perceived as alien concerns, and where knowledge is limited to the practical and the commonsensical.

A son’s early marriage and eventual departure for the United States reveal his uncritical acceptance of the myth of the great American dream. But where Isagani abandons his country, two other sons choose to stay and become politically involved. Jules becomes a dissident. He is captured, allowed to go free, rejoins his comrades, and eventually dies at the hands of the military. Em continues the struggle by joining a human rights group.

The education of Amanda is almost complete. The novel ends in 1982, the year martial law is “lifted” farcically by the dictator. Amanda realizes that many structures of repression are still in place. After weathering a number of crises which would have destroyed a person of weaker resolve, Amanda finds herself more committed than ever to liberating herself as a woman and as a human being, in the most tumultuous decade of her life.

Readers saw in Bautista’s novel one of the earliest articulations of feminism in contemporary Philippine literature. Older novelists like Liwayway Arceo and Rosario de Guzman-Lingat had used female characters to question the unequal relations between men and women, but it was not until Bautista’s Dekada ’70—and her subsequent works—that a sustained inquiry into woman’s condition was made and contextualized within the social and ideological issues of the times. The novel is considered principally a woman’s text not only because it is about a woman as perceived by a woman, but principally because it analyzes the complex structures in which a woman is formed as a subject in the patriarchal system.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Reyes, Soledad. 1978. “The Individual and Society in the Novels of Dominador Mirasol.” Diliman Review 26 (Oct-Dec): 49-53.

text:
Published 1996. Author, Renato Madrid. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Devil Wings is a crime novel with religious overtones. It centers on the demise of three men and the events that led to it. The novel begins in the city of Manila, in the residence of the papal nuncio, an old man who tends his bonsai collection and enjoys the company of cats. He refuses to comment on the slaughter of two priests and a close friend of theirs in a remote region of the Visayas. These three men are Padre Deuteronomio Diaz, a conservative, self-righteous, senior clergyman; Dr Macaraeg, a doctor who wants answers concerning his son’s death; and La Crava, a younger, more unconventional man of the cloth, who once took pride in being a student activist and was acquainted with the doctor’s son.

Joe, the doctor’s son, supposedly committed suicide. The circumstances are mysterious, and there are rumors that he was a member of Land of the Morning, a patriotic cult with an obsession for papaya. Joe’s death affects Diaz as much as it does Dr Macaraeg, because the old priest had expected Joe to enter the seminary, following an agreement between him and the doctor. Diaz advises Dr Macaraeg to have Joe’s body buried in the public cemetery because the interment of suicides at the Catholic cemetery is forbidden. As the body is being transported, however, it goes missing.

The three men investigate the mystery only to end up being drugged and taken to a den run by a mad ex-priest named Faustino, who makes a reverse sign of the cross. On the altar of this mock chapel is an offering, a corpse. The section ends with Diaz slipping into unconsciousness as the sound of chanting voices fade away.

The novel returns to the nuncio in Manila. After he entertains guests at a charity function, he is presented by a nun’s old uncle with a bonsai plant with a trunk shaped like a woman’s thighs. The nuncio is even more surprised when he realizes that the little plant is a papaya.

A major theme of the novel is the conflict between nationalism and religiosity. Can the people of the Philippines find balance between these sentiments? The three priests in the novel may represent the extremes and the middle ground: Diaz, the conservative right; Faustino, the extremely secular left; and La Crava in between, a socially active yet spiritually grounded clergyman. The Macaraegs and Joe’s love interest, Marita, represent the individuals caught in the cross fire.

Like good crime novels, Devil Wings is an introspective piece, delving into the thoughts and personal histories of the characters while slowly advancing the plot. At the same time, it reads as a social commentary. Symbolism, irony, and allegory are interwoven with intrigue to make Madrid’s novel a true amalgam of literary, social, and religious elements.  Written by Charles Dominic Sanchez

text:
Published 1990. Author, Jessica Hagedorn. New York: Pantheon Press.

This novel by an expatriate writer is often described as postmodern for its fragmented and montage-like structure.

Rio Gonzaga is the first of the novel’s two narrators. An immigrant to the United States, Rio recounts her life as a young woman who belongs to an upper middle-class family in Manila during the 1950s and 1960s. The second narrator is Joey Sands, a street-smart disc jockey, prostitute, and heroin addict who works the clubs of Ermita. Joey, the offspring of a Filipino female prostitute and a black American serviceman, hopes to “hit the jackpot” one day and be sent for by one of his foreign lovers.

Woven into Rio’s and Joey’s narrations are the stories of, among others, Romeo Rosales, an aspiring actor; his girlfriend Trinidad Gamboa, a ticket seller at the Odeon Theater; Daisy Avila, beauty queen; her father Senator Domingo Avila, foremost critic of the president and the administration; Lolita Luna, Manila’s most popular bold star; Gen Nicasio Ledesma, Lolita’s lover, the sadistic head of Camp Dilidili; and Severo Alacran, head of the richest family in the country.

The novel unfolds with the assassination of Senator Avila, Joey Sands witnesses the assassination, and realizing that his life is now in danger, finds safety among the rebels in the hills. Romeo gets killed in the violence that erupts immediately after the assassination. Daisy Avila who previously renounced her crown and ran off with rebel leader Santos Tirador, gets picked up, tortured, and questioned. The novel ends with a letter from Rio’s cousin, Pucha, which admonishes Rio for getting the facts, names, and dates in her narrative all wrong.

Hagedorn intersperses the narrative with fictitious newspaper and magazine clippings, radio drama scripts, movie fantasies, gossip, dramas, and letters, as well as actual texts, such as McKinley’s now infamous 1898 presidential address, and quotations from Jean Mallat. She mixes English, Tagalog, Spanish, “Taglish,” gay lingo, and slang. She also uses a variety of typefaces.

The novel achieved a certain degree of popularity in the United States. It was featured on the cover of the 25 Mar 1990 issue of the New York Times Book Review, at the time when Imelda Marcos was on trial in New York. In the Philippines, critics censured it for its negative depiction of Filipinos and women, but praised it for its inquiry into the problem of the arbitrariness of truth.  Written by Maria Teresa Pineda

text:
(Blood at Daybreak). Published 1965-66. Author Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat. Serialized in Liwayway, 6 Sep 1965–14 Feb 1966. Reprinted as a book, with an introduction by Virgilio S. Almario, Quezon City: University of the Philippine Press, 1989.

This novel won for the author second prize in the contest sponsored by Liwayway magazine in 1964. Published in serial form the following year, the novel has been acclaimed as one of the most significant works in contemporary Tagalog literature. Taking off from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion) and its theme of the returning native who seeks justice, the novel is a fine example of Sikat’s literary style, particularly his skill in constructing a fictive world with much intensity, passion, and realism.

Tano is a farmer whose fate is unhappily intertwined with that of the rich Borjas who are responsible for the death of his wife and the loss of his land after a long but futile struggle. The only bright spot in his life is his son, Simon, who grows up keenly aware of how in life, and even in death, his father has been the victim of the rich landlord’s cruelty. Simon leaves San Roque after realizing the futility of eking out a living under such feudal conditions. He comes back after 16 years, a man of wealth. He builds an agricultural school to help the farmers and gains the respect of the people. He forces Borja out of the business, exacting partial revenge on both the patriarch and his son Andro, who has married Elena, Simon’s love before he left. Simon also supports the poor but honest Ador, an old friend and a teacher who decides to wage political battle against the powerful clique headed by the Borjas. While speaking on the platform in the town plaza, Simon is assassinated by Andro. The novel ends with the outraged farmers of San Roque holding up their flaming torches as they mass in the plaza, awaiting the breaking of dawn. The dead Simon has become a symbol of their struggle and of their dreams, a man who came back to redeem them from their oppressors.

The various options toward liberation, in such a violence-wracked peasant society, are presented through the characters of the novel who differ in temper and approach. Duardo, Simon’s “milk brother,” so called because they both sucked from the breasts of Duardo’s mother when they were infants, sees in armed struggle the only way out for the downtrodden. Ador becomes a teacher, believing that education would light up the way out of their plight. Simon comes back with a newfound economic power and a developmentalist scheme: to build a school and create a new breed of self-reliant farmers. Simon’s death appears to negate even this enlightened approach, but the fact that he turns into a rallying symbol for the masses now fully conscious of the landed gentry’s treachery makes the ending of the novel anything but defeatist.

The significance of Sikat’s novel lies not only in its realistic characterization of its protagonists and handling of conflict and resolution in the narrative, but also in its creative presentation of the age-old problems of tenancy and feudalism in Philippine agrarian society.   Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

text:
(Blood in Harvest Time). Published 2012. Author, Ric Patalinjug. Serialized in Bisaya, 7 Jun–10 Oct 2012.

Set in a town called Amaris in Cebu, sometime probably in the late 1950s, the novel begins with the death of Anastacio, the right-hand man of Nyor Lucio, the landlord feared by the people in Amaris. Anastacio’s death haunts succeeding events, all of which occur before the time of harvest.

The people of Amaris try to live peacefully despite the presence of American soldiers who have occupied the town after World War II, the crackdown on guerrilla fighters, and the tyranny of a feudal lord.

Miguel, the novel’s protagonist, harbors a painful past. A melancholic young man, he lives with his wife, who is pregnant with their first child. They work hard for their growing family, dreaming of a better life. Details of Miguel’s past are then revealed: he is the son of Maestro Anoy, whom the military branded as the infamous guerrilla fighter Kumander Sundang.

Maestro Anoy was the town teacher who gave lessons under the shade of a tree, the same tree from which he would be hanged. Then a young boy, Miguel witnessed his father’s execution.

Miguel’s grandfather is Tata Abraham, a talented sculptor, jar-maker, and shaman who hunted wild black roosters and offered their blood before to the spirits before each harvest. Miguel inherits a valuable jar carved by Tata Abraham, an item that Nyor Lucio’s wife yearns to possess.

Throughout the novel, Patalinjug provides highly detailed descriptions of rural folk livelihood: fishermen dive into coral reefs; bamboo cutters build rafts to navigate mangroves and creeks and gather materials for carpentry; traders sell wares in a makeshift marketplace once a month.

The death of Anastacio brings the constable and Nyor Lucio’s henchman Nicolas to Armanis. The novel reaches its climax in a festival, during which dancers dressed as hunters pursue a beautiful maiden dressed like a yellow bird. The festival ends with an arnis (Filipino martial art) combat between Gabriel, a stranger who takes great interest in Miguel, and Nicolas. When the fight turns ugly, Miguel tries to defend Gabriel. Miguel is stabbed, and he realizes that he is destined to be the year’s harvest offering, his blood to stain the famished earth. The mantra he has inherited from Tata Abraham is “Dugo lang ang makaabog kanila!” (Only blood can keep them away!). Miguel embodies the heroic struggle for life in a time of tyranny and colonization.

In this narrative about the various ways in which the past disrupts the present, Patalinjug has produced a Cebuano novel epic in scope and ambition.  Written by Jeffrey Javier

text:
Published 2000. Author, Charlson Ong. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Centennial Literary Prize, second prize for the novel in English, 1998.

Set in the imaginary island-nation called Victorianas, the novel is a picture of a nation struggling to stay together as a nation. When the novel opens, the dictator is dead. Various forces vie to fill up the power vacuum. Gen Artemio Azurin declares himself “President for Life.” Jennifer Sy, daughter of the richest man on the island, decides to run for the presidency. Her friend, Jeffrey Tantivo, the main protagonist and narrator, returns to Victorianas to help her run. His own sister, however, is a leader of the insurgency.

Tantivo’s real mission for returning is to identify the killers of his father. As almost every major character in the novel becomes a suspect, he goes through a roller-coaster of disappointment and discovery. One of the suspects has transformed himself from a businessman to a charismatic religious leader. In the end, Tantivo discovers who his real father is.

As the plot thickens, we meet other characters, most of them shady or corrupt: a sex-starved and money grubber priest who becomes a cardinal; a military colonel who leads a coup against his half-sister; a drug addict under the control of one of the old family friends of the Tantivos. The intricate and vast network of connections and blood relations among the characters suggests that there is nothing simple in the entanglements that threaten to choke the country. Many of those who seem to have good intentions, like Jennifer Sy and Tantivo, find themselves in exile, leaving the country in the hands of criminals, fanatics, and opportunists.

Ong seems to be channeling Jose Rizal, with Jeffrey Tantivo, returning to Victorianas, as an incarnation of Ibarra. A failed assassination plot that could wipe out some of Victorianas’ scum recalls a scene from El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. The ending of Ong’s novel also parallels that of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1952, where Bitoy Camacho pledges “to remember and to sing” of the past. Here Tantivo, a writer, pledges to live “for all of my people who drift in a sea of uncertainty. I live for all who keep vigil in the night of the world awaiting a certain daybreak.”  Written by Robert Kwan Laurel
