text:
(Outsider). Published 2000. Author, Jun Cruz Reyes. Quezon City: Philippine Centennial Commission and University of the Philippines Press. Centennial Literary Prize, first prize co-winner for the novel in Filipino, 1998.

The novel follows the lives of “the race of Lola Sion” across different periods of Philippine history. Their stories constitute a complex mosaic that throws light on the nation’s history from the pre-Spanish until the contemporary period.

The narrative begins when Carrayyo, a hunter in the Cordillera mountains, chances upon a lovely maiden, Osyang, whom he later marries. Osyang turns out to be a deer transformed into a human being because Kabunian, the supreme god, took pity on the young hunter who desperately wanted a wife. The novel proceeds to chronicle events that straddle two worlds—fantasy and history.

Into a strife-torn community comes Fr Francisco de San Esteban, a white missionary sent to the Cordilleras. Thus begins the Spanish colonization. Osyang’s daughter, also named Osyang, lives through the initial phase of the Spanish colonial regime, when the Church is gaining converts. Given up for adoption, the young Osyang becomes the friar’s mistress and is now known as Rosa.

At 14, Rosa marries Teban, an irresponsible young man who joins the revolution against Spain, sees the famed beauty of Jocelyna of Baliwag, turns collaborator during the American period, and takes a position in Malacañan as a reward. Rosa’s streak of ill luck with men continues when she becomes the kept woman of a rich Chinese businessman, Paulino Tan-Yun, friend and supporter of the leaders of two colonial regimes, the Spanish and the American. Sion is the product of this liaison. The final man in Rosa’s life is Papa Dune, an ordinary farmer turned leader of a movement and religious cult called Ang Bagong Jerusalem. With his band of armed men, he wages a desperate war against the Spanish forces. He is eventually caught and beheaded.

At the height of the insurgency movement against the Americans, Rosa loses her son but he comes back with a strange name, Jhonny Graham-White, and with a stranger story. He was saved by an American who took him to their camp where he was interrogated. Fearing that he might betray his father, he willed never to speak again.

Jhonny Graham-White reclaims his original name, Ando. Sion and Ando live together in the mansion built from the chest of gold and silver coins that Papa Dune left behind. This is the source of the family’s wealth. Ando cultivates his interest in music and founds his own orchestra.

In World War II, all of Sion’s children perish; she wages a one-woman guerrilla war and ambushes Japanese soldiers. Ando uses his radio transmitter to help relay messages to the Allied forces.

Embong, the narrator, is the son of Ruben, the product of the marriage between Ando and Dolores, a 17-year-old woman saved from the Japanese. Like his ancestors, Ruben leads a colorful life. A bright student, he turns to activism and is mysteriously killed. Sion follows soon after. As the novel ends, Embong asks: And what do you think should we do now?

The novel has a sweeping and grand vision, covering key historical moments. Reyes’s approach, however, is not straightforward realism that such a scope would usually call for. Thus, the serious combines with the whimsical, the realistic with the improbable, overt didacticism with ironic humor, the detachment of a fairy tale or legend with the intrusive tone of a novel by Lope K. Santos or Fausto Aguilar.

What makes this novel different is the writer’s attempt not only to offer a more arresting and imaginative way of re-constructing the nation’s history but also to problematize the ways in which such terms as “history,” “writing,” “truth,” “representation,” and “reality” have been viewed. The novel is self-referential, constantly pointing to its own status as “writing.” This self-conscious process makes for an unsettling work where the indeterminate nature of events and characters is highlighted. Like the outsider family that it depicts, Etsa-Puwera is itself a text that stands on the outside, as one of the few exceptions to the mode of realism that has dominated Philippine literature. Its creative retrieval of modes and materials from the oral tradition and from the variegated images in the collective psyche pushes the boundaries of the Philippine novel in the 21st century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

Jhonny Graham-White reclaims his original name, Ando. Sion and Ando live together in the mansion built from the chest of gold and silver coins that Papa Dune left behind. This is the source of the family’s wealth. Ando cultivates his interest in music and founds his own orchestra.
In World War II, all of Sion’s children perish; she wages a one-woman guerrilla war and ambushes Japanese soldiers. Ando uses his radio transmitter to help relay messages to the Allied forces.

Embong, the narrator, is the son of Ruben, the product of the marriage between Ando and Dolores, a 17-year-old woman saved from the Japanese. Like his ancestors, Ruben leads a colorful life. A bright student, he turns to activism and is mysteriously killed. Sion follows soon after. As the novel ends, Embong asks: And what do you think should we do now?

The novel has a sweeping and grand vision, covering key historical moments. Reyes’s approach, however, is not straightforward realism that such a scope would usually call for. Thus, the serious combines with the whimsical, the realistic with the improbable, overt didacticism with ironic humor, the detachment of a fairy tale or legend with the intrusive tone of a novel by Lope K. Santos or Fausto Aguilar.

What makes this novel different is the writer’s attempt not only to offer a more arresting and imaginative way of re-constructing the nation’s history but also to problematize the ways in which such terms as “history,” “writing,” “truth,” “representation,” and “reality” have been viewed. The novel is self-referential, constantly pointing to its own status as “writing.” This self-conscious process makes for an unsettling work where the indeterminate nature of events and characters is highlighted. Like the outsider family that it depicts, Etsa-Puwera is itself a text that stands on the outside, as one of the few exceptions to the mode of realism that has dominated Philippine literature. Its creative retrieval of modes and materials from the oral tradition and from the variegated images in the collective psyche pushes the boundaries of the Philippine novel in the 21st century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

(Subversion). Published 1891. Author, Jose Rizal. Ghent: F. Meyer-Van Loo Press. Serialized in Madrid, El Nuevo Regimen, 1891. English translations, Reign of Greed by Charles Derbyshire, Manila: Philippine Education Company, 1912; El Filibusterismo by Leon Ma. Guerrero, New York: W.W. Norton, 1962; The Revolution by Jovita Ventura Castro, Quezon City: ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, 1991. Other English translations by Camilio Osias and Priscilla G. Valencia. Tagalog translation, Ang “Filibusterismo” by Patricio Mariano, Quezon City: Roberto Martinez and Sons, 1958; Ang Pagsusuwail by Rosendo Ignacio, Rizal: ESC Press, 1958. Another Tagalog translation was done by Pedro Gatmaitan. Also translated into German, French, Japanese, and other local and foreign languages.

Meant to be a sequel to Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, the novel was written during Rizal’s second trip to Europe. Many of the characters from the Noli reappear, such as Doña Victorina, the caricature of colonial mentality; and Basilio, the son of the deranged Sisa. However, Rizal introduces a host of new characters: Ben Zayb, a Spanish journalist; Quiroga, a Chinese merchant; Placido Penitente, a disillusioned student; and Señor Pasta, a typical bureaucrat.

After 13 years abroad, Crisostomo Ibarra returns to the Philippines disguised as Simoun, a rich jeweller, to avenge himself on those who caused his downfall in the Noli and to save Maria Clara from the nunnery. Using his wealth and his influence on the governor-general whose appointment he bought, he foments greed and corruption in official and upper circles, hoping to provoke a revolution. He buys arms from Quiroga and plots with Kabesang Tales to seize Manila. He destroys all hopes of reform in the status quo by framing the students fighting for a secular school. When his plans for a general overthrow of the government are about to be realized, he solicits the cooperation of Basilio to rescue Maria Clara. On the eve of the uprising, Basilio informs him that she has just died. Simoun is so shocked he fails to give the signal for the start of hostilities; he abandons his conspirators and leaves the uprising to utter failure, causing the death and arrest of many of his men. He falls ill for some time. Recovering from his illness, he plots anew. He again meets Basilio, whose release from jail he has paid for. This time the disgruntled Basilio is willing to join him. At the wedding of the couple Paulita Gomez and Juanito Pelaez, in which all the rulers and important people in Manila—including the villainous Padre Salvi—are invited, Simoun presents an elaborate lamp as his wedding gift, actually a bomb designed to explode the moment its wick is raised to revive the flame. The explosion is meant to herald another uprising. As the celebration starts, Basilio is watching the house from a distance. He is joined by Isagani, who is brokenhearted because his girlfriend Paulita is to be married to Juanito. Basilio tells Isagani to stay away from the house, informs him of the secret bomb, and moves away. Wishing to save Paulita, Isagani rushes up the house just in time to grab the fatal lamp and throw it into the river, with himself disappearing into the night. Thus is Simoun’s plot foiled a second time. Now hunted by the authorities, a wounded Simoun escapes once more with a load of his treasures. He takes refuge in the mountain retreat of a virtuous priest, Padre Florentino. Knowing that the guardias civiles (constables) have discovered his whereabouts, Simoun drinks poison. But before he dies, he engages Padre Florentino in a dramatic conversation on the fate of the Philippines. The priest absolves him and gives him a final admonition on the wickedness of greed and of violence as a means for social change. The novel ends with the priest throwing Simoun’s chest of treasures into the sea where it will do no harm, saying that these may be retrieved only when the time has come that it may be used for achieving good.

The many other episodes in the novel reconstruct the social milieu. The story of Kabesang Tales and his family shows how the cruelty of some Spanish authorities leads people to violence. Through hard work, Kabesang Tales developed rice lands which the friars grabbed. He becomes a bandit named Matanglawin. Juli, his daughter, borrows money to free his father from prison, but eventually falls prey to the lustful Padre Camorra. Unable to face her fiancé Basilio, Juli commits suicide. In Manila, the young students, led by Basilio, Makaraig, Sandoval, and Pecson, rebel against the state of education in the country, which seeks to blind rather than enlighten. They agitate for a school that will teach Spanish, but are set up and thrown in prison for “subversion.” Padre Millon, a physicist at the Colegio de Santo Tomas, teaches without conducting experiments.

The publication of this novel, like the publication of the Noli in 1887, caused a commotion. Many copies of the books, shipped in boxes to Hong Kong, were confiscated. Rizal was ultimately exiled to Dapitan for the Fili and his other writings which were interpreted as separatist. Rizal’s friends, however, reacted positively toward it. Ferdinand Blumentritt and Graciano Lopez Jaena thought it was better than the Noli. The Filipino community in Spain praised it in La Publicidad, a Spanish periodical, comparing it to the works of Alexandre Dumas.

Most of all, it opened the eyes of natives all over the Philippines to the corruption of the Spanish bureaucracy and the inevitability of change, which Rizal hoped would not be violent.

The lasting legacy of the novel is seen today in the many adaptations made from it. With the same title, El Filibusterismo was adapted into an opera by Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1970, and into film by Gerardo de Leon, 1962. Works imaginatively expanding on Rizal’s characters are plays like Jose Maria Rivera’s Si Ginoong Pasta (Mr Pasta), 1916; Paul Dumol’s Kabesang Tales (Cabeza Tales), 1974; Bonifacio Ilagan’s Himagsik (Revolt), 1989; Jomar Fleras’s Ang Filibustero (The Subversive), 1990; Jose Bernard Capino’s Ang Filibustero, 1991; Floy Quintos’s Fili, 1991; and Jovy Miroy and Ryan Cayabyab’s El Filibusterismo, 1991. Amado V. Hernandez’s Mga Ibong Mandaragit, 1959, continues the narrative, as Simoun’s treasures are discovered and are used to pursue social change.  Written by Ruby G. Alcantara

 

Sources

Mojares, Resil B. 1983. Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel: A Generic Study of the Novel until 1940. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Zaide, Gregorio F. 1970. Jose Rizal: Life, Works and Writings. Manila: Villanueva Book Store.

text:
Published 2003. Author, Erwin Castillo. With an afterword by Cesar Ruiz Aquino. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book may be read as two disparate novellas with settings, sensibilities, and even themes distinct from one another. The first novella, Firewalkers, begins as a murder investigation. The police sergeant, Gabriel Diego, is tasked to discover the murderer of his town’s children. Gabriel Diego finds himself trapped between the investigation and the demands made of him by the American occupational forces led by Major Edwards and the shattered but undefeated Filipino resistance movement, whose leaders are also his relatives. He thus becomes the man caught between two sides of a war, to either one of which he must bear some loyalty for different reasons. As he runs errands for the Americans, the reader is introduced to the sprawling and colorful cast of rogues and would-be heroes of the mythical Cavite town called Lakambaga. Gabriel Diego is powerless to stop the killing of his town’s children—a metaphor for the young being slaughtered by the constant war.

As the novella progresses, Gabriel Diego begins to see the contradictions between what the American soldiers claim to represent and what they actually are. In the end, Gabriel Diego embraces the legend of the Firewalkers, as he too clings to the hope that the old stories are true.

The second novella, The Watch of La Diane, is in the plotless, stream-of-consciousness mode, which displays the author’s use of language at its best. By the end of the narrative, the reader sees the story as a retelling of the history of struggle in the Philippines. The narrator is a vagabond, moored to the shores of the United States, bearing the pain, the sorrow, and the responsibility of what it means to be a man in constant search of the self. Taken as a whole, both novellas give the reader a glimpse into the Philippines’ mythologized past and a sense of being immersed in the uncertain future. The first novella is a structured narrative with folkloric embellishments. It is an attempt to reclaim Philippine history from colonizers, who have cast Philippine traditional heroes as villains or as losers. Gabriel Diego, too, passes into legend as he follows the trail of the mythical Firewalkers. What is human and inessential about him is burned away, and what remain are the ideals that he has stood for.

The Watch of La Diane, on the other hand, is very much like the future; much of it is uncertain and seemingly incomprehensible. Sometimes that future is to be found in some foreign country, but the lack of mooring keeps us lost at sea. Together, these two novellas convey that it is only when we embrace our heritage, our old stories, and the responsibility that comes with them that we can find and define ourselves.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: 'Gapo (at Isang Puting Pilipino, sa Mundo ng Mga Amerikanong Brown)
text:
(’Gapo [and a White Filipino, in a World of Brown Americans]). Published 1988. Author, Lualhati Bautista. Mandaluyong City: Carmelo and Bauerman. Reprinted, Mandaluyong City: Cacho Publishing House Inc, 1992. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1979-80.

’Gapo is the first grand-prize winner in the novel category at the Palanca Awards. The word “’Gapo” is an abbreviation for “Olongapo City.”

The novel is a montage of the lives of Olongapo’s residents when the American military bases there were still operational. The unifying thread is the coming-of-age story of Michael Taylor Jr, the son of an American soldier who abandoned him and his Filipino mother. He is euphemistically called a “G.I. baby.” Magdalena is Michael’s housemate, a prostitute who wants to live the American dream by marrying an American soldier. Modesto is a welder working inside the military base. Alipio is a gay man taking care of his Americanized Filipino nephew, Jeffrey.

Olongapo represents the political, militaristic, economic, and cultural domination of the United States of the Philippines. The many characters’ lives are intertwined with the military base, which provides business and jobs to Olongapo’s citizens. Reflective of racial prejudice, it is zoned: there are the Black Men’s Row, White Men’s Territory, and Brown Community.

The characters’ interconnected lives present a complicated picture of the issues related to the military bases. Although there are characters, like Magdalena, who fawn over the Americans, other characters, like Michael, bear the hurt wrought by the misdeeds of the Americans. Bautista thus balances different perspectives, and the novel becomes a heteroglossia, or a site of competing ideologies. Although the novel can be read as being against the continued presence of the American military bases in the Philippines, it is not unequivocally anti-American. Many American soldiers are domineering and obnoxious, but there is the exception of William Smith, a good-hearted American soldier who looks after the well-being of Filipinos like Modesto.

The novel uses colloquial language in portraying the underbelly of Olongapo and the lives of its denizens, and dramatizes the arguments against the continued presence of the American military bases. The personal tragedies of the characters are clearly situated within the unequal relations between the Philippines and the United States. Although the military bases in Olongapo are gone, the persistence of American presence in the Philippines through the Visiting Forces Agreement, and the military expeditions of the United States elsewhere in the world continue to make the novel relevant.  Written by Christopher Cerda

text:
(Land’s Flame). Published 1985-86. Author, Jose A. Bragado. Serialized in Bannawag, 1 Jul 1985–14 Apr 1986.

This novel follows a community of informal settlers in Manila in their crusade to stop a powerful businessman from seizing their land. The lives of the residents of Filipinas Street—mostly laborers and a few middle-class families—are upended when a businessman, Mr Lopez, asserts ownership of the land on which their houses have stood for decades. With his private army, Mr Lopez threatens the residents with demolition. The community fights back, joined by a phalanx of student activists who form the front line. After successfully turning back the demolition team, the residents organize themselves, led by one named Bonifacio, or Boni.

Mr Lopez tries more insidious means, like offering Boni a bribe and, later, getting a court to issue a 15-day eviction notice. Following Boni’s tack of exhausting all “legal” means, the group hires a lawyer to oppose the court order. They also organize rallies and demonstrations to attract public attention. Their efforts are foiled when they are denied permits to hold rallies by the police, who are on Mr Lopez’s payroll.

Desperate, the squatters forge an uneasy alliance with criminals in the area. The hostilities reach a turning point when the men of Mr Lopez burn Boni and Lando’s house, and in revenge they kill three of Mr Lopez’s goons. Soon it is up to the appellate court to decide the case.

The novel exposes not only greed epitomized by Mr Lopez but also the state’s complicity in the oppression of the disenfranchised in society. The state apparatuses that Mr Lopez has at his disposal—the police, the courts, and the legal system—become repressive tools. Although the communal efforts of the residents are initially effective, the novel’s resolution questions the efficacy of collective action against a coercive state.

The act of “squatting”—which the novel depicts as a valid political action—is portrayed as symptomatic of uneven urban progress. When the novel was serialized in 1985, the Light Rail Transit was newly built. The new mode of public transport, a sign of prosperity, is often juxtaposed with the poverty of the squatters’ area.

Criminality is portrayed ambiguously, as being a weapon of the oppressed. Boni is best friends and lives together with Lando, the most prominent among the underworld characters. The homeowners’ association’s alliance with the criminals when all else fails enables them in the crucial stages of their struggle against Mr Lopez.

Yet more than the fallibility of institutions and the limitation of collective action, what is presented as tragic is the community’s faith in the justice system and rule of law that has proven corrupt. This situation is especially striking given that the novel was published in Bannawag, a venue known for its glorification of Marcos and the dictatorship, during the waning years of the Marcos regime.  Written by Roderick Galam

text:
(Gold Is the Brown Earth). Published 1975-76. Author, Dominador Mirasol. Serialized in Sagisag, Sep 1975–Apr 1976. Anthologized in Panitikan at Kritisismo, edited by Rosario Torres-Yu, volume 3, Quezon City: National Book Store Inc, 1980. Cultural Center of the Philippines Literary Contest, grand prize, 1979.

This novel relates the saga of Moises Dimasupil, a dispossessed farmer who initially takes a stoic, pacifist stance in the face of massive injustice. Then he begins to understand the need for actively taking up his own cause as a human being with a family to protect, a land to defend, and a dream to attain. The passage to a Promised Land turns out to be fraught with agony and pain, terror and tribulation. Moises and his family find themselves fighting for their very lives against the forces of evil. Courage forged by hardship, and the timely help provided by a group of men fighting for the liberation of peasants like them, finally turn the tide of struggle.

The story, whose main action is set in the late 1960s, begins in a logging concession somewhere in Laguna. Exploited and dirt poor, Moises leaves the camp site with his family, and they settle in the forest, which he has earlier cleared. They live a peaceful life for many years. Their only problem is a huge snake which Moises has repeatedly tried to kill, unsuccessfully. With his sons Tante and Francisco, Moises finally destroys the reptile, but only after it has crushed his body, weakening him greatly. Other enemies appear on the land—the hired goons of an influential mayor, the lawyer who betrays Moises’s trust, and a group of avaricious Americans hunting for gold. Moises learns there is gold hidden in his land since the war, buried there by a Filipino soldier, and the secret has become known to the treasure seekers.

War breaks out between the forces of the mayor and the Americans, on one side, and the group of Moises on the other side. The fight is intense, and the forest is littered with casualties. A heavy rain pours for days, triggering landslides which bury the hidden gold beyond the reach of greed. Peace descends upon the land. Moises and Mando, dissident leaders whose forces have come to help, meet again, and the old peasant finds out that his son Francisco is now a member of Mando’s armed group. The young man had left the land to seek education as a solution to poverty, only to be disillusioned with the system; he has joined the revolutionary forces fired up by new hope. Moises’s mission of leading his people into a Promised Land now enters a higher stage, in which his son is going to play an important part. Moses had initially refused Mando’s offer of joining up with the collective effort of organized people to fight for their right to the land they till. The struggle against the gold hunters has made him realize the meaning of commitment and real solidarity. The biblical allusion to deliverance is unmistakable. The protagonist’s name is highly symbolic: Moises Dimasupil, literally meaning “unconquerable liberator.”

With this novel, Dominador Mirasol joins the ranks of major contemporary Tagalog writers whose aesthetics has been shaped and sharpened by ideological principles. Written during the period of martial law, this work is extraordinary in its lucid presentation of the travails of peasants in the Philippine countryside, and of the uncompromising, radical worldview which the author clearly validates in the novel’s resolution.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

 

Sources

Quito, Gil. 1978. “Dominador Mirasol: Kusot at Kwatro Kantos.” Diliman Review 26 (Oct-Dec): 53-55.

Reyes, Soledad. 1978. “The Individual and Society in the Novels of Dominador Mirasol.” Diliman Review 26 (Oct-Dec): 49-53.

text:
(The Gold in Makiling). Published 1947. Author, Macario Pineda. Manila: Palimbagang Tagumpay. Reprinted, with an introduction by Soledad S. Reyes, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University, 1990, 1993, 2001, 2007. English translation, The Gold in Makiling, by Soledad S. Reyes, Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2012.

This love story is also an account of the history of a community, based on a popular legend centered on Mount Makiling, Laguna, and the deities that inhabit the site. The community in the story has been described as a microcosm of a country in search of heroes.

The novel begins with the departure of Edong, with a group of farmers who intend to sell their palay, or unhulled rice, in the neigboring towns of Laguna. Sanang, Edong’s sweetheart, asks him to bring back some orchids that abound in the mountains. When the men return, Edong is not with them. Sanang is told that Edong has fallen into a ravine while trying to save some birds precariously perched on a mountainside. Sanang is disconsolate but her sadness turns into joy when Edong suddenly returns with a mystifying story. He narrates to Sanang how he was saved by a goddess, Mariang Makiling, and how he was nursed back to life by the inhabitants of the town at the foot of the mountain. According to this account, the inhabitants of this town are extraordinary creatures because they do not suffer from such emotions as greed, envy, hatred, or ambition. Instead they lead peaceful lives as farmers working on the land. But they are not allowed to bear any children. We learn that these are the country’s heroes—Lakandula, Sulayman, Jose Rizal, Andres Bonifacio, and so on.

Edong takes the child Doro back to Makiling with him. He has a happy stay with the immortals, and when he goes home, Maria gives him a sackful of ginger. Upon arrival at his house, he finds a sackful of gold nuggets instead. Greed possesses the boy’s father. Together with other evil men, he hikes off to the mountains, planning to steal more of the gold. At night they hear terrifying sounds, warning them to leave the mountain. The goddess punishes them with the loss of their sanity.

The narrative goes on to detail the life of Sanang and the many events in her life, which include a raid on the barrio perpetrated by her suitor. The battle ends with Sanang’s folk lying dead. An account of what Sanang does for the rest of her life follows. The boy gets an education at Ateneo de Manila. The story ends with the narrator talking to Ka Doro, who is now an old man. He says that this is the time for the heroes to come and rescue the country from ruin. The gold of Makiling refers to the country’s young men and women who are willing to work for humanity; this is possible, avers the old man, through education.

The significance of the novel lies in its masterful handling of modern story techniques and the successful evocation of a past world. A visionary quality marks the dreamlike sequences set in Makiling, up to the final exhortation that Tata Doro gives as the story ends. A foil to the likes of Sulayman and Rizal is Sanang who is the novel’s real heroine, because it is she who lives her life most fully in the service of others. It is characters like her, the novel seems to be arguing, who can rebuild the nation from the ruins that it has become.  Written by Soledad Reyes

Published 1988. Author, Alfred A. Yuson. Quezon City: Adriana Printing, 1988. Revised edition, 1996, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1987.

The novel’s plot revolves around two major characters: the revolutionary hero Leon Kilat and the writer Robert Aguinaldo. Escaping the Spanish authorities, Leon hides in the forest, where, one night, beneath a banana tree, the charm of the banana leaf falls into his open mouth and gives him supernatural powers. He sees in a vision his whole future and the future of the Filipino nation, with all the laughter and sorrow, a vision he then sets off to complete. This narrative is subsequently revealed to be the para-novel of Robert Aguinaldo, writing a century later, toward the end of the Marcos dictatorship.

The Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café is a cornucopia of self-conscious modernist and postmodernist strategies, including anachronism, wordplay, stream of consciousness, intertextual allusion, parody and pastiche, magical realism, metafiction, breaks in space and time, endnotes, and many more.

These strategies work to destabilize any monological construction of Philippine history and the nation. Leon’s laughter is emblematic of the novel’s tendency toward extravagance and exuberance. The novel’s metafictional, carnivalesque, and magical realist bent interrogates concepts of knowledge, order, and reality, as well as the blurred division between fiction and history. Real historical writings are extensively quoted and juxtaposed with a very different portrayal of the figures they attempt to construct. For example, Donn V. Hart’s essay about the millenarian hero Buhawi is juxtaposed with a childish, extravagant, and truly superhuman Buhawi. At the same time, Robert Aguinaldo’s process of writing is shown explicitly to the reader to raise questions about the inherent selectivity in the creation of any narrative. In making any single narrative of Philippine history impossible, the novel proposes a Filipino nation composed of multiple voices, interacting and contradicting across time and space, in the same way that Leon Kilat and Robert Aguinaldo interact in the novel.

These techniques, however, lead to the co-optation of real, marginalized, revolutionary figures to suit the novel’s postmodern stance. Parody, by definition, is premised on the readers’ knowledge, understanding, appreciation—and even admiration—of the object being parodied. The various histories and discourses represented by heroes like Leon Kilat, Buhawi, and the millenarian movements are little known, if at all. Thus, while the novel uses parody to construct a polyphonic Filipino nation, this mode also perpetuates the still marginalized positions of these heroes.

The novel is bold, wild, inventive, and masterfully crafted, a seminal text in postmodern Philippine literature and, in the words of Nick Joaquin, a poem. This, however, is the position of only one school of thought in the Philippine literary tradition. The questions Yuson raises about history and nationhood, as well as the license that he takes with real, marginalized, revolutionaries, continue to spark debates among its Filipino readers.  Written by Dominic Sy

(Fragrance). Published 1946. Author, Alberto Segismundo Cruz. Manila: Palimbagang Tagumpay.

The American colonial regime brought with it an accelerated pace of industrialization. Alberto Segismundo Cruz’s Halimuyak establishes a causal relationship between “progress” and the loss of a nurturing traditional way of life. Specifically, the novel zeroes in on the construction of a railway that wreaks havoc on a whole community of people.

Kabulusan, a village in Manila, has been spared the progress that other places in the city, with their paved roads, gleaming town plazas, tall buildings, and huge houses, enjoy. A government railway project, however, threatens the harmony that Kabulusan’s inhabitants enjoy and their self-sufficient economy. They grow and sell their own food. The railway would cut through the heart of the village. The community is angry.

Aning and Neong, both students of Maestrong Tino, take different positions. Aning is adamantly against the plan, while Neong favors the project. She wants, however, that the engineers move the railroad so that it may spare a large number of houses and vegetable gardens that would otherwise be in its way. After a series of pranks directed at those supervising the government project, and after Angel, an engineer, has listened to the people’s reasonable demands, the railroad is built without damaging most of the inhabitants’ dwellings and means of livelihood.

The threat to the community’s life is temporarily contained, but the railway makes an undesirable impact nonetheless: young men leaving behind their gardens to work as machinists, conductors, or shop workers. The elders rue their precipitate decision to be paid laborers rather than owners of their small businesses. Later, after a train is derailed with many lives lost in the accident, the community is in constant fear. More train-related accidents happen.

Meanwhile, the relationship between Aning and Neong also gets derailed. Neong realizes that he is in love with Aning, but she has fallen for Angel, the engineer, whom she accepts in marriage.

The wedding day, however, is marred by the discovery of the mangled body of Lety, Neong’s cousin who is secretly in love with him. She is yet another victim of a train accident. Aning suffers a physical and emotional breakdown. Neong, already stressed out by what he perceives as a brutal erosion of the community’s way of life, loses his mind. He is arrested as the suspect in the latest accident. The wedding is cancelled.

Instead of harboring a grudge against the community, Angel works tirelessly to secure the temporary release of Neong. The real culprit is discovered. His motive was vengeance: in his dying confession, he says that he was one of those whose house and vegetable garden were forcibly taken away for the construction of the railway.

Kabulusan’s old way of life destroyed, the village is now a pale reflection of the its once vital, thriving self. Aning decides to enter the convent. Angel leaves for abroad as a government scholar. Neong, slowly recovering from his mental breakdown, stays in Kabulusan to continue to inspire hope in the community now learning to adjust to the effects of urbanization.

In its exploration of the conflict between progress and modernity, between the rights of the state and the rights of the individual, and in its creative handling of the image of the fragrant flower at various but interconnected levels—Kabulusan, the habitat; the gardens teeming with sampagita (jasmine); Aning as the flower of Filipino womanhood—Halimuyak stakes its claim as one of the best works of Alberto Segismundo Cruz.

Unlike in other novels where the setting is a mere backdrop to a love story, in Halimuyak place and period shape the narrative itself. In retrospect, the novel is a moving elegy to a way of life that millions of Filipinos knew before progress marched thunderously and inexorably over it.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Come to Our Tomorrow). Published 1945. Author, Macario Pineda. Published in Aliwan, no. 73.

In this his first published novel, Macario Pineda offers a complex picture of the Philippines in the years 1896-99.

Coming home from the battle as one of General Luna’s soldiers, Jose “Pepe” de la Cruz lies inert in a horse-drawn cart, fearful that he would be captured by American soldiers. The novel flashes back to three years ago: In the company of Kapitang Tomas’s tenants, Pepe witnessed the rapacity and greed of the rich and powerful. As the tenants were delivering their sacks of rice, Bosyong, Kapitang Tomas’s overseer, berated the farmers for cheating the owner of his share. When Pepe remonstrated with Bosyong, Bosyong made up a story to make Pepe look bad before Kapitan Tomas. The landlord shot and almost killed Pepe. Extremely contrite for what her father had done, Maria Luisa visited Pepe and explained that Bosyong had confessed the truth to her father—thus began their love story.

Pepe warned her that death would befall Kapitang Tomas should he leave with the parish priest for Manila to betray the secrets of a dissident movement in town. Kapitan Tomas’s life was saved. Pepe left to join the revolution but only after Maria Luisa had given him a necklace as a token of her love.

The second part of the novel details the events in Pepe’s life as he recovers from his battle wound. Instrumental in the healing process is Captain Smith, whom Pepe mistakenly thinks is his captor. But the American soldier is a kind doctor who establishes rapport with the village folk.

Pepe’s physical wound heals, but his emotional wounds persist: Pepe is a former soldier who has seen the devastating effects of war, a poor farmer with a small field to till, and a lover agonizing over his ability to secure a future for the woman to the manor born. Believing that Maria Luisa has abandoned him for a wealthier man, he decides to leave the barrio in the company of a fellow war veteran, Berto, his sister Maria’s sweetheart, in search of a better life elsewhere.

They travel until they reach a land where three mulawin (molave) trees grow. They clear it to make it habitable. But snakes abound even in this paradise: they are attacked by unknown men. The timely arrival of Captain Smith and his soldiers, however, saves them.

Maria Luisa and Pepe are reunited. The land that Pepe names “Tatlong Mulawin” is to be divided equally among him, Berto, and Maria Luisa. In this promised land, they will all be equal and devote themselves to cultivating a new community. Leaving the past behind, the characters set their eyes and mind on a bright future.

With this first novel, Macario Pineda not only affirms his reputation as an excellent chronicler of barrio life but also disabuses readers of the perception that he was a writer of bucolic scenes and predictable love stories. Pineda shows himself as a writer deeply immersed in the concrete specificities of Philippine history: the beginning of the revolution, the cupidity of friars, the arrogance of the powerful elite, the evil of the feudal system, the bloody battles, the heroism of Filipino soldiers fighting against numerous odds, the coming of the American forces and the contradictory images they created in the consciousness of the natives.

Idealism is the novel’s dominant mode, and its sensibility unequivocally utopian. The difference between classes, Pineda makes it clear, can never be made to disappear. Thus, Pepe and Maria Luisa must found themselves a new world where they can be equal, Pepe no longer a lowly supplicant. Pineda’s Ang Ginto sa Makiling, 1947, would be the logical development of Pineda’s art.   Written by Soledad Reyes

They travel until they reach a land where three mulawin (molave) trees grow. They clear it to make it habitable. But snakes abound even in this paradise: they are attacked by unknown men. The timely arrival of Captain Smith and his soldiers, however, saves them.

Maria Luisa and Pepe are reunited. The land that Pepe names “Tatlong Mulawin” is to be divided equally among him, Berto, and Maria Luisa. In this promised land, they will all be equal and devote themselves to cultivating a new community. Leaving the past behind, the characters set their eyes and mind on a bright future.

With this first novel, Macario Pineda not only affirms his reputation as an excellent chronicler of barrio life but also disabuses readers of the perception that he was a writer of bucolic scenes and predictable love stories. Pineda shows himself as a writer deeply immersed in the concrete specificities of Philippine history: the beginning of the revolution, the cupidity of friars, the arrogance of the powerful elite, the evil of the feudal system, the bloody battles, the heroism of Filipino soldiers fighting against numerous odds, the coming of the American forces and the contradictory images they created in the consciousness of the natives.

Idealism is the novel’s dominant mode, and its sensibility unequivocally utopian. The difference between classes, Pineda makes it clear, can never be made to disappear. Thus, Pepe and Maria Luisa must found themselves a new world where they can be equal, Pepe no longer a lowly supplicant. Pineda’s Ang Ginto sa Makiling, 1947, would be the logical development of Pineda’s art.   Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1962. Author, Kerima Polotan. Manila: Regal Publishing Company. Originally a long short story titled “Sounds of Sunday,” published in Sunday Times Magazine, 1 Jan 1961, and reprinted in the Asia Magazine, 1962.

This novel won the Stonehill Award in 1961. It is the story of Emma Gorrez, whose idealistic quest for personal integrity in people is frustrated at every turn. Her relationships with men, beginning with her father, are doomed because of their inability to live up to her standards. For a while, she thinks she has found her ideal in Doming Gorrez. But he too becomes entrapped in the materialistic world as his ambition to become successful in Manila corporate life makes him more ruthless and amoral every day. Unable to live with Doming, Emma returns to her old teaching job in the small town of Tayug, where they first met. The old affection between Emma and the school principal Rene Rividad is rekindled, but she lets it get no further than that. In the end, Rene commits suicide with his wife, Norma, by setting their house on fire. Emma writes Doming a letter in which she bids him goodbye with a finality that seems to hint of suicide, or at the very least, of eternal separation.

All the characters in this novel are burdened by guilt, whether or not out of a sin of their own making. Rene lives with the guilt of having survived while his parents were killed in the Sakdal uprising; his wife Norma is a nymphomaniac, perhaps because of his asceticism. Emma herself cannot claim full moral righteousness because of her marital failure and her attraction to Rene. Personal integrity, therefore, is not to be found in the easy choices of barrio over city life, honesty over corruption, or right over wrong. “Life,” as Rene says, “is the Enemy.”

The events in the novel are narrated from Emma’s point of view and, hence, through her recollections. Flashbacks reveal events as Emma interprets them. Woven into the main plot are stories of the other characters which parallel each other thematically. The novel expresses psychological insight and an existentialist theme in richly textured prose, almost poetic in its lyricism.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Published 1970. Author, Lina Espina-Moore. Manila: Solidaridad Publishing House.

This novel is set in Cebu of the 1920s. It is a nostalgic rendering of the fortunes of the Almena family. The controlling symbol is the family compound, “rising fully into the well-earned dignity of 152 years.” Five ancestral houses are under its keep. At its heart lies a lotus pond over which the Goddess of Mercy, Kwan Yin, benignly presides. The family’s name, literally meaning “battlements,” evokes the clash of ideas and values within the family and outside the walls of its compound—into a city still newly settling down into Americanization, while Spanish and Chinese ghosts remain powerful and potent in its native Cebuano racial memory.

“Lorenzo surveyed the scene before him and thought … how safe and solid everything was.” Yet this solidity is shattered in the face of tragedies: Concha’s marriage and Gonzalo’s death in the hands of the peasants; Insong’s unfulfilled love for Pilar Mercedes; Caridad, Lorenzo’s erstwhile lover, becoming a footnote in her child Amparo’s life. If for the grand dame of the family, Doña Filomena, these are settled matters and are unspoken of, it is because she and her cousins are of the generation dying. For the next generations, the questions remain and the resolutions are yet to come.

The author treads lightly on these conflicts, preferring to develop those that are of some importance for the family, but not quite central to the society around it. Lorenzo’s attempt to turn the tables on the Christians in the traditional komedya is an instance; Vicente’s emotional homecoming and the prejudice his wife comes up against are another. But, because of an Old-World honesty perhaps, the conflicts are named and the logic sets itself. Thus the women Yrinea, Pilar Mercedes, Concha, and Filomena, each in her own way, have begun to place male authority into question. Into the compound intrudes the city’s commerce. The peasants are unpunished for their paroxysm of rage against Gonzalo.

The novel’s characterizations are generous and truly painstaking. Espina-Moore’s nostalgia, gentle and forgiving, is unfolded skillfully, in language reaching heights of lyricism. One remembers Mercedes, throwing bits of garbage into the pond, telling Amparo: “Lotus grows well where the filth is.”  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
Published 1979. Author, Edith L. Tiempo. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

This novel has for its central character Marina, a schoolteacher born of an Ifugao mother and a Christian father. During the war, she meets Michael Linder, an American of Czech-German descent, who becomes her lover. But she rejects his offer of marriage, feeling that Michael would not want to marry “a bundle of uncertainties.” He is puzzled and hurt. He goes home to Columbus, Ohio, but now, 11 years later, is in Negros Oriental, having been given a job as the sugar central’s personnel manager. Marina is now married to an ambitious and scheming Spanish mestizo, Paul Lacambre. Paul, Michael soon finds out, has gotten himself involved in a fraudulent scheme. When Michael tells her about it, she refuses to believe him. Later, he realizes that she disbelieves him because, out of her indifference to Paul, she has no desire to interfere in her husband’s transactions. In fact, her artistic temperament and her independent cast of mind make her personality fully incompatible with Paul’s. In spite of her intellectual ability, she is, after all, still “a bundle of uncertainties.” In a turnabout, Mariana makes a decision to go back to the place of her childhood to her Ifugao roots. She retreats to Lagawe in the Mountain Province, to start a new life. There she realizes where she really belongs; and her restless searching for herself ends.

Marina is a complex Filipino woman. She is full of paradoxes—having tribal roots but steeped in American culture, intellectual and artistic but still incomplete and insecure. She is made whole not by marriage—that is, not through a man—but by her return to her roots and by the new life she starts on her own. In short, she constructs herself by herself.

Michael does not understand this and thinks that her return to Lagawe is a withdrawal from real living; hence he thinks she is committing a mistake because “a man listened first of all to the compelling calls from himself, or he should, anyway.” Michael cannot see that he is applying an American and masculine logic to a Filipina, whose decision is a harbinger of the emerging feminist self-discovery. For Marina, the “compelling calls” are for her to go back to her tribe.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
Published 1941. Author, Juan C. Laya. Manila: University Publishing Co. Inc. Reprinted, Quezon City: Kayumanggi Publishers, 1972.

This novel in English won first prize in the first Commonwealth Literary Contests in 1940. According to the chairman of the board of judges, Carlos Romulo, the hero stood for reforms for a “parochial and squalid” Philippines by “encouraging private enterprise to hasten economic development.”

It is the story of Martin Romero, home after 11 years in America. Equipped with American ideas of enterprise, he arrives with fixed ideas of what is wrong with his country and what should be done about it. “To clean out these vipers eating into the bowels of the community” is his declared intention. From the beginning, he clashes with Abogado Murcia, an opportunistic local politician who sees in him a potential rival in the assembly elections. Martin’s father, Don Venancio Romero, is a venerable figure of the opposing clan. But Martin is more interested in putting up a marketing corporation. After convincing his father and his relatives to sell land to convert to capital and join the corporation, he organizes a “purely business venture.” He holds sweeping managerial powers, and this causes resentment among his relatives, who are used to a more personal style of management. Finally, as a result of a series of wrong one-man decisions, the company goes bankrupt. The novel’s resolution is rather abrupt: he decides to leave his town to make a fresh start, abandons Virginia Fe, and takes Soledad as his wife. His choice of Soledad symbolizes his final appreciation of traditional communal values.

The novel belongs to the socially conscious tradition of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. It defines two Filipino dilemmas: that between an impartial work ethic and paternalism, and that between the enterprising individual and the passive community. In a style marked by didacticism and rhetoric, it shows the pitfalls of a person’s impatient idealism and affirms the need for a broadly humanitarian social awareness.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
Published 1992. Author, Lina Espina-Moore. With a foreword by Josefa Borromeo Capistrano and a preface by the author. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

This is a World War II novel told from a Filipina’s point of view. The title, according to the preface, draws on an incident in Jan 1944, when a vendor approached the author at a funeral cortege to sell honey, and, later in the 1950s, when she chanced upon a haiku by Matsuo Basho.

The novel is composed of loosely connected episodes about people displaced and dispossessed by the war, and all in search of home. In the first chapter, “The Honeycomb,” Fe Moreno waits out the war in Santa Barbara Dormitory in Manila. Carlos Arias, a childhood friend from Cebu, visits her to seek her assistance of food and medicine for the guerrilla movement. She decides to join the resistance herself and sets off on an odyssey back to her hometown in Cebu. Along the way she meets people broken by war, who are homesick and anxious about the people they love. Each has a tale that is spun in the succeeding chapters, with Fe bearing witness to it all.

“The Starling” is about Ric Amado, a comrade in arms, who marries Fe’s friend, Marian Abella. They decide to settle in the Visayas but their short-lived marriage ends in one violent sweep of the surging sea. “Sapphire” introduces another character, Guadalupe Smith, who, like Fe, procures food and medicine for the guerrillas in the north. In “Macopa,” when Fe has reached Cebu City, a love affair between the married Hilda Sancho and Bernie Vivo, who is a Bataan Death March escapee, turns sour when Hilda’s husband sues them for adultery. The neighbors relish the entertainment that this domestic drama gives them amid the horrors of war.

In “Abelardo,” Fe’s cousin, Mrs Angelina Cortes, suffers the close scrutiny of their community. Coming from an affluent family she defiantly puts on a show of extravagance when she holds her American-style wedding reception in a Japanese-themed restaurant. This incurs the ire of the guerrillas and costs her her son. In “Augusto Tan: Spy,” a Chinese mestizo is hired by the Japanese for his oriental looks and for his knowledge of Nihongo. He, too, pines for Cebu, his home, and arranges for his return. Upon seeing the outline of Cebu, he lets slip a word in Cebuano to the Japanese pilot. In “Claudia in the Orchard,” Fe is back in Manila, finding friendship in Claudia, a daughter of a Chinese woman and an Englishman, who has yet to communicate since the bombing of Pearl Harbor. Refusing to marry a Filipino hacendero, Claudia flees to Hong Kong the moment her father makes contact and sends for her.

In “Walls,” Fe is again in Cebu, being held in a concentration camp after an embittered lover has testified against her. She is soon released, and she escapes to another province. The penultimate chapter, “The Moths of Talavera,” is about a settlement town stirred by an illicit love affair between Jessica Gabriel, whose husband is Fe’s comrade, and Raul Gil, cousin of the parish priest. The two are turned away by this community of war refugees. In the final chapter, “Deliverance,” Fe is once again in the capital for the much-awaited liberation, but the nation’s first sign of deliverance comes in the form of a US air raid. Those who survive it walk on, amid all the deaths, still seeking shelter.

The novel’s title is a biblical allusion, thus underscoring the characters’ faith in salvation and in finding the path home from the wilderness wrought by the war.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

article_title: Ang Huling Dalagang Bukid at ang Authobiography na Mali: Isang Imbestigasyon
text:
(The Last Barrio Lass and the Erroneous Authobiography: An Investigation). Published 2011. Author, Jun Cruz Reyes. With an introduction by Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Jun Cruz Reyes’s book is an experimental mesh of two literary genres—a planned novel titled “Ang Huling Dalagang Bukid” (The Last Barrio Lass), and his autobiography, “Authobiography na Mali” (Erroneous Authobiography).

The work’s hybrid structure is borne out of the complications that hounded Reyes in the writing of his novel. Reyes reveals in the first chapter that he, or his first-person narrator, was intending to return to his hometown, Hagonoy, to retrieve the drafts of his novel / documentary film titled “Ang Huling Dalagang Bukid,” when his townspeople warned him of military personnel sifting through the debris of his house, which had recently burned down.

Now haunted by the terror of state aggression and the specter of his unfinished work staying unfinished, he embarks instead on writing what he calls his “erroneous authobiography”—a meandering “investigation” of his growth as a writer known for his willful stance against the bearers of power. Erroneous because its subject and manner of telling stray from social and literary conventions, the “authobiography” is part personal essay and part sociological study. It covers Reyes’s free-spirited boyhood in Hagonoy up to his present stature as a celebrated author now confronting the peril of state terrorism.

Weaving gossip and folklore, he recounts the boisterous stories of his relatively privileged childhood, the vibrant customs and traditions of his people, and the complex narrative of power relations in the small town. With an astute sociological eye, he paints the picture of Hagonoy and its people against the backdrop of feudalism, military terror, and the changing faces of elite democracy. The town is the focal point of Reyes’s “authobiography,” to which his ruminations repeatedly return even when he narrates his more recent clashes with authority figures in the city, in the academe, and in the literary world.

Reyes’s skillful use of stream of consciousness seamlessly sews together his “authobiography” with his spectral novel, which he has envisioned to be structured like a documentary film. The unfinished work is a tragicomic narrative of the impoverished town of Wakas (literally, “End”). To help their families escape from the clutches of poverty, the young women leave the town and work as migrant laborers, primarily as entertainers in Japan. Soon, the farmlands and fishponds of Wakas are abandoned, and the entire town is lured into the frenzy of the migrant labor phenomenon. Highly reminiscent of his hometown Hagonoy, Wakas, rendered in Reyes’s satirical storytelling, is a microcosm of the nation. Within this fictional town, the issues of modern-day heroism, state abandonment, capitalist greed and exploitation intersect with the ordinary lives of the village people.

More than its postmodern embellishments and subversion of traditional modes of storytelling, Reyes’s work significantly engages with the crucial question of the writer’s place and role in society. This he answers by painting a full-blooded portrait of a writer thoroughly acquainted with the political and historical reality of his society, along with its dangers and threats.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

This he answers by painting a full-blooded portrait of a writer thoroughly acquainted with the political and historical reality of his society, along with its dangers and threats.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

text:
(The Last Freeman). Published 1936. Author, Servando de los Angeles. Manila: Palimbagang Manuel Zamora.

Said to be based on the novelist’s actual experiences when he ran unsuccessfully for governorship of Rizal, the novel resonates with great power as a social realist text. It begins with widespread rumors of an impending rebellion to be mounted by the Colorum dissidents in the mountains of Baritan. Mateo de la Cruz, considered their leader, denies that they want to sow discord and shed blood. They have banded together—the oppressed farmers—because they have a noble cause. Their enemy is the prevailing system. They discern crooked politicians, such as Braulio de los Santos, Don Procopio, de los Santos’s sponsor, and a mysterious character as the wielders of power. These people have done nothing to help the poor farmers. Ranged against these characters are the concerned and committed ones: Mateo de la Cruz, a former ilustrado (educated native) who turns his back on his class to be of help to the poor; Ricardo Pilares, a brave editor and a passionate enemy of the system; Jose Romero, a student who joins the timawa (freeman); Lieutenant Ventura, the head of the constabulary forces that try to understand the farmers’ plight; and Macario Romero, the candidate supported by the timawa because he has promised to help the poor. Collectively, and with great difficulty, they are able to destroy the political machinery of the rich.

The novel was written a few years after the bloody Colorum rebellion in Pangasinan and one year after the violent revolt of the Sakdalista. This was the period of much agrarian unrest in the face of which the government could do nothing but respond with violence. The world as depicted in the novel is full of opportunistic, greedy, and duplicitous politicians and government leaders. Of the major issues delineated in the novel, the novelist focused on rampant government corruption, found at all levels. Even the love between Jose Romero and Adela, the daughter of de los Santos, falls prey to politics.

Ang Huling Timawa was a foil to the numerous novels of the 1930s, which delighted in describing agonizing love stories and endless sufferings inflicted on mothers and wives. Vigorous and dynamic, the novel exemplifies the strength of the tradition of protest. It suggests that the timawa as a destitute individual is an anomaly in a country that subscribes to democracy, and that it is only through the concerted effort of all the sectors in society that the slave may forever be banished from the land.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Birds of Prey). Published 1969. Author, Amado V. Hernandez. Quezon City: International Graphic Service, 1969. Partially serialized in Liwayway, 15 Jun 1959–12 Sep 1960.

Imagining the recovery from the bottom of the sea of the wealth thrown away by Father Florentino in the final chapter of Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), Hernandez explores the question of revolution as a means to effect basic change in society.

Set in the 1950s, the novel depicts the process by which the mass of workers and peasants is led to take an active interventionist role in society. Alejandro Pamintuan, a former servant of the wealthy landlord Don Segundo Montero, emerges from the war as a guerrilla turned reformist. He lays the groundwork for the formation of a movement and a program of reforms in order to arrest the further decline and decadence of a society devastated by war. He publishes a progressive newspaper, Kampilan, which aims to uphold truth, justice, and reason. With this paper, the movement finds a voice. As Mando Plaridel, he organizes people in their struggle for reforms. With a core of leaders, he also establishes the Freedom University, which aims to produce cadres with a new consciousness and a progressive vision.

Hernandez explores the limits of a reformist agenda, which was initially pursued by the movement led by Mando. He delineates the complex interaction of social forces for and against change. The result is heightened contradiction leaving the progressive camp no choice but to pursue the logical consequence of their struggle. In this, Hernandez, unlike Rizal, is unequivocal about the legitimacy of armed revolution. This novel remains a significant voice in the country’s radical discourse. The importance of this work lies not only in the magnitude of its scope—the depiction of the complex relations of the struggle in the city and the country—but also in the analysis of the nature of class conflict and in the historical sense that fashioned this work. Critics deem Hernandez’s prose at its best in this novel.  Written by Rosario Torres Yu

text:
(Mila’s Mother). Published 1969-70. Author, Austregelina Espina-Moore aka Lina Espina-Moore. Serialized in Bisaya, 31 Dec 1969–18 Mar 1970. Reprinted as a book, with a translation by Hope Sabanpan-Yu, Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2008.

Divided into 12 chapters, the novel is set in 1960s Cebu. The central character is antiheroine, Teresa Garcia, who rises up the ranks but falls again. Teresa’s mother was a bar dancer; her father, an alcoholic. She endures mockery for being an impoverished woman who has a relationship with Juan Eleazar, a Spanish mestizo from an affluent clan. Juan leaves her because she allegedly blackmailed a married man.

A few years later, Teresa marries Ken Graham, who is the archetype of the hardworking, pragmatic American. Her daughter Mila’s engagement with the son of her former lover, Juan, precipitates her downfall. Hence, Teresa is caught in one conflict after another, beginning with the wedding plans.

Teresa insists that the bride’s family shoulder the wedding expenses, as is the American custom. Her husband Ken reprimands her for wanting a lavish wedding for her daughter, but Teresa argues that she does not want people to think that an Eleazar is marrying beneath him by marrying Mila.

At the wedding reception, Teresa overhears guests gossiping about her in the bathroom. She confronts them and loses her temper. The enraged Teresa reveals that the Eleazars’s fortune was built on the opium trade. Later, Ken reminds Teresa that opium was legal during the Spanish era.

By the ninth chapter, Ken and Teresa are fighting over Teresa’s interference in their married daughter’s life. Teresa has advised Mila to profit from the Eleazars’ employees with a lending scheme. After a violent confrontation, Ken decides to divorce Teresa. He leaves for the States, confessing that he only stayed in the marriage for their daughter’s sake.

In the succeeding chapters, Teresa searches for Ken in Hawaii, Seattle, and New York, after he has entrusted nearly all of his assets to their daughter. Ken’s colleagues and friends conspire to keep Teresa from finding him. A dream sequence in which Juan Eleazar bars her from an extravagant party points to the root of Teresa’s character flaws. In the end, Teresa rejoices at the birth of her granddaughter, but she is also devastated by the loss of her husband.

In compact and lucid prose, Espina-Moore illuminates the life of the Cebu elite in the 1960s, when Spanish propriety was giving way to American influences, generally characterized by social critics as materialistic and morally loose. Here, Espina-Moore creates a tragic character whose flaw stems from what Philippine society then would deride as the shameful circumstances of her birth, the consequence of which is her mercenary streak that inevitably dooms all her personal relationships.  Written by John Bengan

text:
(Avenge Me!). Published 1914. Author, Precioso Palma. With an afterword by Julian C. Balmaseda. Manila: Limbagang Banahaw. Reprinted, Ang Singsing ng Dalagang Marmol / Ipaghiganti Mo Ako!, with an introduction by Soledad S. Reyes, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2004.

The narrative is purportedly a document that a grieving man, identified as Pedring, has turned over to the author. The novel shows readers the Filipino-American War from the perspectives of actual combatants, a witness to the bloody mayhem, and a Filipino woman, a victim of rape at the hands of a revolutionary soldier.

Pedring falls in love with his childhood friend Geli. Through his eyes, the reader journeys through the peaks and valleys of young love, including an extended section when Pedring finds himself in the throes of intense jealousy, which turns out to be unfounded.

Their happiness is short-lived. On 4 Feb 1899, a Saturday, the country is engulfed in the war against the Americans. Geli and her mother, Aling Tale, are forced to evacuate to Bulacan to flee the fighting in Manila. Pedro finds out about what has happened to Geli through a letter, which details the difficulties she and her mother experienced as they traveled from Tondo to Baliwag and which expresses the grief and suffering caused by her separation from Pedring. He also learns from a soldier about the horrendous sufferings of the civilian population and the difficulties that the revolutionary forces faced in the hands of the mighty American military, the subsequent death of Aling Tale, and the distraught Geli’s finding refuge in a kind old woman. Readers learn of the rest of the events in Geli’s life from the woman.

Five years later, Pedring sees her again, while he is with his friends in the idyllic town of Antipolo. A shadow of her former self, she recounts her journey through towns and mountainous paths from Baliwag to Nueva Ecija to Talavera. One day, she narrates, she and the old woman came upon a soldier who was severely wounded. They nursed him back to health. Geli even considered him a brother.

The soldier also had his own story: as a young man of 18 years, fired up by love of country, he had joined the revolution against Spain. He had thought that peace had been achieved with the signing of the Pact of Biak-na-Bato, but he had once more taken up arms to fight the American forces.

The hero turned heel, however, when he raped Geli. The child that she is with when Pedring chances upon her in Antipolo is the product of the rape. Tearfully, she begs Pedring for forgiveness. Pedring finds himself in a dilemma—he loves her but knows how a harsh society has already condemned Geli for being a fallen woman. As the novel ends, Geli dies of heart failure but not before she asks Pedring to avenge her.

Written when memories of the Filipino-American War remained fresh in the minds of a whole generation of writers, the novel offers significant insights into the riveting saga of the Filipinos’ war against the American colonizers from its victims’ perspectives. Palma’s critique of American colonialism is severe and unrelenting. Whereas the Spaniards’ colonial enterprise derived from a principle rooted in the “right of the conqueror,” the Americans invaded the country on the pretext of helping their allies—a supreme betrayal. The tragic love story of Pedring and Geli exemplifies the impact of war on the personal level.

Consistently used as a controlling image in the novel is the tyrant’s use of violence to subjugate a weaker person. The unequal struggle is played out in the theater of war between the American forces and the revolutionaries. The violence is reproduced on another level, when the Filipino revolutionary rapes Geli, thus reducing her to being the object of contempt, instead of compassion, by a judgmental and unforgiving society, and causing her son to reel from the shame of being a bastard.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Another Hero). Published 1915. Author, Juan Arsciwals. Manila: Limbagan ni P. Sayo.

This novel is one of the earliest novels to deal with the relationship between labor and capital. Set in 1914, it begins with the workers of a tobacco factory restlessly waiting for the result of a meeting. The labor leaders are deciding on what action to take in the face of the management’s decision to lower the wages. The consensus is for the workers to stage a strike, although Mauro counsels patience and moderation. An unnamed company manager talks to Pablo and offers him and his friends the strikers’ jobs. Pablo, in turn, approaches Gervasio, one of the leaders of the striking workers, and echoes the management: the workers have families, and it is their responsibility to make sure that their loved ones have enough to eat. Pablo is thus able to entice some of the striking workers to return to their jobs. Pablo and Gervasio try to convince Mauro to give up the fight, but Mauro and his wife Serafina are adamant. The conflict becomes bloody when a riot breaks out between Mauro’s group and Gervasio’s scabs. Mauro is wounded in the arm. He stabs Gervasio. When the police arrive, Pablo and Gervasio lie on the street covered in blood. Mauro is arrested, tried, and eventually sentenced to serve a prison term of nine months and a day. The last scene features Serafina and her three children still resolute and convinced that the struggle will go on despite this temporary setback.

The story unfolds in a terse, almost elliptical manner, with little attention to character psychology or vivid descriptions of scenes. The problem is defined as the novel begins, and the consequences of particular decisions are delineated with little fanfare. Thus, Arsciwals makes the purpose for writing his work very clear: to explain the reasons for the basic antagonism between two classes and the possible responses to the reality of this conflict. The events in the last section prove the righteousness of Mauro’s cause. Those who lull themselves into believing that management is really concerned for their welfare are bitterly disillusioned. Their salaries are further decreased; and unionism, the only recourse for the laborers, is banned.

Isa Pang Bayani remains as one of the novelist’s more important works for its unflinching examination of an issue that has touched the lives of millions of Filipinos.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Del Mundo, Herky, and Amante del Mundo. 1976. “Ang Maynila ni Juan Arsciwals.” Sagisag, 22 Jun, 39-41.

text:
(A Million Pesos). Published 1950. Author, Macario Pineda. Serialized in Liwayway, 28 Aug 1950–11 Jan 1951. Published as a book, with an introduction by Soledad S. Reyes, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2013.

In this posthumously published novel, Macario Pineda chose one of the most chaotic periods in Philippine history—World War II and the period of Liberation—as the context for the life of Jose de la Kurus, a battle-weary veteran forced by circumstance to metamorphose into a fearful criminal.

Jose returns from fighting in the war hungry and jobless, his left arm mangled from trying to save an American soldier, only to find that his mother has died. His uncle invites him to live a life of theft, which has enabled his cousins to live like princes, but Jose rejects the offer. With the blood of heroes running through his veins—his grandfather was a revolutionary; his father joined the militia—Jose remains unfazed in the face of suffering.

His resolve, however, weakens when he mistakenly thinks that his sweetheart Selya has left him because of his physical disability and is enjoying the company of Maj Alfredo Losano, a rich and handsome suitor. Jose joins his cousins in their criminal operations, even killing people in the process. Jose barrels his way into Manila’s criminal underworld and becomes known as “Duyan.” Thinking that Selya betrayed him for money, Jose throws his ill-gotten money at Selya. Eventually, he is gunned down by a member of a rival gang. In the hospital, Selya visits him and they are reconciled.

Jose mysteriously disappears when a military policeman comes to pick him up. Thereafter come mysterious sightings of Jose as a vagabond and a beggar, dirty and unkempt, roaming the towns of Bulacan. News spread in Bulacan about widows and orphans of dead soldiers receiving thousands of pesos, together with a letter of thanks.

When Jose is captured, Major Losano demands that Selya marry him in return for his working to spare Jose from being meted out a severe punishment. She reluctantly agrees.

As the novel ends, Jose reveals his secret to Colonel Garcia, the intelligence chief of the military: the American soldier he saved, George Smith, is the source of one million pesos that he, Jose, has anonymously distributed among the widows and orphans. Major Losano is exposed as a fraud. Selya explains that the money Jose threw at her has been used to buy a piece of land. The lovers, separated by men, are joined by fate.

While following the formulas of a typical action-driven Liwayway serial, Isang Milyong Piso, upon closer analysis, also offers glimpses of the vintage Pineda—the careful and restrained use of language to explore the inner world of the character, the committed writer with a profound degree of social consciousness, the artist who crafted scenes to reinforce the narrative’s meanings.

The original title of the novel was “Ang Kaban ni Simoun,” surely an index of the gravity of the novel’s intention. The image of Simoun’s chest of treasures thrown by Father Florentino into the ocean, with which Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo, 1891, ends, haunts the novel. While inside a church, uncomprehending and dazed by the discovery of the gift of one million pesos, Jose thinks that he hears Father Florentino’s words—that in times of need, the treasure should be retrieved from the depths to help the country. As he opens his heart to Garcia, Jose affirms the wider and more meaningful dimension of his act: to be an instrument that would change a community.

In this overriding desire rooted in an unequivocal diminution of the self, Jose regains his humanity and salvation. With this final novel, Pineda reaffirms his faith in those who work quietly but with persistence to bring about the common good. Jose de la Kurus must bear his cross in order to define himself as an authentic hero in the annals of Philippine literature.  Written by Soledad Reyes
