As the novel ends, Jose reveals his secret to Colonel Garcia, the intelligence chief of the military: the American soldier he saved, George Smith, is the source of one million pesos that he, Jose, has anonymously distributed among the widows and orphans. Major Losano is exposed as a fraud. Selya explains that the money Jose threw at her has been used to buy a piece of land. The lovers, separated by men, are joined by fate.

While following the formulas of a typical action-driven Liwayway serial, Isang Milyong Piso, upon closer analysis, also offers glimpses of the vintage Pineda—the careful and restrained use of language to explore the inner world of the character, the committed writer with a profound degree of social consciousness, the artist who crafted scenes to reinforce the narrative’s meanings.

The original title of the novel was “Ang Kaban ni Simoun,” surely an index of the gravity of the novel’s intention. The image of Simoun’s chest of treasures thrown by Father Florentino into the ocean, with which Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo, 1891, ends, haunts the novel. While inside a church, uncomprehending and dazed by the discovery of the gift of one million pesos, Jose thinks that he hears Father Florentino’s words—that in times of need, the treasure should be retrieved from the depths to help the country. As he opens his heart to Garcia, Jose affirms the wider and more meaningful dimension of his act: to be an instrument that would change a community.

In this overriding desire rooted in an unequivocal diminution of the self, Jose regains his humanity and salvation. With this final novel, Pineda reaffirms his faith in those who work quietly but with persistence to bring about the common good. Jose de la Kurus must bear his cross in order to define himself as an authentic hero in the annals of Philippine literature.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1967-68. Author, Magdalena Jalandoni. Serialized in Hiligaynon, 25 Jan 1967–10 Jan 1968. Reprinted, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2006. English translation, Juanita Cruz: A Novel by Ofelia Ledesma Jalandoni, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2006.

This Ilonggo novel was written when the author was 75 years old, two years before she received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award. Unlike other Ilonggo novelists who wrote under the Anglo-American influence, Jalandoni hewed closely to the Spanish literary tradition, perfecting the rhetorical use of language. Though she never dealt directly with broad social issues, she was alive to their implications. In her later novels, like Juanita Cruz, she went beyond her standard subject matter of love, life in the barrio, and the conflict between the rich and poor or between parent and child.

The novel is a love story set during the Philippine revolution. Juanita is driven away by her wealthy parents because of her love for a poor man, Ely Navarro. She goes to Manila, where she wins the affection of an old rich couple, who leave their wealth with her upon their death. Ely, now a famous singer, meets Juanita again. He fails to recognize her because he thinks her to have died in a sea accident. Much later, he discovers her true identity, and they are married. Ely and Juanita join the revolution against Spain. Ely becomes a general of the Philippine army and Juanita nurses the sick and wounded. During the war Juanita meets her brother and father, with whom she becomes reconciled before they die. Ely is killed after victoriously leading his army to free Iloilo from the Spaniards. With the end of the war, Juanita lives out her remaining days in the company of her adopted children.

In this novel, Jalandoni minimizes her tendency at direct moralizing, using more subtle ways of handling theme, such as dramatizing rather than telling, and using imagery and symbolism. Juanita Cruz represents the Philippines suffering under Spanish domination. The katya or glass prism is used to symbolize her vision of life as seen through the prismatic light of the Christian faith, with its redeeming hope and forgiving love.  Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

text:
Published, 2006. Author, Katrina Tuvera. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The novel tells the coming-of-age story of two siblings, Kiko and Gaby, who grow up during the rise and fall of the Marcos dictatorship. Their situation is made complicated because their father, Julian Contreras, is a member of the Cabinet. It is this simultaneous closeness to and distance from “the President” and the complex realities of the Bagong Lipunan that brother and sister must navigate to find themselves.

The plot is almost entirely linear, from the birth of Gaby before martial law to the final stages of the dictatorship. While focusing on Kiko and Gaby, the novel also weaves in and out of the lives of many minor characters: professors, prisoners, protestors, and politicians. Real personages are given different names or referred to by their positions, such as “the President” for Ferdinand Marcos and “the Senator” for Benigno Aquino.

These stories are juxtaposed with the many events, quotidian and monumental, that changed the nation’s history. In doing so, the novel challenges the official post-EDSA characterization of the dictatorship by showing, on the one hand, the grim and horrific abuses of power, and on the other hand, the well-meaning efforts of some government officials and the dubious characteristics of some rebels and heroes. The simple definitions behind “crony” and “hero” are suddenly unsettled, and the question of difference across the gap of politics is thrown disconcertingly into the world.

The Jupiter Effect is both bildungsroman and problematique, both deeply personal and overtly historical. Occasionally, the latter can overwhelm the former, a feeling emphasized by the brevity of the novel. Nevertheless, Tuvera’s sharp and succinct writing succeeds in giving every character his due and adds an important and unique perspective to martial law fiction.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Ang Kabaho, Unya, ang Kahumot sa Pulbos
text:
(The Odor and Fragrance of Powder). Published 2007. Author, Temistokles Mangila Adlawan. Serialized in Bisaya, 2 Jul–19 Dec 2007.

This novel is set in a town called Lipata in Minglanilla, Cebu. The narrator and protagonist Cesar Selonia wishes to settle down after retiring early from his post as a government employee in Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. His plans are forestalled when he is accused of assaulting the woman with whom he has fallen in love. Part detective story, part romance, the novel follows Cesar as he tries to clear his name and reclaim the quiet life he has sought for himself.

Connie Rentopa, a 27-year-old public school teacher, attracts many suitors in Lipata. However, she rebuffs all of them, including Cesar. One night, an unknown man barges into Connie’s room, but her sister Precy arrives just in time. Though she does not see her assailant’s face, Connie presumes he is Cesar and files a case against him. Like Cesar, the assailant drove a motorcycle and smelled of talcum powder.

Coincidentally, Cesar has bruises on his face because he had an accident on the same night as the failed assault of Connie. He had attended a dance where he saw Connie pairing up with Macario “Karyo” Lobitanis, a man Cesar knows from Bonifacio, Misamis. With the exception of Cesar’s relatives and close friends, the whole town is convinced of his guilt.

Meanwhile, Kolasa, Connie’s household helper, is thrown out of her employers’ home after spreading rumors about them. Kolasa goes to Cesar’s house and begs him for a place to stay. Their unlikely friendship enables Cesar to gather clues as to what transpired during that fateful night.

Connie is assaulted a second time in her bedroom. She writes to Cesar, expressing disgust at his behavior and informing him that a settlement is now out of the question. Cesar writes back, asserting his innocence.

With the help of Kolasa, Cesar gets hold of a letter from Karyo to Connie that maliciously identifies Cesar as the offender. Cesar searches for Karyo in Misamis and discovers that Karyo has lied about details of his life. Witnesses inform him about Karyo’s suspicious behavior. Cesar also learns that Karyo’s parents in Pagadian were killed recently in an accident. He writes Connie that he has found her true aggressor. Connie follows Cesar to Misamis, where they both find out what has become of Karyo.

In this tale of love, transgression, and reckoning, it is Adlawan’s style that emerges as the hero. His sinuous prose captures the distinct registers, variations, and textures of Cebuano spoken by diverse characters. In the hands of Adlawan, the Cebuano novel becomes a tapestry of voices.  Written by John Bengan

article_title: Ang Kagilagilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah
text:
(The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah). Published 2003. Author, Carlo Vergara. Compiled by Nida Gatus. Makati: Visual Print Enterprises.

The graphic novel revolves around Ada, the gay owner of a beauty parlor, and a secret admirer of Dodong. When a stone mysteriously falls from the sky, Didi, Ada’s assistant, eggs him on to swallow it, hoping that like Darna, the famous character from the komiks created by Mars Ravelo, Ada would receive extraordinary powers. She does. As Zsazsa Zaturnnah, Ada battles extraordinary forces. First, she defeats giant frogs that were threatening the barrio folk. Then, she faces a horde of zombies. Among the “living dead” is Ada’s father, who hurls invectives at him for being a homosexual.

The most baleful and vicious force is the Amazonistas, invaders from another planet, bent on wiping away all men-forms. At Dodong’s instigation, the community rallies behind Zsazsa to help her expel the invaders. In fighting side by side with her, the community affirms its commitment to keep itself free from all forms of domination. The aliens retreat, and Dodong carries a weakened and battered Zsazsa in his arms.

In the epilogue, the media treats the phenomenal events as pure fiction, but Dodong and Ada feel real love between them. Ada decides to leave the barrio for the city with Dodong. Both are secure in the thought that there will be struggles ahead and that they must persevere.

This graphic novel is of importance when contextualized against the immensely rich tradition of popular culture in the Philippines. It burst into the scene at a time when the komiks and the local film industry lay dying. In a single act, Vergara resurrects powerful images from both forms. At the outset, it frames itself against the well-known komiks heroine Darna, whose legendary exploits have mesmerized readers and filmgoers since the 1950s.

The choice of the name Zsazsa resonates with the meanings attached to Zsa Zsa Gabor, a famous Hollywood actress, and Zsa Zsa Padilla, a popular Philippine singer and actress. In the battle with the Amazonistas, Vergara pays unabashed homage to popular film genres such as the melodrama and the “bomba” and to film icons: the Queen is named Femina Suarestella Baroux; her cohorts are called Nora A, Dina B, Sharon C, and Vilma S. Vergara also alludes to figures from high society and quotes from commercials and popular songs.

Vergara’s rendering of an ordinary mortal endowed with marvelous powers, however, departs from its predecessors. Whereas they rendered the struggle between good and evil in a generally serious tone, Vergara is playfully tongue-in-cheek, even while he problematizes gender. His illustrations also broke boundaries, panels dynamically spilling over into one another. The graphic novel so resonated with the public that it was adapted, first, into a successful stage play and then into a film starring Zsa Zsa Padilla playing the role of Zsazsa Zaturnnah.   Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1983. Author, Ceres S. C. Alabado. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

This novel in Filipino is about the Philippine revolution against Spain. It sets out with two aims: to write a story for a juvenile audience and to set down a historical account of the 1896 Cry of Balintawak.

The juvenile audience would identify with Plorante, who at the onset is obsessed, as only youth can be obsessed, with attaining full manhood and acceptance into a society that he at first does not quite understand is revolutionary. Around him are his friends Dadong, Tonio, and Renato, who overnight all become Katipuneros or members of the Katipunan, a secret society against Spain. With Clara, a girl who makes her own decisions, Plorante is by turns patronizing and vulnerable until circumstances force him to declare himself. His relationship with his father undergoes a deep change, the resentful fear and admiration turning at last to understanding as they stand as equals on the battlefield.

Another character is Pacifico, who has suffered much at the hands of his Spanish master, but who kills his master not for himself but for his mistreated brother. Plorante concludes that they are able to muster the strength to kill if they do it in the name of their suffering brothers, not in the name of individual revenge. To declare war on the conquistador and guardia civil (constabulary) was not an easy decision for the Filipino peasant, adult or adolescent. This decisive historical moment Alabado recreates vividly without rhetoric. She makes alive, through the characters and their development, a philosophy of revolution and history. In all, the action is tight and swift. The adolescent viewpoint proves to be a wise literary device: the respectful awe and sense of history of the main character from whose eyes we witness events is balanced by his inquisitive peasant common sense.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
First published 1929. Comic strip series. Author, Romualdo Ramos. Illustrator, Tony Velasquez. First published in Liwayway, 11 Jan 1929.

Kenkoy formally introduced the komiks in the Philippines. When Ramos, its writer, died in 1932, Velasquez, its illustrator, became the strip’s writer as well, until it ended in 1961, having run for three decades in various publications. Mga Kabalbalan ni Kenkoy (The Antics of Kenkoy), as the cartoon was originally called, first came out as a four-frame weekly cartoon strip occupying one-fourth of a page. Its initial appearance was met with enthusiastic response from the public. After the third week, it was given one-half page in the magazine, with six frames. A year later, it was occupying a full page in full color, and was appearing in the Liwayway chain of magazines published in five major languages: Tagalog, Ilocano, Ilonggo, Bikol, and Cebuano.

Kenkoy, whose full name is Francisco Harabas, is portrayed as a fun-loving, sartorially elegant, brilliantined dandy who talks in an amusing mishmash of Tagalog and English. This comic character illustrates the seepage of colonial ideas, tastes, terminologies, idioms, fashions, and values into the native sensibility. Kenkoy remains a romantic, devoted lover to his lady friend and future wife, Rosing, who is a marked contrast to the modernized Kenkoy with her traditional costumes, fidelity to her native tongue, and Maria Clara-like demeanor. While mainly about the adventures and misadventures of Kenkoy and the happy moments he shares with Rosing, the comic strip unravels a menagerie of characters and episodes reflective of the times and the manners. The cast includes Mang Teroy and Aling Matsay, his parents; Tirso, his archrival for Rosing’s affections; Ponyang Halobaybay, the fashionable lady whose own comic strip also doubled as Velasquez’s vehicle for showing off his modish fashion designs, which actually set off a trend during those days; Nanong Pandak, diminutive millionaire constantly scheming to impress women he admires, particularly Ponyang; Talimusak, neighborhood numskull who is Nano’s sidekick; Tinyente Dikyam, an African-looking officer who’s a friend to everyone; and other characters with names like Dr Wakwak, Talakitok, and Tsikiting Gubat.

The comic strip evolved in drawing style and content through the years. The inaugural strip shows a roughly drawn Kenkoy wearing checkered, flared pants, and an American sailor’s cap, strumming a Hawaiian ukelele as he croons an American song, then getting chased by a dog who keeps him up an electric post until the moon comes out. The drawings become more articulated: Kenkoy starts sporting a gleaming Valentino hairstyle and an American two-piece suit complete with tie, suspenders, and fedora hat; he begins spouting English words and expressions spelled in Tagalog; and the dog remains his nemesis on the street.

The hybrid language used by Kenkoy was one of the comic strip’s main attractions. These “Kenkoyisms” caught on fast: halo, get redi, watsamara, beri nesesari, baygali, wetaminit, gud morning, okey, okedowk, istak, tekewok, isputing, nating duwing, and many others. Stringing these together with native words, Kenkoy was the pioneer of “Taglish.” During the Japanese occupation, Kenkoy was used by the Japanese Information Bureau for its cleanliness and health campaign. With most publications closed by the Japanese, Kenkoy became the only comic strip allowed to appear during the war.

Accolades have been paid to him by well-known artists in other fields of art. Jose Corazon de Jesus, aka Huseng Batute, wrote a poetic tribute, “Pagpapakilala: Ay Introdyus Yu, Mister Kenkoy” (Introduction: I Introduce You, Mr. Kenkoy). Nicanor S. Abelardo composed a rousing march with a chorus titled Kenkoy Blues. In 1992, librettist Bienvenido Noriega Jr and composers Bob Serrano and Archie Castillo collaborated on a musical called Kenkoy Loves Rosing starring Janno Gibbs and Regine Velasquez. The Filipino funnyman has made a lasting mark on Philippine popular culture as a symbol of wholesome entertainment, native humor, and painless social commentary. The name, in fact, has entered the Filipino language as an adjective. A person who is kenkoy is fun loving, risible, and okey.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

Stringing these together with native words, Kenkoy was the pioneer of “Taglish.” During the Japanese occupation, Kenkoy was used by the Japanese Information Bureau for its cleanliness and health campaign. With most publications closed by the Japanese, Kenkoy became the only comic strip allowed to appear during the war.

Accolades have been paid to him by well-known artists in other fields of art. Jose Corazon de Jesus, aka Huseng Batute, wrote a poetic tribute, “Pagpapakilala: Ay Introdyus Yu, Mister Kenkoy” (Introduction: I Introduce You, Mr. Kenkoy). Nicanor S. Abelardo composed a rousing march with a chorus titled Kenkoy Blues. In 1992, librettist Bienvenido Noriega Jr and composers Bob Serrano and Archie Castillo collaborated on a musical called Kenkoy Loves Rosing starring Janno Gibbs and Regine Velasquez. The Filipino funnyman has made a lasting mark on Philippine popular culture as a symbol of wholesome entertainment, native humor, and painless social commentary. The name, in fact, has entered the Filipino language as an adjective. A person who is kenkoy is fun loving, risible, and okey.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Killing Time in a Warm Place
text:
Published 1992. Author, Jose Y. Dalisay. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Reprinted, with an introduction and epilogue by the author. Pasig City: Anvil, 2006. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 1993; Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1993; UP President’s Award for Most Outstanding Publication, 1993.

Noel Ilustre Bulaong, a student activist turned government officer, is returning to his country in order to bury his father. As his plane nears, he is suddenly assaulted by flashbacks of his activist past. These flashbacks form the core of the novel. While the activist Bulaong seems idealistic, even eagerly overenthusiastic about fighting the regime, he is frustrated by the very people he calls his comrades. For him, they take in questionable characters, are moving too slowly, or do not exert enough effort.

Bulaong’s family is torn apart by his decision to quit school and join the activists. His father, a retired policeman, strongly disapproves of his son’s choices, but he does not try to stop him. Noel observes that his father has a cataract, a subtle hint of the blindness that Noel will eventually acknowledge as his own for taking part in the underground movement.

With the declaration of martial law, Noel is arrested and sent to Camp Sunflower. There, he spends most of his days trying to fit in with the other inmates and trying to recreate society as they knew and remember it. Jail transforms him and beats down his defiant attitude. When he is released, his confidence in the cause is shaken and he does not return to his comrades. Instead, he begins to work for a magazine called Fresco and later for the government.

The scene that best captures Bulaong’s change is when he meets Laurie once more. In his activist days, she attracted him but he kept his distance because she was his friend and comrade Benny’s woman. When he makes love to her this time, he finds the encounter unsatisfying. He realizes that he was only equating the movement to her. The romantic illusions that he forged about the movement, its members, and himself are gone. He must either move on with his life or fight a cause that he no longer believes in or that, as his comrade Jong puts it, he never understood.

The novel ends just before Bulaong’s plane lands. Noel remembers that he has come to bury his father, his own flesh. The flashbacks have comprised a litany of his sins, imagined or otherwise. Coming back to the warm place of “storms and coconuts” in which people often have to find ways to kill time, he will need to confess.

This multi-awarded novel has often been described by its author as a semi-biographical piece. The author’s experiences with the protest movement, the boredom he felt in prison, and the listlessness of living within the confines of a dictatorial government are mirrored in the novel. Like Bulaong, Dalisay also worked for a magazine and for the government.

The novel is enlivened by Dalisay’s vivid descriptions of places: Manila, the apartment, Tambakan, Camp Sunflower, Cubao, Romblon. It is the gradual change in Bulaong’s character, however, that should not be overlooked. The novel is a mirror reflecting not only Bulaong’s faults but also the faults of a nation.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(When Summer Is Gone). Published 1970. Author, Rosario de Guzman Lingat. Manila: Liwayway Publishing. Reprinted, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1996. English translation, The Death of Summer, by Soledad S. Reyes, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 2013.

The author’s first published novel, it is a brilliantly crafted story of a man’s unceasing quest for eternal summer, of what he does to attain his dream, and of the consequences of his act on his family and on himself. The narrative follows the adventures of Victor from his gilded youth to old age, and explores the numerous relationships he has with different characters.

The story begins when Victor impulsively decides to elope with Atanacia while they are enjoying themselves at the carnival. Seething with anger, Atanacia’s family refuses to accept the couple into their home. This thorny relationship with his in-laws merely reinforces Victor’s conviction that he will never find his happiness in the woman he has married. Victor meets Eking, a man who has two wives, and Victor becomes convinced that Eking is a model worth emulating in his own search for happiness. This signals Victor’s odyssey from one woman to another until Atanada finally decides to leave him, unable to endure her husband’s infidelity any longer.

World War II breaks out, and Victor’s only son Luisito dies on the battlefield. A daughter, Carmela, has eloped with a married man and returns to their home, a changed woman; she eventually dies. In his old age, Victor still struggles to find that elusive happiness. He meets Gina, a cabaret dancer, and lives with her for some time until Gina leaves him.

Traumatized by the series of tragedies that has struck his family, Victor has a nervous breakdown and, on one occasion, he tries to commit suicide. Atanacia comes back to Victor as the novel ends. Gradually, Victor learns to accept the coming of old age and the irretrievable loss of his youth. As the rains fall, Victor is resigned to what life has yet to offer him, with the wife at his side.

On the surface, this is a tale of an adulterous man who is punished for his indiscretions. What endows the novel with dramatic force is the writer’s delineation of Victor’s inner life and the many steps he takes to make real this obsessive quest for happiness. The writer’s creative imagination renders in fully realized detail the complexity of Victor’s character, one perpetually compelled to seize the day. He will fail, as he realizes much later, but only after he has seen the futility of this quest.

Written in the 1970s, this is a groundbreaking text, offering a psychological study of a type of character which in earlier texts was used to symbolize wickedness and cruelty. Rather than follow a convenient stereotype, Lingat carefully draws a portrait of a man whose unceasing struggle becomes a myth for the contemporary man caught in a world where the dominant cult is that of the youth. The novelist subverts this central idea and shows the reader the same man peacefully accepting the passing away of summer.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Reyes, Soledad. 1978. 1982. Nobelang Tagalog, 1905-1975: Tradisyon at Modernismo. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
Published 1946. Author, Alberto Segismundo Cruz. Manila: Associated Enterprises.

On the surface a novel about friendship, unrequited love, and betrayal, Lakandula is also a history lesson on Tondo, once a mighty kingdom, later an important district with links to the secret Katipunan movement and a thriving fishing industry, but, at the time of the novel’s events, a poverty-stricken and vice-ridden area of the city, already a pale shadow of its glorious past.

Amelita, the niece of the rich Donya Mercedes, and Tindeng, the daughter of a family renting out horse-drawn carriages, are both students at the University of the Philippines and good friends. Their friendship is tested, however, when both of them fall in love with Angel, an orphan that Tindeng’s family has adopted and who is studying to be a lawyer.

Realizing that Angel has been smitten with the rich and lovely Amelita, Tindeng hatches a plot to make him marry her, Tindeng, instead. Discovered seated by Angel’s bed, Tindeng gets her wish to marry Angel. After a few years, however, she rues the day she concocted her plot. Losing sight of his mission, the once idealistic Angel begins to lead a degenerate life, and Tindeng and her son live in poverty.

For her part, Amelita works as a social welfare officer in the community and seeks to address the community’s serious problems: rampant vices, the people’s lack of initiative, corruption, and theft. In a curious twist, she faces Tindeng, now an emaciated, weary mother, whose child, Nestor, has been arrested for petty theft.

Driven by an overwhelming desire to uplift the horrible condition of Tondo, Amelita uses her power and influence in the government to exhort the community to help themselves climb out of the quagmire they have fallen into. At one point, she takes the stage and minces no words in denouncing Angel, who is then a candidate in the forthcoming election, for his moral shortcomings. Angel is repudiated by the electorate.

Now a pariah, Angel roams the streets in desperation, as Tindeng refuses his offer of reconciliation. The outbreak of World War II gives Angel a chance to redeem himself. He founds a group of guerrillas, aptly named Lakandula, the ancient ruler of Tondo. The band of young fighters inflicts huge damage on the Japanese forces.

The novel ends with the death of the long-suffering Tindeng. Angel, the alienated father who has repented of his sins, and the ever faithful, generous Amelita, step in to take care of Nestor.

Like numerous popular Tagalog novels, Lakandula explores familiar themes—a love triangle, the need for filial piety, the conflict between tradition and modernity, and concern for the marginalized poor. The experiences of the three major characters are cautionary tales, an oft-invoked convention of Tagalog novels, and a gallery of types: Angel is the symbol of the idealistic young man gone bad; Tindeng is the epitome of the suffering wife; Amelita is the agent of change.

However, this novel goes beyond dishing out platitudes about the sufferings of the poor. The novel is situated against a specific temporal and spatial context—Tondo in the first half of the 20th century when its fame as the birthplace of heroes and artists had dimmed—which Cruz fleshes out in great detail. With Lakandula, Cruz adds to the list of works that celebrate the Tondo of past glory and excoriates the postwar Tondo. Like his predecessors, the author writes a novel that offers hope for Tondo’s eventual transformation and its return to the important place it once occupied in Manila’s rich and complex history.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1907. Author, Juan Crisostomo Soto. Manila: Imprenta de Santos at Bernal 1907. Abridged form serialized in Ing Kapampangan, 15 Apr–31 May 1946.

Lidia is plotted along a love triangle involving Lidia, her sweetheart Hector, and her secret admirer FD. Although Hector and Lidia have professed undying love for each other, he is distraught to find her avoiding him. One Christmas Eve, he appears beneath her window and pleads with her to explain her strange silence. Lidia’s only answer is to return his love letters and to demand hers back. Later, Hector discovers among the returned letters one that is not his: a brief note asking Lidia for a meeting, signed with the initials FD. Unable to guess the identity of the writer, Hector suspects that he is Lidia’s new lover. One day, he overhears Lidia confiding to her girlfriend that she has broken off with Hector because someone informed her that Hector had been maligning her name. Hector asks Lidia to reveal the identity of her informant but she refuses. Meanwhile, FD visits Lidia, bringing with him as proof of Hector’s treachery some love letters that Lidia wrote him while he was away at school in Manila. Unknown to Lidia, FD, who had lived in the same boarding house as Hector during those days, stole these letters as part of a plan to win Lidia for himself. Driven to desperation, Hector stops Lidia on her way to church one afternoon. When she ignores him, he creates a public scandal by loudly professing his love for her and by impulsively kissing her on the cheek. Some nights later, Lidia is haunted by a dark vision of Hector’s corpse: she watches helplessly as the corpse rises from the casket, opens the window, and flies off into the air. Within a few hours after seeing the vision, Lidia hears that Hector, missing the last three days, has been found dead of poisoning, an apparent suicide. A year after Hector’s death, Lidia visits his grave and offers a white flower as a token of her love. Outside the cemetery, she meets FD, whom she forces to his knees before Hector’s grave to beg his forgiveness.

Lidia was the first prose narrative of its kind in Kapampangan literature. To readers familiar with the kuriru or romances, the plot of Lidia was conventional, even commonplace. What they must have found novel was the way in which it recreated the ambience of a time and place they recognized as their own: Lidia and her friends walking briskly in the cold night air on their way to attend misa de gallo or early morning mass; standing together in the churchyard before attending a novena in honor of the Sacred Heart; showering blossoms on the Virgen de Culiat as the procession passed by. These details gave Lidia a degree of realism not previously found in Kapampangan narratives. While not written in verse, the novel is written in prose style whose metaphorical language and rhythmic flow made certain sections sound like uncadenced poetry. Soto’s romanticism, a characteristic feature of all his writings, shows itself to fine advantage in Lidia, unarguably the most popular Kapampangan novel.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

text:
(Secret of an Island). Published 1927. Author, Faustino Aguilar. Manila: Sampaguita Press. Reprinted, Manila: Benipayo Press, 1958.

This allegorical novel reconstructs Philippine precolonial history in the context of a class-driven society reflective of the novelist’s own historical period. Set in the hypothetical kingdom of Lambak before the coming of the Westerners, the story foregrounds the deathless love between Luningning and Hinahon against a broad social landscape of class conflict between, on one side, the timawa or free persons who occupy a low social status, and on the other, the island’s nobility and the foreign invaders—the pirates. The hero, Hinahon, is a timawa who defends the poor and oppressed of Lambak against people like Lakan Kislap, the leader of the marauding sea pirates. The king of Lambak ignores the pleas of Hinahon by spreading the rumor that those who stand in his way are thieves and murderers. Disgraced, Hinahon is banished from the kingdom, and from the sight of his beloved Luningning. Hinahon travels to Mabuso sa Nitatalo where he plans to continue defending the poor. Enlisting the help of Balaho, Kislap’s former right-hand man, Hinahon eventually defeats and captures the pirates, but in one encounter he is mortally wounded. Luningning mourns the death of Hinahon. She soon marries Gat Tarik, the leader of the king’s forces which fought the pirates. Luningning continues to pine for her Hinahon. She dies and is buried beside his grave. They are elevated to the status of immortals.

The significance of the novel lies in at least three aspects: its unprecedented reconstruction of a Philippine past in a language that sought to approximate the language of the ancient Filipinos; its dramatization of the motifs and mosaics of the country’s vital and rich indigenous culture; and its allusions to the power structures and social hierarchies obtaining in the Philippines of this period, the American colonial period.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1998. Author, Carlos Cortes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This novel by the Cebu-born Cortes retells the story of Ferdinand Magellan’s expedition to what would be the Philippine Islands from the point of view of his Malay slave and interpreter Enrique of Malacca.

In the book’s preliminaries, Cortes presents a fictitious account of how the “author” of the novel Longitude obtained a manuscript which the author has translated from Portuguese. However, he expresses doubt over the manuscript’s authenticity, a self-reflexive comment on the unreliability of texts in general and of history and literature in particular. The author’s historiographic intention is clear: the novel pays homage to Enrique in the same manner that Pigafetta’s writings paid tribute to Magellan.

We hear Enrique’s voice for the first time in the “Prologue” as he narrates the mythical foundation of his race, from its creation in the fabled mountain of Meru to the glorious days of Sri Harimau of Sri Vijaya. The novel is then divided into four main sections that follow the trajectory of Enrique’s voyage: “O Mundo Novo” (The New World), “No Outro Mundo” (In Another World), “O Mar Pacifico” (The Pacific Ocean), and “O Mundo Velho” (The Old World).

In “O Mundo Novo,” the story begins in Seville, Spain. Enrique attends to Magellan as he prepares to embark on a voyage to find a Western route to the Spice Islands. At a stopover in the Canary Islands, they receive information about treachery in the armada. The mutiny begins but fails. Enrique observes the strange ways of his master and the “white men,” such as their faulty concept of time and distance and their inability to invent a method for measuring longitude.

In “No Outro Mundo,” the expedition reaches Brazil after many months at sea. During their search for the mythical passage of Mar do Sul (South Sea), they withstand another mutiny.

In “O Mar Pacifico,” they enter what they call the “Pacific Sea” after eight months of searching for the passage. Crossing the Pacific, Enrique dreams about Magellan’s life before the expedition. Before they reach Guam and Homonhon Island, Enrique returns to the story of his race, narrating his birth and eventual enslavement.

“O Mundo Velho” describes the expedition’s brief stay in Homonhon. They proceed to Masawa and Sugbu where they are warmly welcomed. The rajahs and datus pay tribute to the captain-general and Laksamana of España. Lapulapu, the datu of Mat-an, refuses to welcome them, prompting the armada to launch an attack on Mat-an. They are easily defeated by the natives. After Magellan’s death, Enrique turns against the armada and his treason incites a massacre at a banquet. Eventually, the remaining members of the armada leave Sugbu.

In the “Epilogue,” “Afterword,” and “Endnote,” Enrique plans to return to Malacca but decides to build a hut on a deserted island. In pursuit of historical accuracy, the author searches for the original owner of the source manuscript, one Tristão Lopes-Pelea. He receives a letter reporting the death of Lopes and he soon notices the resemblance between the sender’s signature and the handwriting in the manuscript. The author poses a theory that Enrique is originally from Sugbu, which if correct, would make Enrique the first circumnavigator.

For much of history, Magellan’s expedition is about finding new frontiers to conquer. In this novel, Enrique’s odyssey becomes a search for one’s place in the world. The voice that has been marginalized in history takes the role of protagonist in fiction. Inventive and at the same time rigorously attentive to archival details, Cortes sees colonialist history as a malleable fiction that can be reshaped to offer the alternative story of an exile. In the Age of Discovery, here is a character who is not looking for something new, but who seeks the glory of his past.  Written by Jeffrey Javier

article.value: Published 1998. Author, Carlos Cortes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
(Before Sunrise). Published 1909. Author, Iñigo Ed. Regalado. Manila: J. Martinez Publishing. Reprinted, with an introduction by Soledad S. Reyes. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1987.

Written when Regalado was 18 years old, the novel is known for its experiment with “formlessness.” There is no single plot in the novel; instead, there are several interweaving strands of narratives. On the surface, the author’s singular interest seems to be the subject of love as expressed by several pairs of characters. Mauro, a painter-poet, is in love with Luisa, whose parents object to their relationship. Daniel is in love with Nieves, the daughter of a rich man. These lovers are up against not only their parents but also the schemes of a character named Pendoy, who is smitten with both women and who plots to destroy them and the men they love.

Pendoy writes Mauro a letter, insinuating that Luisa has been used to pay off a debt incurred by her father. He also writes poison letters, hinting at an affair going on between him and Nieves. Mauro and Daniel choose to lend credence to the anonymous letter writer’s mendacious allegations, and they drop the women. The other major narrative strand of the novel is the social structure of the period scathingly portrayed by Regalado as being controlled by greedy and opportunistic foreigners and their Filipino counterparts. One of them is Kapitan Leon, Mauro’s uncle, whose money comes from exploiting his workers. The author alternates idyllic description of love among the major characters with violent scenes of labor unrest in the city of Manila. Another important character in the novel is Juan Galit (the family name meaning “anger”), the son of a rich man who leads a dissolute life until he becomes impoverished. The omniscient presence in the main narrative, he becomes the avenger of society’s downtrodden, murdering Kapitan Leon in the novel’s climax. Galit invokes patriotism as the highest cause. He even admonishes Mauro to forsake personal concerns like love and happiness to fight for nobler ends. Other victims who, Galit sees, require vengeance include Nendeng, whose brutal experience in the hands of her own guardian, Mang Marcos, is graphic proof of women’s vulnerability to men’s abuse of power. The novel also makes parallel indictments of Pendoy, Mang Marcos, and the moral weaklings Mauro and Daniel who are quick to condemn women on the basis of lies.

The social dimension of the novel is intensified by discussions, among the male characters, on alternative means to change the oppressive system; these means range from the peaceful to the most anarchic. A mysterious American belonging to the Anti-Imperialist League even turns up in the narrative, and joins the Filipino protagonists in talking about the necessity for violence to subvert and overthrow the government.

Unwieldy and uneven in certain parts but energetic all throughout, Regalado’s novel stood out in his time as a work with an all-encompassing vision and a new approach to the interpretation of familiar reality.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(The World Be Lovely Still). Published 1955-56. Author, Lazaro Francisco. Serialized in Liwayway, 5 Dec 1955–30 Jul 1956. Reprinted as a book, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1982, 1989, 1992.

The age-old tenancy problem in central Luzon and the unrelieved suffering of the peasants in the postwar years form the historical background of this novel, which depicts the struggle of a war veteran, Lino, and others like him who have lost faith in an oppressive social system.

Deeply traumatized by what he did and saw during the war and by his experience as a job seeker in wartime Manila, Lino comes home to Pinyahan where he finds work as a gardener in the house owned by Miss Sanchez, a public school teacher. His wife is dead, leaving him to care for their son Ernesto, for whom Miss Sanchez develops much affection. Lino refuses to become a tenant. After having witnessed the disastrous and inhuman effects of the sharecropping system on his father and grandfather, he has sworn never to work for any landlord. However, his faith in country folk slowly returns, as he sees the willingness of some people to help improve the lot of the poor. Padre Amando, an enlightened landlord of Pinyahan and an uncle of Miss Sanchez, is one of the few who express their willingness to give up their land to be parcelled out to the needy farmers. But the process of restoring Lino’s faith is fraught with ordeals. While in Manila, he is falsely accused of committing robbery with homicide. Though innocent, he is convicted and sentenced to 11 years in prison. He escapes and leads the life of a fugitive, until he and his fellow prisoners find themselves trying to defend an enlightened landlord against the threats of the Huks, the dissident peasants of central Luzon and former guerrillas who fought the Japanese. Rumors about him as a ruthless murderer and thief abound. Through the help of Colonel Roda, Padre Amando, and several kindhearted people, Lino is made to understand the futility of leading this kind of life. The novel ends as Lino comes down from the mountain in the company of Miss Sanchez and those who care about him.

The novel belongs to the tradition of social and political literature since the 1900s. It is peopled with highly individualized characters representing social types: greedy landlords, enlightened rich, devoted public servants, corrupt lawyers, poor peasants, dissidents waging armed struggle, among others. In weaving together his complex plot, Francisco allows the voices of the dissidents to surface at crucial points. It is clear that the ideology espoused by the peasant leader Hantik is a major option confronting the embattled peasant class. This point of view, however, is not allowed by the author to dominate and become the key to the resolution of the conflict in the narrative. Indeed, the ending affirms his belief that change is possible if there is a “revolution” in the hearts of the contending social forces. Lazaro’s contention appears to be this: church and education, two of the most powerful and conservative institutions in the system, might still be agents of change.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Alaras, Consolacion. 1975. “The Novels of Lazaro Francisco.” Master’s thesis, University of the Philippines.

text:
(The Peanut Vendor). Published 1924. Author, Teofilo Sauco. Serialized in Liwayway, 20 Jun–1 Aug 1924. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Mayon Publishing House, 1933; Manila: MCS Enterprises Inc, 1970.

This well-received novel, which won the first prize in a contest sponsored by Liwayway magazine, helped establish the young Sauco’s reputation as a writer. Liwayway’s editor, Jose Esperanza Cruz, later described the work as Sauco’s masterpiece and a Tagalog literary gem. Love in its many forms is the shaping sensibility in this slim novel. Adding poignancy to this familiar theme is the unintended rivalry between a mother and her daughter for the love of one man.

The story begins with a series of narrations by Ingkong Pinong to his adopted daughter, Ninay. He recounts how a mysterious woman left her newborn baby with him 16 years earlier. He believes that this unfortunate woman had been abandoned by her lover. The child, whom he has named Ninay, is now a beautiful young woman who helps her guardian by peddling peanuts in Baliwag, Bulacan. One day, Ninay is seen by Luis, a handsome rich man from Manila who is immediately smitten with love for the girl. Luis is living with his mistress, Tentay, a famous cabaret dancer who, at 35, is still attractive and desirable. By chance, she discovers Ninay’s picture in Luis’s coat pocket. She comes to realize that Ninay is her own daughter, and vows to make a supreme sacrifice. She will leave Luis so that he can marry Ninay. Her daughter would then have a bright future as the wife of a rich man. Before marrying her, Luis sends Ninay to a convent for formal training and education. There she befriends Madre Victoria, who showers her with love and affection. After three years, Luis finally marries Ninay. Through a letter, Ninay learns the true identity of Madre Victoria, who turns out to be Tentay, now in the throes of death. Ninay and her husband rush to the convent, where she learns that Madre Victoria’s confessor, Padre Ventura, is her father. The dying nun breathes her last after seeing her daughter for the last time.

In Ang Magmamani, Sauco successfully uses the formula of the popular novel in fulfilling the motto of Liwayway, which is to provide its readers both aral or moral lesson and aliw or pleasure. This novel follows the formula by playing up life’s basic contradictions, then resolving them in a cathartic, generally happy ending with heavily dramatic, sometimes tragic touches, with the heroine living happily ever after with her hero.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Typewriter Altar). Published 2002. Author, Luna Sicat-Cleto. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Madrigal-Gonzalez Best First Book Award, 2004.

Makinilyang Altar is an autobiographical novel which testifies to writers’ devotion to their craft, and the inevitable trade-offs arising from such a commitment. It opens with the main character, writer and university instructor Laya Dimasupil, reflecting on a recurring dream. In it she lives alone in a house and need not socialize—a dream life that differs from her waking life. Longing for solitude, which she can only experience in the house in her dreams, Laya, who is sometimes the narrator, brings the reader to every house she has lived in and all the people she has encountered and lived with: her now deceased father, Deo Dimasupil, himself a writer and university professor; her mother, Gloria Dimasupil, a housewife who used to work as an accountant; her siblings; the househelp; and her relatives. In all these houses, there is one room in particular that always intrigues her: her father’s. It was where he used to isolate himself from his family. This is the same world that Laya dreams of living in, a secluded place that she can call her own, a world of words and of writing.

Deo’s narrative is at the center of the novel. The silence that he demands while he writes is sometimes disrupted by the younger Laya’s inquisitiveness, to which Deo harshly, sometimes violently, reacts. Because of his chain smoking, Deo succumbs to a terminal illness, and after his death, Laya digs into her father’s elusive writings. She comes across her father’s journals, and Laya learns about her father’s world, where fishing and farming provide respite from the struggles between conforming to the policies of the academic community and remaining faithful to one’s literary craft.

The novel’s narrators vary every now and then. There is Gloria’s point of view, which reveals how she gave up her job as an accountant to take care of her family while trying to build a contemplative space of her own. Laya finds herself confronting the same issues that plagued her father and mother as she juggles her time between working in the academic and artistic community, and performing her duties as a wife to her husband Antonio, and mother to her son Hugo.

The novel offers wit and humor with its candid digressions, and its enjoyable, spontaneous, and freely flowing prose, as the reader is provided with rich descriptions of each character. The most interesting passages involve the three main characters’ reveries, which allow the reader to dissect the plotlines, names, and locations that compose the autobiographical elements of the narrative. The nonlinear structure and the use of shifting points of view do not allow for direct encounters among the three main characters; it is rather in their isolated and introspective writings that they find themselves engaged in meaningful conversations.  Written by Jemma Pamintuan

text:
(History) aka Maragtas kon (Historia) sg Pulo nga Panay Kutub sg Iya Una nga Pamuluyo, Tubtub sg Pag-abut sg mga Taga Borneo nga Amo ang Ginhalinan sg mga Bisaya, Kag sg Pag-abut sg mga Kastila (History of the Island of Panay from the First Inhabitants and the Bornean Immigrants from Which the Bisayans Are Descended to the Arrival of the Spaniards). Published 1907. Author, Pedro Monteclaro. Kadapig sg Banwa. Reprinted, Iloilo: Makinaugalingon Press, 1929. Third edition, Manila: Sol Gwekoh, 1957.

Written in 1901 by Monteclaro, who was the first municipal president of Miag-ao, also a local historian and war hero, Maragtas purports to be a record of events that happened sometime in the 13th century, supposedly based on oral and written sources, of which no copy has survived. Its narrative portion first appeared in a document annotated and translated by Fr Tomas Santaren, OSA, in 1858 in Janiuay, Iloilo.

Monteclaro’s document consists of six parts: (1) the life of the Aeta of Aninipay, the old name of Panay; their language and traditions; and the introduction of Marikudo, son of Chief Polpulan; (2) the arrival of the 10 Bornean datus who led a mass migration from Borneo to flee the oppressive rule of Datu Makatunaw of Brunei; and the legendary barter between Marikudo, leader of the Aeta, and Datu Puti, leader of the Bornean datus; (3) the formation of an idealist confederation of Madia-as under the executive authority of Sumakwel, the division of the land, the first crime committed in the new settlement, and Kapinangan’s infidelity to Sumakwel, which puts to the test the latter’s wisdom as leader; (4) the division of the island, now called Madia-as, into districts, each ruled by a datu; (5) customs and traditions that the Bornean migrants brought with them, which are still practiced in Panay today; and (6) the arrival of the Spaniards.

The data for parts 2 and 3 are taken from a 19th-century document that was translated into Spanish by the Augustinian Santaren in 1858. It was then published under the title “Historia de los Primeros Datos Que, Procedentes de Borneo, Poblaron Estas Islas” (History of the First Datus Who, Coming from Borneo, Populated These Islands), as appendix 3 to Igorrotes: Estudio Geografico y Etnografico Sobre Algunos Distritos del Norte de Luzon (Igorots: Geographical and Ethnographic Study of Some Districts of Northern Luzon), 1902, by Augustinian friar Angel Perez.

The Maragtas is easily the most popular subject matter among Ilonggo writers. It has inspired more than half a dozen novels and a number of short stories, poems, and essays.  Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

 

Source

Scott, William Henry. 1984. Prehispanic Source Material for the Study of Philippine History. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

article.value: (History) aka Maragtas kon (Historia) sg Pulo nga Panay Kutub sg Iya Una nga Pamuluyo, Tubtub sg Pag-abut sg mga Taga Borneo nga Amo ang Ginhalinan sg mga Bisaya, Kag sg Pag-abut sg mga Kastila (History of the Island of Panay from the First Inhabitants and the Bornean Immigrants from Which the Bisayans Are Descended to the Arrival of the Spaniards). Published 1907. Author, Pedro Monteclaro. Kadapig sg Banwa. Reprinted, Iloilo: Makinaugalingon Press, 1929. Third edition, Manila: Sol Gwekoh, 1957.

Written in 1901 by Monteclaro, who was the first municipal president of Miag-ao, also a local historian and war hero, Maragtas purports to be a record of events that happened sometime in the 13th century, supposedly based on oral and written sources, of which no copy has survived. Its narrative portion first appeared in a document annotated and translated by Fr Tomas Santaren, OSA, in 1858 in Janiuay, Iloilo.

Monteclaro’s document consists of six parts: (1) the life of the Aeta of Aninipay, the old name of Panay; their language and traditions; and the introduction of Marikudo, son of Chief Polpulan; (2) the arrival of the 10 Bornean datus who led a mass migration from Borneo to flee the oppressive rule of Datu Makatunaw of Brunei; and the legendary barter between Marikudo, leader of the Aeta, and Datu Puti, leader of the Bornean datus; (3) the formation of an idealist confederation of Madia-as under the executive authority of Sumakwel, the division of the land, the first crime committed in the new settlement, and Kapinangan’s infidelity to Sumakwel, which puts to the test the latter’s wisdom as leader; (4) the division of the island, now called Madia-as, into districts, each ruled by a datu; (5) customs and traditions that the Bornean migrants brought with them, which are still practiced in Panay today; and (6) the arrival of the Spaniards.

The data for parts 2 and 3 are taken from a 19th-century document that was translated into Spanish by the Augustinian Santaren in 1858. It was then published under the title “Historia de los Primeros Datos Que, Procedentes de Borneo, Poblaron Estas Islas” (History of the First Datus Who, Coming from Borneo, Populated These Islands), as appendix 3 to Igorrotes: Estudio Geografico y Etnografico Sobre Algunos Distritos del Norte de Luzon (Igorots: Geographical and Ethnographic Study of Some Districts of Northern Luzon), 1902, by Augustinian friar Angel Perez.

The Maragtas is easily the most popular subject matter among Ilonggo writers. It has inspired more than half a dozen novels and a number of short stories, poems, and essays.  Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

text:
Aka Margosatubig: Maragtas ni Salagunting (Margosatubig: History of Salagunting). Published 1946. Author, Ramon Muzones. Serialized in Yuhum, 1946.

Considered the first Ilonggo bestseller, this novel is an exotic blend of history, fantasy, legend, romance, epic, and bildungsroman. The most important Ilonggo writers of the period have praised Margosatubig as a major literary achievement. Fellow Ilonggo writers and critics, such as Emilio Zaldivar, Pura Araneta, and Donato Flor de Liza, have variously described it as a “valuable document on human freedom in the tradition of Rizal’s novels”; “equal to any other classic written now and in the past” or one that “could be equaled but never surpassed”; and “a reminder of the Filipinos’ historic struggle against all enemies, local and foreign, who sought to oppress and impose their unjust rule through criminal conquest from the time of Makatunaw of Bornay to the three centuries of Spanish domination.”

At its barest, Margosatubig is an account of how the waters of Margosatubig, a little town in Zamboanga, turned bitter. Threading through the novel is a plot of political treachery and magic, of a search for a lost kingdom, of a prince’s series of adventures and romantic entanglements, and of the conflict between Christians and Moors. Fantastic elements include a mermaid, a giant bivalve that swallows the prince but spits out his mother, and a woman whose magic power comes from her strand of golden hair.

Datu Mohamed has usurped the throne, forced the king into exile, and thereby caused the king’s death. The king’s son is Salagunting, the hero of the novel, whose struggles to wrest the throne from the usurper are further complicated by other pretenders to the throne. There is also a contest for supremacy between Salagunting and Datu Mohamed’s daughter Morgana, who has the power of black magic. After learning that freedom can be gained only through constant vigilance, Salagunting finally establishes himself beyond doubt as the true sultan of Magindanaw and Sulu.

He acquires the qualities of wisdom, humility, and patience. He thus succeeds in rendering Morgana’s black magic impotent and wins her love thereby.

The novel shows Muzones’s adeptness in language, skill with revelatory dialogue, deft handling of suspense, and insight into human nature. It combines some of Muzones’s favorite themes: that woman is smarter than man, that love conquers all, that society always changes, that right will prevail over might. Evident also in the novel is his penchant for portraying strong women who overwhelm their fallible heroes, and his treatment of the man-woman relationship as one fraught with competition and antagonism.   Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

article_title: Mass for the Death of an Enemy
text:
Published 2000. Author, Renato E. Madrid. Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Set in the historic Valladolid district of the municipality of Carcar, Cebu, Madrid’s second novel returns to the themes found in Devil Wings, 1996, such as the hypocrisy of the clergy and their uneasy relationship with the affluent members of their flock. The events in Mass, however, are set in the American colonial period.

At the center of the novel is the household of Capitan Delfin, the administrative head of Valladolid, a passionate patron of the performing arts and a habitual betel nut chewer. The mysterious murder of Braulio Pantorilla, a lawyer who tricked a younger Delfin into purchasing property that was already owned by a businessman, sends the novel into full swing. Fearful of being found the most likely culprit, Arcadio flees to Manila where he stays with Nyora Candil, an old acquaintance of his father and the grandmother of an up-and-coming musician named Cordillera. One night, Nyora Candil finds the two young men in an embrace while asleep. This prompts her to write Delfin a letter against Arcadio. Once he deems it safe to return home and after hearing that his father is ill, Arcadio returns to Carcar, much to Nyora Candil’s liking.

Cordillera also travels to Carcar after earning his performer’s diploma. He finds himself admiring the church organ and growing fond of Padre Constancio, the self-righteous parish priest. He inadvertently comes into conflict with Arcadio. The two realize that they are courting the same woman, the church maestro’s daughter, Irenea.

Other characters in the novel are Maurice, a serviceman in Delfin’s employ; the presidente, Lemuel Acha; Encarnacion, a once-renowned stage performer whose illness has ruined her voice and pockmarked her face; and Pampila and Rosario, who delight in gossip-mongering.

Mass concludes with a bedridden Delfin talking to a frightened Padre Constancio, whose carriage only moments ago was driven into a river while it was being pursued by Aurelia, an old maid whom many believe to be a witch. Delfin tells the priest that a man must have enemies so as to give him some claim to make on his friends. “I feel, after all I have seen and heard, that death is not the enemy. It is life. And his closest accomplice is love.” This final statement does a fine job of summarizing the web of love and hate that interconnects all the characters of this novel.  Written by Charles Dominic Sanchez

text:
(The Mystery of a Borrowed Heart). Published 2003-4. Author, Gumer M. Rafanan. Serialized in Bisaya, 29 Oct 2003–14 Jan 2004.

This romance novel explores the manifold responses of people in love, a group of wealthy and well-meaning characters driven to yearnings, rather mysteriously, for what money cannot buy.

Told in limited third-person point of view, the story starts with the tragic death of a man driving home to his family on his birthday. Alfredo “Fred” Amante, on 13 Feb, meets a fatal vehicular accident, leaving Helen Amante, his wife, their businesses, including Amante Subdivision, and a heart that could still save a life. Helen agrees to donate the heart to a transplant patient on the condition that the donor’s identity remain anonymous.

The recipient, Dante Villasin, who is heir to the Villasin Enterprises, survives the surgery. But confounded with a feeling of incompleteness about his person, he sets out to meet the family that has given him a new lease on life. He is inexplicably drawn to Helen and her child, Herbert “Boy” Amante, who prefers him to Ramon, his mother’s persistent suitor, also from an influential family.

Having learned each other’s identities, the two fall in love despite Dante’s parents’ wish that he marry Linda, whose untarnished background would do the family business good, Ramon’s disgruntlement at being rebuffed, and Helen’s vow to herself never to marry again. Linda is set to wait for Dante no matter the duration.

The incidental character Chona Sandoval, whom Dante meets when he visits Fred Amante’s grave, reveals the love she harbored secretly for Fred and the guilt she has been living with since his death, as it was she who had urged him to stay on and celebrate his birthday with their friends. His delay caused him to rush on his way home. Ramon schemes to have Boy kidnapped and ransomed for 50 million pesos. Helen, who is clueless about his involvement in the crime, calls him for help and agrees to marry him out of gratitude. Still, she secretly meets with Dante soon after the kidnappers have released her son. The climactic scene has Helen and Dante fighting for their lives against Ramon’s rage.

The characters’ social class makes possible the larger-than-life plot twists and underscores the theme that happiness is more than material abundance, with the transplanted heart as a symbol. True to the tradition of serialized cliffhangers, the novel avoids waxing sentimental by moving at breakneck speed. The novel’s use of everyday Cebuano was an attraction that drew readers to every heart-stopping installment.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

(The Nun). Published 1929. Author, Fausto Galauran. Manila: Limbagan ni P. Sayo. Reprinted, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 1997.

The novel depicts the relationship between two sisters, Naty and Bebang, who belong to a middle-class family in Caloocan. They fall in love with the same man, the handsome Roberto. Naty becomes Roberto’s sweetheart, but when he hears rumors that she is engaged to marry another man, he turns his attention to the older sister who is a widow. At first, Naty is at a loss trying to understand Roberto’s strange behavior, but she eventually finds that he and her sister are already carrying on. Because she is deeply in love with Roberto, she becomes disconsolate and starts to think that life has lost all meaning. She talks to a priest who advises her not to fight for her love, for to do so would only tear her family apart. Believing that the only honorable deed is to give way to ensure her sister’s happiness, Naty decides to enter the convent and become an inviolate bride of Christ. The novel ends with Naty turning her back on the world and seeking solace and peace in the service of God.

The novel was highly acclaimed and enjoyed great commercial success. It went through a second and third edition. A film was made based on Galauran’s story. Its depiction of a nun as a brokenhearted woman who resorts to the veil and the silence of the convent has been a major source of stereotypes revolving around the Filipino religious woman.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 2000. Author, Eric Gamalinda. Quezon City: Philippine Centennial Commission and University of the Philippines Press, with the UP Creative Writing Center. Centennial Literary Prize, first prize for the novel in English, 1998. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 2001.

Eric Gamalinda’s fourth novel takes its title from the first line of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar’s awit (metrical romance) Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1838, which, like Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891, also frames nationalist discourse within a love story. Gamalinda goes further by involving a historical figure in the fictional love triangle, and setting the romance against the backdrop of the Philippines’ bloody transition from Spanish to American colonization. The historical “Pope of Negros,” Dionisio Magbuela, led a Catholic-infused, millenarian revolutionary movement on Negros Island as Papa Isio (Pope Isio), fighting against first Spanish, then American rule; and he continues to be regarded as a folk hero in the Visayas. Gamalinda fictionalizes his life and motives for pursuing revolution, explaining in an afterword that he “found the obscurity of the pope’s life an interesting parallel to the obscurity of the Filipino-American war.”

Gamalinda’s Papa Isio begins as a young folk healer and mystic who comes to the attention of a hacienda matriarch, who introduces him to her ward Asuncion, bastard daughter of a Spaniard and a member of the matriarch’s household. Also interested in Asuncion is Tomas Agustin, mestizo member of the local guardia civil (constabulary) and later a soldier in the Spanish army. Tomas impregnates Asuncion, thereby compelling her to marry him, although she remains in love with Isio, who receives stigmata and realizes his divine revolutionary mission. Asuncion and Isio remain obsessed with each other, even as Tomas’s military career escalates his and Isio’s mutual antagonism. Later, Tomas and Asuncion’s son Felipe attempts to reconcile, in his own way, the contradictory beliefs of his father and his mother’s lover. The love triangle narrative lends itself to an archetypal interpretation in which a hybrid woman/motherland is torn between a hybrid future and a return to the native, but also inadvertently suggests that Isio’s revolutionary mission might have been derailed by requited love, marriage, and hacendero status.

Isio eventually meets and befriends another historical figure, his eventual nemesis, the American general James Francis Smith, briefly military governor of Negros Island. This fictional friendship serves as the dramatic engine for the second half of the novel, predictably complicating Isio’s revolt against American colonization and his eventual capture and sentencing. The novel is markedly sympathetic toward America, as evidenced by its moral, well-intentioned, and rational American characters, and its inclusion of a passage in which Isio is inspired and influenced by the utopian principles expressed in the United States Declaration of Independence, a copy of which he happens to come across. The spiritual, mystical, and emotional Isio can only aspire to such unattainable ideals, echoing his own unrealistic pursuit of Asuncion.

Gamalinda’s prose is in top form here—lush, rhapsodic, and transporting, while remaining precise, felicitous, and concrete. The narrative allows Gamalinda to revel in the erotic and sensual, the occult, and the exotic, all of which he has also treated in his other works of fiction. In its final pages, the novel sidesteps the burden of passing judgment on history, choosing instead to affirm the mystery of existence, the power of storytelling, and the importance of memory.  Written by Vicente Garcia Groyon

text:
(Nena and Neneng) aka Ang Kasaysayan ng Magkaibigang si Nena at si Neneng (The Story of the Friends Nena and Neneng). Published 1903. Author, Valeriano Hernandez-Peña. Serialized in Muling Pagsilang, 1903. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Limbagan ng La Vanguardia and Taliba, 1905, 1911, 1948, 1971; Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co., 1975.

The first Tagalog novel to be published in book form, Nena at Neneng revolves around the friendship between Nena and Neneng, which is put to a test on several occasions. A major threat takes the form of Miguel, Nena’s suitor, whom Neneng considers to be unworthy of her friend’s love. Neneng turns out to be right: Miguel abandons a woman named Chayong after she gives birth to their child. The scoundrel eventually ends up behind bars for all his crimes and dies while serving his sentence. Nena finds happiness in Deogracias, a quiet kindhearted man whom she has known since she was a child back in the old hometown. Nena visits the province and finds that the man has never forgotten her. Neneng falls in love with Narciso, the former sweetheart of the hapless Chayong, and marries him. Isko, a notorious gambler, starts sending Neneng love letters. Narciso becomes insane with jealousy. One day, he sees Isko and Neneng in what he perceives to be a compromising situation. He broods over his wife’s presumed infidelity, and leaves her. Disconsolate, Neneng falls ill. Nena tries to nurse her friend back to health, but too far gone in the sickness that afflicts her soul, Neneng dies, still professing her deep love for her husband. Narciso comes back, also ailing, and is told of Neneng’s death. Realizing the enormity of his unjust act and weakened by his sickness, Narciso collapses and dies. His body is interred in Neneng’s tomb.

This realistic novel was a fresh departure from the customary themes of the awit and korido or metrical romances popular at the turn of the century. It had recognizable characters of ordinary people inhabiting a familiar world, using actually spoken language. Readers could identify with its engrossing themes of love, friendship, betrayal, passion, and tragedy. It also provided writers of the early 20th century a literary model for the fictional interpretation of a society undergoing rapid changes as a result of the new colonial order. An important device used by Hernandez-Peña was simultaneous narrative, which served to highlight the contrasting fates of the characters. The novel’s use of the epistolary style is another device that later novelists would also employ. Through a series of letters exchanged between the main characters, the author makes the narrative move by summing up past events and hinting at future actions. The letters also enable the characters to reveal thoughts and feelings known only to them. The omniscient point of view is employed effectively to disrupt the narrative flow, by way of offering comments on the characters’ actions.

Other than the narrative novelty of its genre at the turn of the century, this novel’s unqualified affirmation of traditional values, with its stress on the avoidance of all forms of excess that could destroy human relationships, constitutes its major contribution to Philippine literature and to generations of writers and readers.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

 

Sources

article.value: (Nena and Neneng) aka Ang Kasaysayan ng Magkaibigang si Nena at si Neneng (The Story of the Friends Nena and Neneng). Published 1903. Author, Valeriano Hernandez-Peña. Serialized in Muling Pagsilang, 1903. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Limbagan ng La Vanguardia and Taliba, 1905, 1911, 1948, 1971; Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co., 1975.

The first Tagalog novel to be published in book form, Nena at Neneng revolves around the friendship between Nena and Neneng, which is put to a test on several occasions. A major threat takes the form of Miguel, Nena’s suitor, whom Neneng considers to be unworthy of her friend’s love. Neneng turns out to be right: Miguel abandons a woman named Chayong after she gives birth to their child. The scoundrel eventually ends up behind bars for all his crimes and dies while serving his sentence. Nena finds happiness in Deogracias, a quiet kindhearted man whom she has known since she was a child back in the old hometown. Nena visits the province and finds that the man has never forgotten her. Neneng falls in love with Narciso, the former sweetheart of the hapless Chayong, and marries him. Isko, a notorious gambler, starts sending Neneng love letters. Narciso becomes insane with jealousy. One day, he sees Isko and Neneng in what he perceives to be a compromising situation. He broods over his wife’s presumed infidelity, and leaves her. Disconsolate, Neneng falls ill. Nena tries to nurse her friend back to health, but too far gone in the sickness that afflicts her soul, Neneng dies, still professing her deep love for her husband. Narciso comes back, also ailing, and is told of Neneng’s death. Realizing the enormity of his unjust act and weakened by his sickness, Narciso collapses and dies. His body is interred in Neneng’s tomb.

This realistic novel was a fresh departure from the customary themes of the awit and korido or metrical romances popular at the turn of the century. It had recognizable characters of ordinary people inhabiting a familiar world, using actually spoken language. Readers could identify with its engrossing themes of love, friendship, betrayal, passion, and tragedy. It also provided writers of the early 20th century a literary model for the fictional interpretation of a society undergoing rapid changes as a result of the new colonial order. An important device used by Hernandez-Peña was simultaneous narrative, which served to highlight the contrasting fates of the characters. The novel’s use of the epistolary style is another device that later novelists would also employ. Through a series of letters exchanged between the main characters, the author makes the narrative move by summing up past events and hinting at future actions. The letters also enable the characters to reveal thoughts and feelings known only to them. The omniscient point of view is employed effectively to disrupt the narrative flow, by way of offering comments on the characters’ actions.

Other than the narrative novelty of its genre at the turn of the century, this novel’s unqualified affirmation of traditional values, with its stress on the avoidance of all forms of excess that could destroy human relationships, constitutes its major contribution to Philippine literature and to generations of writers and readers.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

text:
(Ninay: Philippine Customs). Published 1885. Author, Pedro A. Paterno. Madrid: Imprenta de Fortanet.

The first Filipino novel, it is a romantic melodrama in Spanish. Ninay is Antonina Milo y Buisan, beautiful young daughter of Don Evaristo Milo and Doña Carmen Buisan. A rich heir, Don Carlos Mabagsic, falls in love with Ninay, but a rival suitor comes between them, Don Federico Silveyro, son of a rich Portuguese capitalist.

Ninay’s friend Loleng has a sweetheart, Berto, but Don Juan Silveyro, father of Federico, tries to take Loleng for himself. Loleng flees with Berto to the hills; but, worn-out by the vicissitudes of the wilderness, she dies. While Berto is burying her remains, Carlos comes upon him. Berto swears to avenge the life of Loleng, and he joins the tulisanes or bandits, who plunder the homes of the rich, including Ninay’s parents. Carlos rescues the family. Meanwhile, Don Evaristo becomes the guardian of Pilar, a deceased friend’s daughter. Seeing the growing love between Ninay and Carlos, and being herself interested in Carlos, Pilar schemes to get Federico Silveyro jealous so he will propose marriage to Ninay. Rejected, he vows to avenge himself, using his money and powerful connections to persecute the Milo family. Unable to bear the persecution, the Milos decide to leave for Singapore. Carlos also decides to leave so he can be with Ninay. But Don Evaristo is arrested and imprisoned at Fort Santiago. Carlos disappears and is thought dead, but he has actually drifted to an island whose queen falls in love with him. During an attack by tribal enemies, the queen is killed, but not without having given her wealth over to Carlos. Carlos escapes from the island and tries to find his way home.

Meanwhile, Berto kills Federico. Ninay’s parents die because of the hardships they are made to endure. Pilar flees, leaving Ninay alone in desperation, unaware that Carlos is still alive. She decides to enter the convent. A cholera epidemic hits the city. Carlos arrives, but he promptly gets sick and ends up at the hospital where, by means of a ring Ninay once gave him, they recognize each other. Then Carlos dies. Ninay herself falls ill and dies.

It is Ninay’s funeral with which the novel opens, and her story is told in the framework of an improbable device—the pasiyam or nine nights of novena prayers for the eternal repose of the departed, each night being a convenient time for Taric, the narrator, to relate a chapter of Ninay’s story. This device appears to have been chosen to serve Paterno’s central purpose—to give the readers in peninsular Spain a picture of Filipino types, places, and customs in the mode of costumbrismo. The narrative seems to be a mere third of the book. Another third is taken up by footnotes complete with historical, ethnographic, geographic, and scientific terminologies. Another third is authorial intrusion into the narrative to explain details of native custom and tradition. From the very first page, for example, one learns that the population of Manila was about 400,000 at the time.  Written by Florentino Hornedo
