(Touch Me Not). Published 1887. Author, Jose Rizal. Berlin: Berliner Buchdenckerei Aktiengesellschaff Setzerinner-Schulede, Letter-Verein. English translations, The Social Cancer by Charles Derbyshire, Manila: Philippine Education Company, 1912; The Lost Eden by Leon Ma. Guerrero, New York: Norton Library, 1961; Noli Me Tangere by Jovita Ventura Castro, Quezon City: ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, 1989. Other English translations by Camilo Osias and Priscilla Valencia, among others. Tagalog translations, Noli Me Tangere by Pascual Poblete, Manila Limbagan ng El Mercantil, 1906; and Noli Me Tangere: Huwag Mo Akong Salingin by Patricio Mariano, Manila: IR Morales, 1913; Noli Me Tangere by Antolina T. Antonio and Patricia Melendrez-Cruz, Quezon City: ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, 1991. Other Tagalog translations by Pedro Gatmaitan; Bartolome del Valle and Benigno Zamora; Domingo D. de Guzman, Francisco Laksamana, and Maria Odulio de Guzman; and Ligaya Buenaventura, among others. Also translated into German, French, Chinese, Ilocano, Ilonggo, Cebuano, Kapampangan, and other languages.

Jose Rizal reinterpreted the words of the risen Christ to Mary Magdalene in the gospel of Saint John to refer to the disease in Philippine society that is so virulent that the least touch causes great irritation and pain. In his novel, he proposes to expose the sick, as the ancients did, “on the steps of the temple so that everyone who came to the Divinity might offer them a remedy.”

The plot of the novel revolves around the hopes and the frustrations of a well-intentioned young mestizo, Crisostomo Ibarra. He has just returned from his studies in Europe, the classic example of the ilustrado (educated native) influenced by the Enlightenment ideas of liberalism and reform. After some investigation, he finds out that during his seven-year absence, his prominent father, Don Rafael, quarreled with the powerful Padre Damaso and eventually suffered the ignominy of imprisonment and death at the instigation of the latter. Ibarra controls his bitterness and decides to continue his plan to build, at his own expense, a schoolhouse for his townmates, believing that only education can uplift the indio (Christianized native) from their abject condition. But the friars, especially Padre Salvi, who lusts after Ibarra’s sweetheart, Maria Clara, throw obstacles in his way. At the groundbreaking ceremonies, Ibarra is nearly killed in an “accident” designed by Padre Salvi and his indio accomplices. During the dinner following the ceremonies, the boorish Damaso heaps insults at the memory of Ibarra’s father. Provoked, Ibarra nearly kills Damaso. For that incident, Ibarra is excommunicated and called a filibustero (subversive). His engagement to Maria Clara is called off. A few days later, a mock uprising, contrived by Salvi, erupts but is swiftly crushed. Ibarra is imprisoned as the leader of the plot. He escapes with the help of the enigmatic Elias, whose life he saved during the picnic on the lake. With his good reputation, his hopes, and his sweetheart Maria Clara all lost, Ibarra confronts an uncertain future. The novel ends with the death of Elias, who offers his life so that Ibarra may escape and work for reforms.

An unpublished chapter involves Elias and his sweetheart Salome. Coming from the picnic in which he was nearly killed by a crocodile, Elias meets Salome in her place by a river. The chapter depicts the pitiful conflict between Elias’s love for Salome and his duty to avenge his family’s honor. Salome wants to return to her parents in Mindoro, but Elias decides to stay in San Diego.

The Noli’s plot is not simple and unilinear. In fact, its epic quality derives from the many colorful characters and lives interwoven with those of Ibarra and Maria Clara: Capitan Tiago, Maria Clara’s “father,” who will curry favor with anyone who can advance his business interest; Padre Damaso, Maria Clara’s real father, who loves his daughter as much as he despises anyone who has progressive ideas; Pilosopong Tasio, whose progressive ideas are ridiculed as crazy or subversive; Sisa, who loses her sanity because her son Crispin disappears and Basilio goes into hiding; Elias, whose ancestors were victims of Spanish abuse and who decides to offer his life to effect social change; Doña Victorina and Doña Consolacion, who typify colonial mentality among the rich and the poor respectively; Fray Salvi, whose life is dominated by lust; and a host of other carefully drawn individuals, Spanish, mestizo or indio, upper or lower class, who embody the concerns, foibles, virtues, and humors of colonial Philippine society.

Drawing influences from European writers like Alexandre Dumas, père, Victor Hugo, Eugene Sue, and Benito Perez Galdos, the Noli is the first Philippine realist novel, presenting a vast and vivid panorama of Philippine life in the grip of Spanish ecclesiastical and secular authorities. For creating well-rounded individuals as characters and its as yet unrivalled use of irony, caricature, sarcasm, and black humor, the Noli has been accorded the foremost status in Philippine letters. Rizal’s brand of realism is immediately evident in the Noli’s opening scene, which paints the house of Capitan Tiago in painstaking but telling detail. The same technique is used in the scenes of the fiesta, the building of the schoolhouse, the cockpit, and the church scene during Padre Damaso’s sermon.

Considered with its sequel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891, the Noli’s significance is not only literary but also social and political. As the first searing indictment of friar dominance and oppression in the Philippines in fiction, the novel, originally written in Spanish and published in 2,000 copies, opened the eyes of Filipinos of different regions to their common plight under colonial rule and thus helped to unite Filipinos of many classes and occupations against Spain during the Revolution of 1896.

The novel has influenced and inspired generations of Filipino artists. Juan C. Laya’s His Native Soil, 1941, and Stevan Javellana’s Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, as well as Ang mga Anak ni Sisa (The Children of Sisa), 1931, by Francisco Varona and Ramon Torres, translated by Godofredo Herrera into Filipino from Spanish, were inspired by it. It has been adapted into an opera, Noli Me Tangere, by Felipe Padilla deLeon and Guillermo Tolentino in 1957; into plays such as Kanser (Cancer), 1979, by Jomar Fleras, Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa (The Journey of Sisa), 1977, by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, and Kutsilyo, Pamaypay at Yantok (Knife, Fan and Cane) by Chris Millado and Nicolas Pichay, 1984; into dances such as the Noli Dance Suite, 1955, by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Sisa, a modern dance piece by Corazon Generoso Iñigo; into a film with the same title by Jose Nepomuceno, 1930; Gerardo de Leon, 1961; and into a 13-part television series by Eddie Romero, 1993, for the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Ruby G. Alcantara and Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Nathan’s Sheep). Published 1928. Author, Antonio M. Abad. Manila: La Opinion. Reprinted, with an English translation, La Oveja de Nathan: Una Novela Filipina / Nathan’s Sheep: A Philippine Novel, translated by Lourdes Castrillo Brillantes, with Lilia Ramos de Leon and Edgardo Tiamson, Makati City: Georgina Padilla y Zobel, Filipinas Heritage Library, and Ayala Foundation Inc, 2013.

The novel is the story of Mariano Bontulan, son of a very poor drunkard and gambler. Too poor to support the child, Ta-Titay gives Mariano to Don Miguel Logarta, a fiscal in Cebu, who in turn gives the boy to Don Benito, a government official in Manila. In the city, Mariano obtains the rudiments of education in English and becomes a linotypist at the government printing press. When the war in Europe breaks out, he volunteers to fight in the armed forces of the United States, hoping that by being an excellent and heroic soldier, the United States may be convinced to grant Filipinos their independence. Mariano fights for a year and a half, during which time he wins honors for his courage. Returning to the Philippines, he receives a hero’s welcome. He marries his sweetheart and brings his mother from the province to Manila. He prospers quickly, acquiring a chalet and a car.

But his happy days are numbered. He gets involved in the political turmoil in Manila. First, he is forced to write articles against the granting of Philippine independence in order for him to stay employed. Then, he witnesses the corruption of the American administration and the division among Filipinos. Disgusted at the inequities in the country, he and Jose Baluyot, an old friend at the government printing press, visit Don Benito to hear his opinion on the recent political developments. Don Benito reads them the story about a rich man who slaughters a poor man’s sheep to feed his guest, which the prophet Nathan tells King David in the Old Testament. Don Benito explains the story as an allegory of the situation of the Philippines. The United States, Don Benito says, is the rich man; the Philippines is the lamb taken by the rich man to feed his guest. Later, exasperated by his employer’s anti-Filipinism, Mariano resigns.

The incident becomes a sensation. The printers under the employ of the American presses declare a strike and Doherty, Mariano’s employer, is in danger of total ruin. Mariano himself experiences a financial crisis. His mother falls ill and dies, but a new child is born to him. He gets a new job in a nationalistic press—and he sells his troublesome car. There are signs of growing Filipino unity—the Nationalists and the Democrats have joined a coalition party to work for independence.

 

The novel is a condemnation of American imperialism during the first quarter of the 20th century. It is also a dissertation by a social philosopher upon a great variety of topics, from the “Great War” to the home life of the rich and the poor in Manila and Cebu. His brave criticism of the established regime of the mid-1920s places him in the tradition of Jose Rizal’s social criticism; but unlike Rizal, he sees clearly the potential of the poor laboring class for self-liberation. He is also like his contemporary writers in Tagalog in recognizing and denouncing capitalistic imperialism as guilty of raping the country.  Written by Florentino Hornedo

text:
(Fortune’s Reward). Published 1934. Author, Lorenzo Dilag. Serialized in Kabisay-an, 21 Mar–23 May 1934.

This Ilonggo novel is about the travails of a Negros plantation owner’s son who gains wisdom through sufferings. This theme is interwoven with the author’s insight into Ilonggo society and culture.

After a quarrel with his father, Salvador Garcia runs away from the family mansion in Negros Occidental and fends for himself in Manila. Andres Lunares, a fruit vendor, adopts him. Through Salvador’s intelligence and resourcefulness, Andres’s business thrives. Salvador further adds to his foster family’s income as a professional boxer. He puts himself through college and eventually becomes a newspaper editor. He has a turbulent love affair with Anita, who, despite her attraction to Salvador, belittles him for his apparently humble origins. Salvador then marries Cecilia, Andres’s daughter. A reconciliation with his father takes him back to the family plantation in Negros. Labor unrest, brought about by worldwide recession, causes the accidental shooting of Cecilia. This, followed by the death of another woman who has offered him solace in his widowed state, drives him insane. He and Anita are reunited in Mariveles, where she lovingly nurses him from a most pitiful state to full recovery.

article.value: (Fortune’s Reward). Published 1934. Author, Lorenzo Dilag. Serialized in Kabisay-an, 21 Mar–23 May 1934.
This Ilonggo novel is about the travails of a Negros plantation owner’s son who gains wisdom through sufferings. This theme is interwoven with the author’s insight into Ilonggo society and culture.

After a quarrel with his father, Salvador Garcia runs away from the family mansion in Negros Occidental and fends for himself in Manila. Andres Lunares, a fruit vendor, adopts him. Through Salvador’s intelligence and resourcefulness, Andres’s business thrives. Salvador further adds to his foster family’s income as a professional boxer. He puts himself through college and eventually becomes a newspaper editor. He has a turbulent love affair with Anita, who, despite her attraction to Salvador, belittles him for his apparently humble origins. Salvador then marries Cecilia, Andres’s daughter. A reconciliation with his father takes him back to the family plantation in Negros. Labor unrest, brought about by worldwide recession, causes the accidental shooting of Cecilia. This, followed by the death of another woman who has offered him solace in his widowed state, drives him insane. He and Anita are reunited in Mariveles, where she lovingly nurses him from a most pitiful state to full recovery.

text:
(Magdalena’s Awakening). Published 1958. Authors, Alejandro G. Abadilla and Elpidio P. Kapulong. Manila: Inang Wika Publishing House. Reprinted, with an introduction by Cirilo F. Bautista and an afterword by Efren R. Abueg, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 1988.

Described by various critics as “futuristic” and “erotic,” this novel stirred a storm of controversy when it first appeared. The explicit and graphic description of sex was unprecedented and proved to be “scandalous” for that period, while its political theme of totalitarianism focused attention on the social and political conflicts existing in the Philippines since the Huk rebellion of the 1940s. On top of these, the use of a Christ-figure to symbolize the main protagonist projected religion in a radical interpretation. The novel was written by a tandem of modernist authors; Abadilla was noted for his iconoclastic poetry celebrating individualism and the “sovereignty of the poet,” and Kapulong, for his short stories and powerful prose. Abadilla had read Sigmund Freud, D. H. Lawrence, Alberto Moravia, John Steinbeck, and Henry Miller, and could have been influenced by their works.

The novel is set 20 years into the future, 1980. The Philippines is under the rule of Communism whose leadership is Chinese, personified by Ernesto Pong. He holds office in Manila’s city hall. The local resistance is headed by Dario Lazaro, sporting the nom de guerre Kasamang Rizal. A professor at the University of the Philippines, he believes in a personal code of individual responsibility, sexual freedom, and a social philosophy reminiscent of the “contractarian theory” of civil society for its belief in “self-interest” as the prime mover of human action and collective behavior. Believing in national self-reliance, he cautions his fellow citizens against dependence on external—that is, American—aid in this struggle for liberation. However, he also wholeheartedly welcomes this aid that comes in the form of war material supplied by submarines in Dingalan Bay.

Magdalena or Denang, the female protagonist, is a complex character whose life has been a litany of sin and guilt, rivaling that of her biblical namesake. Sired by a priest, desired, used, and abandoned by a succession of men, she becomes “Komrad” Pong’s spy and his unwilling mistress. She falls in love with Dario, attracted not only to his mind but also to his good looks. He is a sharp contrast to the sinister, because Sinic and leftist, Pong, to whom are attributed the most unpleasant qualities, including his sickly yellow color. Denang abandons Pong and aborts her mission, goes over to the side of the revolutionaries, and escapes with Dario to the mountains. Miss Reyes, a secretary in Pong’s office, and a member of the resistance with the code name Kasamang Liwayway, has been nursing a secret love for Dario. In one fateful meeting with Dario, she bares her feelings, and they begin to carry on an affair. Dario’s failure to fully reciprocate the pent-up passion of Miss Reyes leads her to betray him to the authorities. Playing the Judas archetype, Kasamang Liwayway is overcome with remorse, goes mad, and gets run over by a vehicle after being felled by bullets. The regime arrests many rebels in a dragnet. Dario is executed, and Denang becomes so distraught that she falls into a fevered swoon, during which she has a vision of Dario as Christ appearing to her and promising to return someday, when he has been freed from his Man-God duality. Another character is American Peter Johnston who, despite his being a professor and not a military man, has been dispatched by the US government to liaise with the guerrillas in the Philippines and in the Far East. He serves as an audience, and a sounding board, for Dario’s lectures on his theory of individualism and sexual morality.

The novel reads “futuristic” only insofar as it is projected 20 years ahead of the author’s time. It achieves but a sketchy treatment of a hypothetical alien regime that has implausibly taken over the country by 1980. The work, however, is a convenient vehicle for an exposition of the author’s, particularly Abadilla’s, unconventional ideas on the individual’s place in human society.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

text:
(A Woman’s Faith). Published 1931. Author, Patricio Lataquin. Iloilo: La Panayana.

The novel, which is Lataquin’s most popular, is also typical of his works—slight and sentimental. It contains all the conventions of a romance: a convoluted plot, the vague but instinctive recognition of a long-lost relative and a sense of premonition as foreshadowing devices, coincidences, timely revelations, surprise endings, and long-lost lovers.

Berting’s ambition and foresight are matched only by his passion for women. Before leaving for Manila to earn a degree in education and then law, he pays court to Corazon and Nena, and swears his undying love for Lydia. As a lawyer in Manila, he courts Rosa Maria. Back in Iloilo, his love for Lydia is rekindled after he listens to her sing at a party. They are reunited after he seeks her out and finds her praying in church. Rosa Maria and her father Don Angel are introduced to Lydia, who feels a vague foreboding at the sight of Don Angel. When her mother Tiya Asion meets Don Angel, they fall into each other’s arms as long-lost husband and wife. Moreover, it is revealed that Rosa Maria is Berting’s sister. Hence, the older couple are reunited, Berting and Lydia are married, and Rosa Maria happily finds another man to marry.

Like most of Lataquin’s novels, Pagsalig sang Babai is short. He seems to have written some of the shortest novels, spanning no more than 51 pages each. Like Magdalena Jalandoni, Lataquin deals with the standard subjects of romances: star-crossed lovers, love triangles, and undying love. He was successful in this type of novel because of his easy, readable style and because romance was the dominant influence on Ilonggo literature at that time. This influence extends to this day in the novels of writers like Ismaelita Floro-Luza.   Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

text:
(The Fire Birds). Published 2010. Author, Jesus Balmori. Editor, Isaac Donoso Jimenez. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: Instituto Cervantes.

The significance of this novel derives from the fact that it is the only known novel in Spanish written during and about World War II. It is also Balmori’s last novel. Don Lino Robles is a decadent but rich Filipino hacendero who spends his days supervising his palatial home and overseeing the transformation of his lawn into a Japanese garden. In contrast, his brother Don Ramon Robles is distrustful of the Japanese. Fernando and Natalia Robles are Don Lino’s only children. Marta Gala is Fernando’s fiancé. At the outbreak of the war, no one is really alarmed except Fernando, who enlists in the army. Amid global turbulence, Natalia and Sandoval get married. When the war reaches the Philippines, Fernando postpones his wedding to Marta to join the armed forces in action. The “fire birds” arrive to bomb the cities. When the Japanese reach Don Lino’s hacienda, they confiscate whatever they please. They rape Natalia and kill her. Don Lino is beaten up. Valuables at the local parish church are confiscated. Father Elias, the parish priest, is also taken. Don Lino goes mad and disappears. His corpse is discovered later somewhere on the fringes of the hacienda. On the battlefield, Fernando’s men are decimated, and he himself is wounded and taken to an enemy-camp hospital. Fernando escapes with the help of Pablo, a capataz or overseer of the Robles hacienda. He has fled to the hills and has become a leader of a band of guerrillas. For a while, Fernando joins them, but the disorder and violence soon disappoint him, and he begins to think of Marta. He returns to the mansion to Don Ramon’s delight. But the joy is short-lived. The Americans, advancing after the retreating Japanese, burn and shoot wherever they pass. A bullet accidentally fells Fernando, and Don Ramon is left delirious with grief over the death and horror of war on the one hand, and joy at the arrival of the Americans on the other.

Balmori develops well the themes of this novel, which are about the absurdity of war and violence, and the inanity of victory in war. Using the costumbrista technique, he puts in much description of details of custom and small talk among the social elite. Like in his other novels, Balmori tends to drift into sensuous and sentimental description, but unlike his previous inclination, his practice of inserting poems into his fiction is absent. In their stead are Latin ritual prayers.  Written by Florentino Hornedo

article_title: Para Kay B, O Kung Paano Dinevastate ng Pag-Ibig ang 4 out of 5 sa Atin
text:
(For B, or How Love Devastated 4 Out of 5 of Us). Published 2008. Author, Ricky Lee. Quezon City: Writers Studio Philippines Inc.

As its title suggests, the novel at first reads as if it were about five women, four of whom were ruined by love. Irene has a photographic memory but is unremembered by the man who promised her love when she was very young. Sandra, in love with her own brother, causes him lifelong suffering. Erica, coming from a community where love is unheard of, leaves home for a taste of love, only to realize that she is incapable of loving anyone. Ester, a widow raising a sexually active gay son, finally admits to herself that it is her female house helper and friend whom she has really loved all her life. Finally, there is promiscuous Bessie, who seduces Lucas, the fictional character who is the writer of all these five tales.

The final chapter, however, takes a metafictive turn. The Writer takes part in his own creation and has conflicting visions of the characters that he has created. As the book reaches its climax, the characters confront the Writer, decide their own endings for themselves, and plead for salvation and love—even in its most deceitful guise.

One of the best-known scriptwriters in the Philippines, Ricky Lee is also an important fictionist. His Palanca award-winning stories in the 1970s already anticipated the postmodern narrative in Filipino fiction, where boundaries between genres (fiction and reportage) and between realities (imagined and lived) are often blurred. This novel, his first, is evidence of his facility with postmodernist writing. Readers might first be deceived into thinking that Lee is giving them stereotypical characters and worn-out scenarios, but they realize later that these are elements and devices of the book’s postmodern scheme.

Para Kay B also exhibits Lee’s mastery of contemporary Filipino, perhaps a testament to his experience as creative consultant to many television shows and his exposure to popular texts. It is also a showcase of his skill in creating memorable individuals who live ordinary yet strange lives.  Written by Edgar Calabia Samar

text:
Published 1964. Author, Linda Ty-Casper. Manila: Bookmark.

This historical novel in English is set in mid-18th century Philippines, when the decline of the Spanish central government in the colony has just begun. The novel opens with the arrival of the ships of the galleon trade, ending the long wait by the citizens of Manila. The readers are introduced to the royal fiscal, high priest of intrigue in the colonial bureaucracy, and to the unnamed governor-general and his young loyal aide Santistevan. Nearing the end of his term as governor-general and yearning to make his mark in history, he secretly commissions the building abroad of ships for a navy. He acquires the needed loan-capital from the Chinese merchants and gets additional funds by setting up Don Paco, an indio (Christianized native) merchant, for a loan from the Obras Pias. He feels himself deeply compromised by what he sees as necessary decisions. Meanwhile, a locust plague wipes out the rice harvest, leaving famine in its wake. The air thickens with rebellion and repression. The royal emissary Don Epifanio, a silk merchant, arrives to persuade Manilans to give up the Chinese silk trade for Spanish silk. Together with the royal fiscal, he foments a revolt, planning to heap the blame on the Chinese to cause their deportation. The revolt lasts only for some hours. The leaders are executed before dawn. Among them is Agbayani, son of a Spanish father and an indio mother. For him, rebellion is the sole logic of existence. His friend Santistevan asks the governor for his pardon, but it is denied. In his frustration, Santistevan joins the privateer Segovia on a voyage to pacify the Moros. Making a stopover in Negros, they are trapped by a Moro siege that lasts for days. Santistevan meets Father Licaros, another half-breed, who leads a capable defense of the town. Back in Manila, the ships commissioned by the governor-general arrive, severely battered by typhoons. The royal fiscal takes advantage of the ensuing outcry against the failure and orchestrates demands to change the governor. Meanwhile, the British adventurer Falkener demands a ransom or else, his four ships will attack the city and seize the awaited galleon. The royal fiscal and the archbishop are paralyzed with indecision, until the governor-general sends Santistevan and Licaros to lead in the defense of the city. But under the accumulated weight of deceit, intrigue, greed, and plunder, the colonial structure collapses in the face of the British attack. This is well symbolized in Santistevan’s disintegrating mind, a veritable tour de force of technique toward the novel’s end.

Ranked by Bienvenido Lumbera as one of the five significant Filipino novels written till the 1960s, it filled a need in the Philippine literary tradition for expressing a historical consciousness that seemed sadly lacking in Filipino writers at the time.   Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
(Eclipsed). Published 1907. Author, Faustino Aguilar. Manila: Limbagang Manila Filatelica. Reprinted, with an introduction by Benilda S. Santos, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1986.

A work of realism set in the early years of the 20th century, Pinaglahuan unfolds a tragic story of people in the grip of human passions and social conflicts spawned by colonialism. The novel opens with a fiery meeting at the Opera House where emotional denunciations of American imperialism alternate with cries of approbation from the audience. The principal figures are the lovers Luis Gatbuhay and Eduarda Gutierrez. He is an employee and a courageous labor leader in a business firm owned by the American Mr Kilsberg; she is the daughter of Don Nicanor, an inveterate gambler and religious fanatic. The story’s central focus is class conflict, although love is the leitmotif. This is immediately apparent in the social stations of the lovers.

Deeply in love, both characters realize the difficulty of obliterating their class differences. Eduarda is eventually forced by Don Nicanor to marry Rojalde, a handsome and rich mestizo whom the old man owes a lot of money because of gambling losses. She consents to marry him as payment for her father’s debt. The lovers succeed in spending a night together before their final parting. Luis is taken to prison on trumped-up charges masterminded by Rojalde. The novel ends when a bomb explodes and fatally injures Luis who, with faltering vision, sees a huge fire devouring Manila. As he lies dying, Eduarda is nursing their baby. Rojalde realizes this, at the same time that he sees his own house—a symbol of his wealth and power—threatened by the conflagration.

The novel seems to suggest that only a radical, structural change can transform a society rotten to the core. The author’s vision is dark and pessimistic: an equal fate awaits those who are poor and committed to change, as well as those who rape and pillage the nation’s patrimony. Society is one grand conspiracy against the poor by the elite: Don Nicanor and Rojalde, the ilustrado (educated native), the factory-owning Mr Kilsberg, and the country’s corrupt politicians. But some glimmer of light shines through. Change is possible only if the whole society has been rent asunder. The apocalyptic fire that hits Manila symbolizes this necessary transformation. Luis Gatbuhay, literally meaning “lord of life,” dies but he and his ideals live on through his child who may someday carry on his struggle.

With Pinaglahuan, Aguilar can be classed together with Lope K. Santos, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Roman Reyes, Juan Arsciwals, and other writers who personified the voice of social realism. In his later works, Aguilar would further affirm his position as a leading novelist of the first quarter of the 20th century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

article.value: (Eclipsed). Published 1907. Author, Faustino Aguilar. Manila: Limbagang Manila Filatelica. Reprinted, with an introduction by Benilda S. Santos, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1986.

A work of realism set in the early years of the 20th century, Pinaglahuan unfolds a tragic story of people in the grip of human passions and social conflicts spawned by colonialism. The novel opens with a fiery meeting at the Opera House where emotional denunciations of American imperialism alternate with cries of approbation from the audience. The principal figures are the lovers Luis Gatbuhay and Eduarda Gutierrez. He is an employee and a courageous labor leader in a business firm owned by the American Mr Kilsberg; she is the daughter of Don Nicanor, an inveterate gambler and religious fanatic. The story’s central focus is class conflict, although love is the leitmotif. This is immediately apparent in the social stations of the lovers.

Deeply in love, both characters realize the difficulty of obliterating their class differences. Eduarda is eventually forced by Don Nicanor to marry Rojalde, a handsome and rich mestizo whom the old man owes a lot of money because of gambling losses. She consents to marry him as payment for her father’s debt. The lovers succeed in spending a night together before their final parting. Luis is taken to prison on trumped-up charges masterminded by Rojalde. The novel ends when a bomb explodes and fatally injures Luis who, with faltering vision, sees a huge fire devouring Manila. As he lies dying, Eduarda is nursing their baby. Rojalde realizes this, at the same time that he sees his own house—a symbol of his wealth and power—threatened by the conflagration.

The novel seems to suggest that only a radical, structural change can transform a society rotten to the core. The author’s vision is dark and pessimistic: an equal fate awaits those who are poor and committed to change, as well as those who rape and pillage the nation’s patrimony. Society is one grand conspiracy against the poor by the elite: Don Nicanor and Rojalde, the ilustrado (educated native), the factory-owning Mr Kilsberg, and the country’s corrupt politicians. But some glimmer of light shines through. Change is possible only if the whole society has been rent asunder. The apocalyptic fire that hits Manila symbolizes this necessary transformation. Luis Gatbuhay, literally meaning “lord of life,” dies but he and his ideals live on through his child who may someday carry on his struggle.

With Pinaglahuan, Aguilar can be classed together with Lope K. Santos, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Roman Reyes, Juan Arsciwals, and other writers who personified the voice of social realism. In his later works, Aguilar would further affirm his position as a leading novelist of the first quarter of the 20th century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

(The Pulahan). Published 1919. Author, Nicolas Rafols. Cebu: Patikanan ni Falek.

The novel is a thinly veiled account of actual events in Cebu at the turn of the century. In his preface, Rafols states that he wanted to portray how in Cebu the movement of the pulahan, scattered bands of rebels who wear something red for identification, was sired by the abusive acts of the newly established constabulary. He says that he is a witness to the events narrated in the book, which fact makes the novel a semidocumentary.

Though the war with the Americans has passed, much hostility still persists because of the abuses of the new guardia civil—the Philippine Constabulary. Leon, the novel’s hero, goes to Manila to study. Here, he learns the importance of knowledge as a tool against oppression. When he returns to Cebu, he learns of the abuses of the constabulary and the rape of his girlfriend Siding by an American officer, Captain Peigg. Getting no justice from the military and civil authorities, Leon joins the pulahan. Although he wounds Peigg, Leon is imprisoned along with other captured pulahan. Meanwhile, the province has a new governor who adopts a policy of conciliation and promises the rebels pardon. For nine years, the province prospers and finds peace; but the imprisoned pulahan have not been granted the promised pardon. After serving his term, Leon returns to his hometown and lives peacefully with Siding.

Modeled after the historical sketch, this novel exhibits the empirical impulse, although romantic tendencies are still visible. The romantic strain is at work in the highlighting of the subjective element and the idealization of characters and motives, such as the portrayal of Leon as a blameless martyr.  Written by Resil Mojares

text:
(The Golden Dagger). Published 1933. Author, Antonio Sempio. Manila: Benipayo Press.

The novel revolves around Dalisay, a poor girl who falls in love with Dante, son of rich and arrogant Don Sergio. They get married after the woman discovers she is pregnant by him. Don Sergio causes the marriage to break up. Dalisay finds herself in Lukban where she begins life anew by opening a small business with the help of Elias, a man who falls in love with her. Don Sergio finds out where she and her child live, and orders her place burned down. The child gets sick, and Dalisay begs the old man for help. Don Sergio agrees to help, but at the same time gets her arrested for theft and thrown in prison. There she meets a woman who helps her get a job as the manager of a brothel called “Templo ni Benus” (Temple of Venus). Dalisay encounters Don Sergio again and attempts to poison him, but the old man is saved by Elias. Once again, Dalisay is hailed to court, accused of frustrated murder. While out on bail, she returns to her barrio, gets sick, and loses her sanity. Dante returns from exile only to find out that Dalisay has succumbed to a fatal heart attack. Realizing the gravity of his sins against his daughter-in-law, who did not choose to be born poor, Don Sergio is guilt stricken, but his repentance comes too late.

In contrast to other heroines in Tagalog novels, Dalisay comes out as a woman of strong and resolute character. She refuses the money offered by Don Sergio after he breaks up her marriage, starts her own small business, raises her child all by herself in the total absence of her weak-willed husband, and even attempts to avenge herself on Don Sergio who has unjustly persecuted her. She remains beholden to no one until her lonely, tragic death. In Dalisay, Sempio created one of the most memorable and inspiring heroes in the history of the Tagalog novel.

This work established Sempio as one of the most significant and popular novelists of his generation. Its film version, 1933, directed by Jose Nepomuceno for Malayan Studios and starring Alma Bella and Carlos Padilla, was the first “talking and singing picture” in Philippine film history.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

text:
(Heart without Love). Published 1910. Author, Roman Reyes. Reprinted, with an introduction by Mona Highley, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1990.

The novel draws on actual historical events between the 1890s and the 1900s as the social context in which characters live out a drama of loveless marriage, abandonment, and reconciliation. Enrique is a 19-year-old rake endowed with looks and a glib tongue, and is a compulsive gambler. He survives by sponging off an old couple who has adopted him. Faced with a lawsuit and fearing for his life because of indiscretions, Enrique marries Loleng, a 27-year-old woman whom he does not love, and who marries him out of a sense of filial duty. Enrique gambles away Loleng’s small inheritance. They have a daughter, Elsa, who grows up not knowing her father because the latter has supposedly signed up to join the revolution.

Details from history are liberally woven into the narrative: the outbreak of the revolution in 1896, the bloody encounters between Filipino and Spanish forces, the dislocation of families fleeing the war, and other horrible scenes, such as the bloody massacre that took place in Kakarong, Bulacan. Loleng and Elsa leave their town to escape the raging battles. But the two get separated, and Loleng spends several years searching for her daughter. In the meantime, there are glimpses into the events taking place during the first year of the American occupation. Loleng finally finds Elsa in the house of a kind doctor and his wife, who take pity on the mother and take her in as well. The two women finally have a chance to see the long-lost Enrique for the last time. He has heard of their whereabouts and is on his way to see them when a speeding automobile runs him down. Loleng and Elsa are reunited with the dying Enrique as the novel ends.

Pusong Walang Pag-ibig treats history as a subject matter even as it serves as a social backdrop to a microscopic human drama. History comes out alive in certain scenes which are described in detail, such as the impact of the revolution on the lives of townspeople. The novel freezes for posterity sights and sounds characterizing a specific period in Philippine history. Its depiction of an antihero in the person of Enrique was a bold stroke of realist writing on the part of Reyes.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Highley, Mona P. 1990. Introduction to Pusong Walang Pag-ibig by Roman Reyes, vii-xxvi. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

THE PRETENDERS

TREE

Published 1978. Author, F. Sionil Jose. Manila: Solidaridad Publishing House.

 

MY BROTHER, MY EXECUTIONER

Published 1979. Author, F. Sionil Jose. By the author; Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

 

MASS

Published 1983. Author, F. Sionil Jose. Manila: Solidaridad Publishing House. Translated into Dutch, 1982.

 

POON: A FILIPINO NOVEL

Published 1984. Author, F. Sionil Jose. Manila: Solidaridad Publishing House.

 

The Rosales novels are five novels recounting the saga of the Samsons. It begins in Cabugao, a town in Ilocos Sur, toward the end of the Spanish regime, when the clan name was Salvador. Eustaquio Salvador is an acolyte who receives Spanish- and Latin-book learning. But when the Salvador family suffers humiliations in the hands of the new young friar, Eustaquio’s father kills the friar, and the entire clan is forced to flee. Pursued by the guardia civil (constabulary), they journey through mountain trail, Ilocos seashore, and the Agno River plains. The exodus encounters death, hunger, disease, pillaged villages, and the guardia civil; but they succeed in reaching the promised land in the new town of Rosales. Settling down in Cabugawan, Rosales, Eustaquio marries Dalin. But the Philippine-American War breaks out a year later. The Cripple, a personification of the hero Apolinario Mabini, sends Eustaquio back to Ilocos to take an urgent message to President Aguinaldo. Eustaquio passes by barrios destroyed by the American troops. He himself is tortured and left for dead. He fails to reach Aguinaldo, but he joins the heroic stand of the revolutionaries at Tirad Pass.

In contrast to the peasant Eustaquio’s turbulent and committed life is the lethargic and aimless life of an unnamed landlord’s son. He recalls his childhood in Rosales with his tenant playmates and his love, Teresita. He is largely occupied with thoughts of his father, the right-hand man of Don Asperri, who is the chief landlord. His father is symbolized by the balete tree in their ancestral mansion. The tree is tall and overpowering, but beneath its shade grows nothing. The father is domineering, selfish, and unjust to the tenants and household help. It is through the secondary characters, his victims, that the father is defined. In the end, the father dies violently in a peasant uprising. The moral counterpoint is Baldo, who as land surveyor, gathers evidence of Don Asperri’s land-grabbing. But Baldo fails the peasant’s hopes, and in the end commits suicide. The son’s insights come at the end of a long life, and his realizations are those of one who has been ignorant and uncomprehending.

A generation later, at the time of the Huk rebellion in the 1950s, Luis Samson grows up as a peasant boy with his half-brother Victor. They are raised by their mother and grandfather, both poor tenants. When Luis turns eight, his father Don Vicente Asperri, the biggest landlord in Rosales, claims him as his own son and raises him as sole heir. Social circumstances now completely separate the half-brothers. Luis fashions a liberal outlook in his college education. He is forced by the religious authorities to quit his studies on an issue of insubordination. However, he quickly gets a job as the editor of an avant-garde magazine, which is published by a big industrialist, Dantes. At this point, he seems to be in want of nothing, not of creature comforts nor of romantic interest. Trining, his cousin, and Ester Dantes are devoted to him. Victor, meanwhile, has become a Huk fighter. When he comes one night to recruit Luis, the latter hedges. Victor leaves, walking into the “primeval darkness, thicker than the night.” But Luis cannot go undecided for long. The long simmering feudal conflict breaks out in Rosales, and his barriomates and grandfather are massacred by the military. His mother loses her sanity, and Don Vicente becomes a dying recluse in a mansion that is in a state of permanent siege. A host of military men are placed on guard against the inevitable attack by the Huk rebels led by Victor. Luis obeys when Don Vicente asks him to marry Trining to produce an heir, but he feels compelled to denounce the massacre which has shattered his complacency. He pours all his anger in a magazine exposé. But because of threats by the military, Dantes asks him to resign. Trining gives birth to a deformed baby. Don Vicente dies, and Luis himself dies when the Huks attack the big red stone mansion, signaling the end of the Asperri line.

The third-generation Samson is Antonio. His father has died in prison after joining the rebels in burning the municipal building. Antonio, his sister Betty, and his cousin Emy leave Cabugawan for Manila. Tony obtains a scholarship to Harvard and, in America, has an affair with Carmen Villa, a rich man’s daughter. He is unaware that he had gotten Emy pregnant before he left for America. Emy returns to Cabugawan and there gives birth to a son. When Tony returns to Manila, he is betrothed to Carmen, having gotten her pregnant. He rises from his lower middle-class background to become a professor in the state university, but later, he is persuaded by his father-in-law, Don Manuel Villa, to join the corporation’s public-relations circuit. Toward his erstwhile friends Godo and Charlie, Tony comes to adopt a cynical attitude, criticizing their “idealism.” Yet Tony is uneasy with himself. The unease reaches a turning point. He visits Cabugao in a search for his psychic roots, and comes upon Eustaquio Salvador’s manuscript. The contrast to his life of abandoned ideals shakes him. When he returns to Manila, he learns through Emy’s sister that Emy has borne him a son. He goes to Cabugawan to meet the child. He recalls how Carmen insisted on an abortion and realizes that Carmen has long been unfaithful to him. He leaves her and returns to his sister’s house by the railroad tracks. His suicide leaves Carmen and his father-in-law contrite.

Jose (Pepe) Samson, Tony’s illegitimate son by his cousin Emy, is brought up in Cabugawan by his mother and unmarried aunt, who lovingly and painstakingly sustain him with their earnings as seamstresses. Although not ungrateful, Pepe is embittered by their poverty and his illegitimacy, a resentment that he carries with him when he comes to Manila to study. His lackadaisical attitude takes him from experience to experience. When he is caught up in the student activism of the late 1960s, he is skeptical. But he soon develops friendships with Juan Puneta, a rich man who provides the activists financial support, and Father Jess, who shelters him and his fellow activist Toto. Pepe learns his lessons in the organization, and he becomes an organizer. He falls in love with Betsy, an upper-class activist. His friend Toto is gunned down in a Mendiola demonstration; Pepe is himself arrested and tortured by the military. He discovers Puneta’s villainy and finally decides to go back to Rosales to become a true revolutionary. Written by Victoria S. Calizo, with notes from Lourdes H. Vidal

 

Source

Morales, Alfredo. 1989. F. Sionil Jose and His Fiction: The Filipino Journey to Justice and Nationhood. Quezon City: Vera-Reyes.

text:
(In the Claws of Light). Published 1967-68. Author, Edgardo M. Reyes. Serialized in Liwayway, 13 Nov 1967–15 Jan 1968. Reprinted as a book, Manila: Liwayway Publishing Inc, 1968; with an introduction by Rogelio Mangahas, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 1986. Second edition, Quezon City: C & E Publishing, 2007.

Written by one of the country’s leading social realists, this novel has become a contemporary classic for its dark portrayal of urban life and the dehumanization of the poor and powerless. It was a literary breakthrough of sorts that the novel, with its depressing theme and unconventional writing style—elliptical, terse, and sometimes hallucinatory—could appear in the pages of a conservative magazine like Liwayway. The novel generated much interest not only for its literary style and pessimistic tone, but also for its racial undercurrents. The villain in the story is a Chinese businessman whose name alone, Ah Tek (an allusion to atik, a slang for “money”), resonates with capitalist greed. When the novel was published, the movement for the nationalization of the retail trade, aimed against the longtime Chinese control of small business, was on the rise.

The novel tells the story of Julio Madiaga’s search for his sweetheart Ligaya who has left their barrio for a promised job in Manila. While searching, Julio finds life in the city a constant struggle for survival. He works at a construction site, where he meets all kinds of characters, such as the exploitative foreman, Mr Balajadia, who skims off the meager earnings of the workers; Atong, a close friend who lands in jail and gets killed inside; and Perla, Atong’s sister who is driven to prostitution by poverty. Ligaya is absent for a greater part of the novel and remains a distant goal Julio strives for as he suffers in the city. Finally, he tracks her down to a house in Misericordia where she lives as a mistress of Ah Tek, with whom she has a daughter. Julio succeeds in contacting Ligaya and persuades her to leave Ah Tek. She does not appear at the appointed hour. Pol, one of Julio’s friends, reads an account in the papers of a woman who has died under mysterious circumstances. Julio goes to the funeral parlor and sees Ligaya for the last time in her coffin. Driven to extreme anguish and desperation, Julio storms Ah Tek’s house and stabs the Chinese. Ah Tek’s Filipino hired hands surround him and move in for the kill, avenging their master’s death. The novel’s end underscores the height—or depth—of irony. Julio is killed by his own kind, in the service of a master who has destroyed his only chance for happiness, Ligaya.

text:
(Seasonal Cane Workers). Published 1954-55. Author, Gregorio Sumcad. Serialized in Hiligaynon, 10 Nov 1954–21 Sep 1955.

This Ilonggo novel is written in the socio-realist tradition. Marcial Senero is a law student in Manila when he receives word that his father, a sakada or seasonal cane worker, has died of unknown causes in the sugarcane fields of Negros Occidental. He leaves behind his law studies and a sweetheart, to go home to Tibiao, Antique, and then to Hacienda Dolores, Negros, to find out the circumstances surrounding his father’s death. Now working as a sakada himself, Marcial is appalled at the subhuman conditions of his fellow workers while the Negros capital, Bacolod City, prospers. Slowly he tries to awaken their consciousness to their oppression. In an attempt to placate him, Tiyo Magno, the contratista or labor contractor makes him capataz or overseer. Marcial wins the friendship of the plantation owner’s son Cesar and the heart of Tiyo Magno’s daughter Victoria. However, Victoria is torn between her loyalty to her father and her love for Cesar. Marcial gradually discovers the treachery of Tiyo Magno against the hacendero, Don Fernando, and the anomalies that he commits to enrich himself at the expense of the workers. Tiyo Magno underpays them and then loans at usurious interests the money he has cut from their pay. It is he who undermines the fair treatment that Don Fernando and Cesar wish to accord their workers. Hence, despite Don Fernando’s compliance with social legislation for the workers, he is confounded by the workers’ unrest: a threat to strike, arson in the sugarcane fields, and the deliberate derailment of the cane cars. Tiyo Magno’s attempts to thwart Marcial’s good intentions escalate into violence. Marcial finally unmasks him, and Don Fernando has him arrested.

Like many of the Ilonggo novels in the socio-realist tradition, Sakada faults individuals for inequities in the society but does not call attention to defects in the social structure itself. However, the novel reveals an accurate knowledge of the details of the sakada’s life, such as their migration from Antique to Negros as seasonal workers, the miserable conditions of their living quarters, and their passive feudal attitude toward these conditions. It also expresses a popular notion of the hacienda social structure: that the contratista is the direct exploiter of the sugar workers, that the hacendero’s fault is generally one of benign neglect, and that labor unrest can be quelled by replacing a greedy contratista with a virtuous one.  Written by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava

(Innermost Testimony). Published 1986-87. Author, Juan S. P. Hidalgo. Serialized in Bannawag, 21 Apr 1986–11 May 1987.

Set around the time of the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the novel follows Felipe Lazaro Saleng, who returns to his hometown in Ilocos after receiving a telegram about his mother Luzviminda’s heart attack. There, he renews his ties with his relatives and attempts to rediscover his roots.

Speaking in various guises and using a range of narrative techniques, Felipe proceeds to trace the country’s history within the larger purview of colonialism and neocolonialism. In one sequence, he assumes the character of a videographer who narrates the power struggle in the Ilocos town of Bautista when incumbent local officials are forcibly replaced by the new government’s designated officer-in-charge, Mayor Imperial. In another sequence, he becomes a painter who views two sets of paintings, his own and a Marcos loyalist’s, that depict events in Philippine precolonial, colonial, and contemporary history from an evolutionary perspective.

In another, he is the author-narrator of a Bannawag short story that resurrects characters like Raha Soliman, Andres Malong, Diego Silang, and Prinsesa Urduha as Marcos loyalists actively involved in the movement to bring the dictator back to the country. In another series, he undergoes hypnosis and conjures a dreamlike interpretation of the events of 25 Feb 1986, the final day of the EDSA Revolt. A later sequence contains a letter where he recounts to his brother Primo his other visions while under hypnosis. He realizes that deliverance from the malaise that has been plaguing him needs to come from himself alone. All these sequences simultaneously become part of the novel that Felipe intends to write.

At the core of Saksi ti Kaunggan is a proposed binary between the country’s precolonial condition, on the one hand, and its colonial and postcolonial situation, on the other. At the outset, these are represented by Luzviminda and Felipe, whose name echoes the Spanish monarch after whom the islands were named. As the novel unfolds, it proceeds to criticize the colonial conquests that polluted the supposedly Edenic state of the indigenous Filipino, culminating in the American betrayal of Marcos. Consequently, it posits that the time of Marcos occasioned the country’s return to this pure state, and that a much-needed national renewal is premised on his return to power. The paintings confirm this version of history, which also resembles Marcos’s appropriation of nationalist historiography in his Tadhana textbooks.

Couched in Felipe’s search for his roots, the novel’s narrative is preoccupied with the recovery of the “national soul-body,” predicated on fighting any form of colonial bondage. Using the Ilocano concept of “soul,” the title alludes to the inward direction of this search and the interiority of the sought transformation, which Felipe eventually finds.

In terms of technique, Hidalgo is an innovator who has pioneered in Ilocano literature what has come to be collectively described as “postmodern.” Serialized in 1986, Saksi ti Kaunggan may be the first novel in the Ilocano language to extensively use devices like multiple perspectives, metafiction, and other forms like affidavits, film scripts, and ekphrasis.

For all its formal innovation and philosophical weight, the novel is fundamentally an attempt to rescue the image of a disgraced dictator whose ghost and legacy continue to haunt the nation.  Written by Roderick Galam

Published 2006. Author, Dean Francis Alfar. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 2005.

The novel examines the complicated relationship between Gaudencio, a writer, and Jacinta, a woman whose beauty is so stunning that the walls of her house turn to glass. It is about an artist and his muse incarnate—even when that muse is actually reluctant to play that role.

The first time Gaudencio sets his eyes upon Jacinta, he is immediately infused with the creativity that has eluded him. He begins writing on every piece of paper he can find in the town. He even writes on the walls of his rented home when he runs out of paper. This is a hyperbole, but it examines the process of making art. Gaudencio later marries Jacinta but leaves her behind as his selfishness takes over. He goes back to Manila and begins a literary career the likes of which no one has ever witnessed before. At this juncture, he takes his inspiration from his sexual perversions.

But the novel makes the case that the art born out of the senses is limited, and as the years pass, Gaudencio sees the power of his words decline. He then realizes that his abandonment of his muse was perhaps the reason he was beginning to lose his artistry. Thus, he returns to Palawan in order to get Jacinta back.

The novel teems with elements of magical realism—an acknowledgement of the Filipino people’s capacity to believe in some of the most outrageous events in the world. Jacinta’s house turns to glass the moment her beauty blossoms; a village refuses to have children because the most beautiful creature in the world lived among them; an American teacher teaches no one in an empty classroom; a storm takes away Jacinta’s aunt to the skies; a Vietnamese refugee crosses the South China Sea and into Palawan on a small boat. But even without the magic, Jacinta and Gaudencio discover that something unsaid keeps them together. Gaudencio’s extrication of Jacinta from Palawan to Manila shows them leaving the place of magic and entering the realm of the real.

The novel offers two worlds—the world in which people used to believe in magical occurrences, and the world that refuses to acknowledge the existence of magic. The novel is a lamentation on the disappearance of magic in the modern world. It is also a testament to the power of love as that which we all have and can give freely. In that love lies the capacity to produce magic once more. Fortune and fame follow Gaudencio because of his magical way with words, but it is his quest for love that sends him on the road to redemption. By going back to Jacinta, he might not have recovered his creativity, but he discovers that he wants her love more. This discovery is what saves him.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
Published 2012. Author, Cyan Abad-Jugo. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Salingkit is a coming-of-age story. Kitty Eugenio is 14 turning 15, and she experiences many of the pressures of growing up: mean classmates, unsympathetic adults, and a sense of isolation, even from her friends. Adding to these usual typical adolescent problems, however, is that her father has been missing and her mother decides to live abroad. Kitty feels abandoned even as she comes under the care of her aunt and uncle and their son Alan. Then, she develops feelings for a boy whose family is politically at odds with hers but whose father may help her find her own father.

What adds weight to Salingkit is that it also reflects on social realities. Set in 1986, the novel suggests that the nation’s history folds into Kitty or any other adolescent’s life drama. Kitty’s missing father, the reader realizes, is detained by the military. Bensy, who becomes Kitty’s boyfriend, is the son of a general loyal to Marcos. Alan’s friend Toby is reported killed at a rally at the Batasang Pambansa.

Though the narration itself is straightforward and simple, the novel does not offer a simplistic perspective on the historical events. The Marcos “Loyalists,” like Bensy’s father, are not portrayed one-dimensionally, and the religious discourse adopted by supporters of Corazon Aquino, like Kitty’s aunt Leanna, are gently satirized. Neither does the novel endorse false optimism. The EDSA Revolt, with its euphoria and triumphalism, is depicted early in the novel; the rest of it goes on to the coups and internal contradictions that plagued the Corazon Aquino government.

The ending of the novel is not necessarily a happy one, but it is hopeful. Kitty learns to see beyond her immediate concerns and interests, though these remain real to her. The nation’s story, the novel suggests, can take a similar route: with the idealism of its youth, like Alan and now Kitty, it can weather the uncertainties that lie ahead.

Clearly written for a generation that never witnessed the EDSA Revolt, or that know little of the history behind it, the novel includes an introduction that provides an overview of the events leading up to the revolt and definitions of key terms and concepts like “coup d’etat,” “martial law,” or “recession.” That Kitty is politically uninformed when the novel opens allows the author to bring in information on the major players of the political drama unobtrusively, chiefly through Kitty’s diary entries and her conversations with her activist cousin, Alan.

Abad-Jugo, like Kitty, is a child of the 1980s, and her portrayal of adolescent life in that decade is vivid. The novel is replete with references to cassette tapes, greeting cards, and other things that now are quaint. The author artfully injects British New Wave music, a hit among Filipino middle-class teenagers in the 1980s, into the novel. Kitty is a fan of Depeche Mode, and her friends are followers of Duran Duran and Tears for Fears. The titles of the chapters are taken from the songs of New Wave bands, and ingeniously, lyrics from their songs, quoted intermittently in Kitty’s diary, are made to signify in the Philippine context. Salingkit: A 1986 Diary is an example of how young adult fiction can be made to entertain and educate at the same time.  Written by Jonathan Chua

text:
(A Sacred Oath). Published 1950. Author, Maria Magsano. Dagupan City: Pangasinan Review Press.

This Pangasinan novel dramatizes the conflict between a woman’s claims on her husband and her determination not to get in the way of his success.

Evangeline Lopez, an only child of wealthy landowners from Iloilo, goes to Baguio for a vacation. She meets Rudolfo Villamin, a doctor from Pangasinan. Falling in love with Rudolfo at first sight, she breaks off her engagement with a rich townmate. Rudolfo and Evangeline marry after a whirlwind courtship. Evangeline does not mind that Rudolfo comes from peasant stock, because he has attained the position of director of Sta. Fe General Hospital in Baguio through his intelligence, industry, and driving ambition. However, as Rudolfo’s wife, Evangeline begins to feel neglected because of the patients’ constant claim upon his time and attention.

The objects of Evangeline’s jealousy come to include Rudolfo’s fellow doctors and nurses. She wishes she were a nurse too, so she can be by Rudolfo’s side, helping him in his sacred work. She feels particularly jealous of the head nurse, Miss Benedicto. The jealousy, it turns out, is well founded, for Miss Benedicto is very much in love with Rudolfo and attempts suicide because of this hopeless love. Rudolfo saves her and does not tell Evangeline of this episode.

Rudolfo is tempted to reciprocate Miss Benedicto’s feelings but desists when his and Evangeline’s baby is born. Miss Benedicto assists in the baby’s delivery and stays with the mother and child for a week. She realizes the folly of her intentions and decides to preserve Evangeline’s family by resigning from the hospital.

Although what is directly stated in this novel as the “sacred oath” is that of the medical profession, another sacred oath is also implied—that is, the wedding vows exchanged by the couple. The author’s direct exhortation and the character’s dialogues stress the sanctity of the marriage bond. Ways are outlined and strategies suggested by which the usual pitfalls of marriage can be avoided. Man’s inclination to marital infidelity is analyzed by this novel to be caused by his natural vanity and weakness. A woman’s constant prayers help in preventing man’s fall. A third oath is that of the writer to serve as society’s guiding light.  Written by Rosa Maria Magno

Rudolfo is tempted to reciprocate Miss Benedicto’s feelings but desists when his and Evangeline’s baby is born. Miss Benedicto assists in the baby’s delivery and stays with the mother and child for a week. She realizes the folly of her intentions and decides to preserve Evangeline’s family by resigning from the hospital.

Although what is directly stated in this novel as the “sacred oath” is that of the medical profession, another sacred oath is also implied—that is, the wedding vows exchanged by the couple. The author’s direct exhortation and the character’s dialogues stress the sanctity of the marriage bond. Ways are outlined and strategies suggested by which the usual pitfalls of marriage can be avoided. Man’s inclination to marital infidelity is analyzed by this novel to be caused by his natural vanity and weakness. A woman’s constant prayers help in preventing man’s fall. A third oath is that of the writer to serve as society’s guiding light.  Written by Rosa Maria Magno

text:
(Scentless Sampaguita). Published 1918. Author, Iñigo Ed. Regalado. Manila: Limbagan ni P. Sayo.

Regalado’s novel deals with the moral norms of a society undergoing massive changes under the American sociopolitical order, focusing on the mores and lifestyles of rich and famous Filipino colonials. It revolves around Nenita Deala, the beautiful wife of Bandino Deala, a wealthy businessman, and the events that overwhelm her as she becomes deeply immersed in the activities of Manila’s elite. As the story begins, Nenita is with Paquito, a handsome bachelor who used to be her sweetheart in the past, when he was still a poor man. A misunderstanding had cast them apart, and she later married the rich Bandino. Their love is now rekindled. Nenita finds in Paquito an exciting lover. They become bolder, and carry on their affair right at Nenita’s house. Meanwhile, Bandino himself has been indulging in extramarital affairs. During the famous Manila Carnival where members of high society live it up in sybaritic pleasure, Nenita and Paquito are confronted by Bandino, who has been tipped off by a friend about the illicit affair. Up against the anger of her husband, Nenita breaks down in tears, unable to defend herself against Bandino’s condemnation of her. Gloom descends on the Deala house. Bandino finds himself the laughing stock of his circle for being a cuckold. Nenita becomes an outcast because she has violated a cardinal rule in society. Out of frustration, Bandino tries to shoot himself, and only the timely arrival of his four-year-old daughter brings him back to his senses. The novel ends with Nenita weeping, distraught, on the verge of losing her mind, as the ship carrying Bandino and their daughter leaves Manila’s harbor.

Regalado not only weaves a moving tale of adultery and punishment, but also plays up the social drama that ensues when people like Nenita depart from traditional notions of fidelity and purity. Bandino is, of course, equally guilty of infidelity, but traditional culture puts a heavier onus on the woman to preserve her honor and her husband’s reputation. The novel effectively demonstrates Regalado’s thesis that cultural values derived from the West—such as liberality in human relationships—could be harmful and destructive. This theme is echoed in the other works of Regalado, who was a novelist of manners and a lively chronicler of the lifestyle of Manila’s elite. These he portrayed as the protector of traditional values that he himself believed in. With this and other works, Regalado could lay claim to being the foremost social historian of Manila during the American colonial period.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(The Flower Was Stripped of Its Petals). Published 1915. Author, Jesus Balmori. Manila.

This novel in Spanish is romantic in both subject and style but employs the technique, called costumbrismo, of detailing customs and manners and using indigenous terms for various objects. The novel is divided into three parts. Rafael is an errant husband who shamelessly maintains an illicit affair with his wife’s sister Leonarda. For fear of creating a scandal and for love of Rafael, the wife Dolores suffers in silence while vainly trying to win him back. In the second part, she is resigned to the fact that Rafael loves her no longer. Because of her depression, she succumbs to consumption.

Leonarda becomes engaged to Crisostomo Cristobal. To spite Leonarda, Rafael seduces Rosario Silva. Rafael leaves Manila for his parents’ home in the province. Having lost Dolores, he now realizes how much he loves her. He falls in love with Margarita, a poor farmer’s daughter and a spitting image of Dolores. He resolves to bury the past and to start anew. But when Leonarda invites him to her wedding, he blackmails Leonarda into submitting to him before her honeymoon with Cristobal. The interlude leaves him a cynical man. He returns to the province where Rosario follows him to claim the love he has promised her. He wallows in desolation and becomes sick, until one night, remorseful about what he has done to Dolores, Leonarda, and Rosario, he kills himself near Margarita’s hut. His corpse is discovered the following day. As her father goes to inform the authorities, Margarita grieves over her dead lover’s body.

As in his first novel Bancarrota de Almas (Bankruptcy of Souls), 1910, Balmori explores eroticism and desire. Sensual and scoffing toward religion, Se Deshojo received the ire of the Roman Catholic Church. Balmori apparently drew much from the European Romantic writers, such as Gabriele d’Annunzio and Felipe Trigo. Costumbrismo is evident in the meticulous description of mores and local places like Ermita, and in the use of native terms. The language is rather rhetorical and flowery, betraying the lyric poet in the novelist.  Written by Reynaldo Coronel Jr, with notes from E. S. de Adolfo.

 

Sources

Alinea, Estanislao B. 1964. Historia Analitica de la Literatura Filipino-Hispana. Manila: Imprenta los Filipinos.

Hornedo, Florentino H. 1980. “Notes on the Philippine Novel in Spanish.” Saint Louis University Reserch Journal 11 (Sep): 383-422.

Mariñas, Luis. 1974. Literatura Filipina en Castellano. Madrid: Editorial Nacional.

text:
Published 1954. Author, N. V. M.Gonzalez. Serialized in Weekly Women’s Magazine, 6 Apr–26 Nov 1954. Published as a book, Manila: Benipayo Press, 1956, 1963, 1967.

This is a novel in English about the life of the kainginero or swidden cultivators, in Mindoro island. It depicts their day-to-day life, customs and beliefs, the joys and trials of married life, the economic complications of a barter economy, the exploitation by the rich, the cooperative system of farming and the resulting closeness among members of the community—all these against the backdrop of a harsh environment. The narrative contains only 12 incidents, which take place over a span of one year. The incidents are narrated as they are recalled by the characters Doro and Sabel; hence, there is no adherence to chronological time. Suspense or climax is absent in the novel, for the characters’ conflicts are recurring problems that come with each season of the year.

Sabel and Doro leave Tara-Poro, where the soil is overworked, for the fishing barrio at Alag. When survival here proves just as difficult, they leave again to clear a small parcel of farmland, or kaingin, of their own in the interior. Doro strikes a friendship with Blas Marte, once an independent small farmer, now a sharecropper. Together they clear the kaingin. Then come months of hunger, when the only food available are yuro, mushrooms, and bamboo shoots. Although Doro and Sabel’s marriage is generally stable, quarrels may occasionally erupt. Doro often has one drink too many; Sabel sometimes succumbs to impulse buying, which Doro resents.

Certain elements of nature are used as portents of doom or malevolent symbols: fish, rats, a hawk preying upon the chickens, and the tall dao tree. The indirect depiction of the kainginero’s problems is achieved through symbolism, imagery, and, occasionally, a surrealistic style. Hence, although this is a novel of social concern, social injustice is rendered with neither drama nor authorial comment. A memorable scene is the attack of the rice field by rats, which, as in a nightmare, Sabel sees as “little people” harvesting the rice. Repetition of certain incidents evokes the cyclical quality of the kainginero’s life. The novel begins and ends with Sabel expecting a child during the harvest season. In the beginning, Sabel had to give up four of her six mats to the municipal officials; later it is Clara’s turn. Recurring scenes are Sabel putting her children to sleep with a lullaby; Sabel’s ritual baths after childbirth and after a serious illness; Doro’s jocular moments with Blas Marte while harvesting; and the loss of the chicks.

The novel is written in the same terse and laconic style that is characteristic of Gonzalez’s other novels, The Bamboo Dancers, 1959, and The Winds of April, 1941. But because it is narrated from the kainginero’s point of view, Gonzalez transliterates the idiom and catches the rhythm of the local dialect in the English language. The impoverished quality of the kainginero’s life and their environment is faithfully reflected in the vivid but economic descriptions and the sparseness of the dialogue.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

 

Sources

Galdon, Joseph, SJ, ed. 1979. Essays on the Philippine Novel in English. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Majid, Abdul Bin Nabi Baksh. 1970. “The Filipino Novel in English.” Philippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review 35 (Mar-Jun).

text:
(The Ring of the Marble Maiden). Published ca 1905. Author, Isabelo de los Reyes. In Ang Kapatid ng Bayan. Spanish translation by Isabelo de los Reyes, in El Grito Pueblo, 1905. Tagalog reconstruction, Carlos B. Raimundo, 1912.

What is now known as Ang Singsing nang Dalagang Marmol was a novel written by Isabelo de los Reyes for the newspaper Ang Kapatid ng Bayan. The author later translated the novel in Spanish for El Grito Pueblo in 1905. The loss of the original Tagalog prompted a certain Carlos B. Raimundo to write a Tagalog version of the novel. The frontispiece of the 1912 edition featured the name of Isabelo de los Reyes as the author followed by the novel’s title. A woman’s picture is in the middle of the page with a caption below: “O si Liwayway ng Baliwag” (Or Liwayway of Baliwag), followed by the words, “Mga Nangyari sa Paghihimagsik” (What Transpired during the Revolution).

In this short novel, two themes are explored in such a way that they appear seamlessly woven into the major narrative. The narrative is an engrossing, fast-paced series of movements where love of country is deftly interspersed with love of a woman, a grand motif that can be traced to Francisco Baltazar’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1838.

Colonel Puso is an officer in Emilio Aguinaldo’s army that has been fighting the Americans. When the novel opens, he is wounded and is recounting his story: Colonel Puso first met a woman named Liwayway in Baliwag as he was rallying his forces for an attack. He was instantly smitten with her and called her “ice maiden.” Though apparently indifferent to him, Liwayway gave him a handkerchief and a lock of her hair when he asked for a token that he could bring with him to the battlefield. When he was seriously wounded, he was sent to Baliwag to recover, with Liwayway attending to his needs. In jest, she offered him a gold ring upon which he could vent his frustration for her seeming coldness. Liwayway’s adoptive mother, however, fearful that the officer was not taking Liwayway seriously enough, spirited the young woman away.

This is the story that the grieving officer unfolds as he begs a soldier to look for Liwayway and return the ring to her, as a reminder of her treachery. At this point, the place where the colonel is recuperating is attacked by American soldiers. Colonel Puso drives the soldier away and fights the enemies singlehandedly. He is eventually captured, and his wounds treated by a kindly American officer.

The soldier finds refuge in the house of an old woman, Aling Edeng. The old woman’s curiosity is aroused when she sees the ring on the soldier’s finger. She tells him that she is the mother of the colonel and asks the soldier to help her locate her son. They find the colonel in a hospital in Manila, and in a dramatic scene, Aling Edeng reveals her true identity as Liwayway.

The ill-fated lovers are finally joined in matrimony by a priest from the Philippine Independent Church founded by Fr Gregorio Aglipay. The Americans, earlier constructed as the Filipinos’ enemies, emerge as purveyors of progress in the colonized country. Colonel Puso is assimilated into the new system when he is appointed governor of the province of Kabulaklakan.

The significance of this novel derives not solely from its wealth of historical details or from its masterful depiction of the traditional “dalagang Pilipina,” or Filipino maiden, who was lovely, modest, and gracious but who did not easily succumb to honeyed words of suitors. The novel owes its importance to the fact that it was written by Isabelo de los Reyes, 1864-1938. De los Reyes’s place in Philippine history is as a revolutionary against Spain, an influential writer and founder of the newspaper El Ilocano, and as founder of the Union Obrera Democratica, 1902, and with Gregorio Aglipay, the Aglipayan Church, the last the result of the growing nationalism and an anti-imperialistic thrust directed against the ruling Catholic Church.

Isabelo de los Reyes lived through the experiences he depicts in the novel and witnessed both the destructive and the benevolent faces of American colonialism. It is this contradiction that shapes the novel, a timely one for its original readers, who were still reeling from the disastrous effects of Spanish colonization but who were faced with another colonial order.  Written by Soledad Reyes
