text:
(Noemi’s Ring). Published 2005. Author, Gremer Chan Reyes. Serialized in Bisaya, 16 Feb–13 Jul 2005.

The novel begins in Bogo City, Cebu, shortly after World War II. On his way to work, Maximo “Max” Tirana encounters Noemi Molina, a woman he met during the war. When Noemi confronts Max about a ring she has given him, they are both overcome with emotion. This meeting between old friends leads to a flashback on how Max and Noemi fell in love and how their engagement was disrupted by Max’s imprisonment in a Japanese garrison.

It is 1942. Max arrives in Hilantagaan, a remote island in Cebu that seems to have been insulated from the war. He goes fishing with Titi Pantik, his uncle, and Mano Minoy, a friend of his father’s. They sell their catch in markets in Lambusan, San Remegio.

One day, Max meets Noemi, a young woman who has just arrived from Cadiz. Her family had to leave after Japanese forces had captured their hometown. Though not from the same social class, Max and Noemi develop a strong bond. Consumed by his feelings for Noemi, Max dreams of the legendary couple Bantogan and Bathalumay, whose deeds made possible the creation of Hilantagaan. He recites poetry while sailing in the Visayan Sea. When he returns to Lambusan, Max breaks off his engagement with Inday, a woman he grew up with, and he and Noemi become lovers.

Max earns the respect of Noemi’s father and his friends when he joins them for a nightcap where they debate, among other things, the virtues and faults of Americans and Japanese colonizers. Before Titi Pantik asks for Mr Molina’s permission to marry Max and Noemi, he engages Mr Molina in a discussion of whether America would eventually sell the country to Japan.

Before Max leaves the island to seek his own parents’ permission, Noemi gives him a diamond ring, a symbol of their promised reunion.

In Lambusan, Max’s parents reluctantly give their blessing, surprised that their son is marrying a woman they do not know. On the way to the market to sell dried fish, Max and his friend Trining are apprehended by a Japanese soldier. After learning that Max is from Lambusan, a stronghold of Filipino guerrilla fighters, and seeing that he still carries Philippine currency, the soldier takes him to a Kempeitai prison, where he is beaten up and repeatedly questioned. In prison, Max meets Watanabe, a sympathetic soldier who urges him not to give up. Moved by Watanabe’s kindness, Max gives him Noemi’s ring, believing that he is about to die.

Charges against Max are dropped. He returns to Lambusan, gaunt and sick with typhus. He falls ill and suffers temporary memory loss. When the Japanese surrender after the bombing of Nagasaki and Hiroshima, Max marries a woman from Bogo.

The novel returns to Max and Noemi’s meeting after the war. Max tells Noemi that he has a three-year-old son and that his wife died during childbirth. Noemi informs Max that she is returning to Hilantagaan to write about the island’s history for her thesis. In the end, Max introduces Noemi to his son as his mother who has finally returned to them.

In this novel about initiation, love, and survival, Gremer Chan Reyes does away with scenes of violence and terror which proliferate in typical war novels. He uses instead the elements of the serialized romance to show a coastal community that persistently clung to a way of life even under threat of invasion. Rife with historical and anthropological details, this novel provides an account of an important period and milieu for a new generation of readers.  Written by John Bengan

After learning that Max is from Lambusan, a stronghold of Filipino guerrilla fighters, and seeing that he still carries Philippine currency, the soldier takes him to a Kempeitai prison, where he is beaten up and repeatedly questioned. In prison, Max meets Watanabe, a sympathetic soldier who urges him not to give up. Moved by Watanabe’s kindness, Max gives him Noemi’s ring, believing that he is about to die.

Charges against Max are dropped. He returns to Lambusan, gaunt and sick with typhus. He falls ill and suffers temporary memory loss. When the Japanese surrender after the bombing of Nagasaki and Hiroshima, Max marries a woman from Bogo.

The novel returns to Max and Noemi’s meeting after the war. Max tells Noemi that he has a three-year-old son and that his wife died during childbirth. Noemi informs Max that she is returning to Hilantagaan to write about the island’s history for her thesis. In the end, Max introduces Noemi to his son as his mother who has finally returned to them.

In this novel about initiation, love, and survival, Gremer Chan Reyes does away with scenes of violence and terror which proliferate in typical war novels. He uses instead the elements of the serialized romance to show a coastal community that persistently clung to a way of life even under threat of invasion. Rife with historical and anthropological details, this novel provides an account of an important period and milieu for a new generation of readers.  Written by John Bengan

text:
Published 2003. Author, Vicente Garcia Groyon. Manila: De La Salle University Press. Second edition, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2011. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 2002.

The novel’s basic plot is a rescue mission that Negros plantation owner Margie Jarabas Torrecarrion calls on her son Rafael to undertake. George, Margie’s loony husband and therefore Rafael’s father, has been holed up with a worker’s daughter in the abandoned manor of Hacienda Dimas for the past three months. It is the only kind of reason that would make Rafael, now living in Manila, break his resolve never to set foot on Negros ever again. He dutifully returns to Negros, drives to the hacienda located a few hours from the city, and takes his father back in an ambulance.

Rafael’s return to Bacolod triggers an explosion of reminiscences, authorial flashbacks, plot detours, mini biographies of bizarre characters, and cameo appearances of eccentric types with familiar names identified with the Negros elite, such as Cuaycong, Lizares, Jalbuena, and Lopez.

The structure of the novel consists of interlinked stories rather than chapters conventionally connected by cause-and-effect, with the portrayal of place and its people serving as the unifying device. We get vivid, if brief, stories of Jarabases and Torrecarrions sprouting either directly or tangentially from the family tree. Then there is a parade of characters illustrating the cross section of Negrense society: bored hacendero wives, deferential and diffident workers, Margie’s half-brother who is the fruit of an illicit union between her father and a lavandera (washerwoman), and the loquacious family driver.

Sky over Dimas includes an elaborate backstory in the form of a memoir-within-a-memoir. It is a mythified history that could be a virtual novel in itself and, recounted as it is in fragments, creates shifts in style and scene which are jagged. The memoir-within-a-memoir device points to Groyon’s proclivity toward the breezy, realistic style and not that of the mythmaker or the historical fictionist. However, the novel is written in consistently flawless and elegant prose and the comedy is often knockabout, sometimes sly, certainly always engaging.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Published 2002. Author, F. H. Batacan. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Expanded edition, New York: Soho Press, 2015. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1999; Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 2003; Madrigal-Gonzalez Best First Book Award, 2003.

The novel follows two Jesuit sleuths, Fr Gus Saenz and Fr Jerome Lucero, as they solve a series of gruesome murders in Payatas. On the first Saturday of every month, a boy is found in the dumpsite with his face and genitals removed. Although police reports claim that the murders are unconnected, the priests deduce that they are the work of only one man, and they quickly muster their tools, contacts, and expertise to find him before another first Saturday passes by.

For the most part, the novel is a straightforward narrative with occasional perspective shifts between characters, and abundant forensic details to enhance the realism of the plot. The main difference between Batacan’s work and traditional detective novels is the inclusion of the killer’s private thoughts in between certain chapters. These come in short, intense passages that get more and more chaotic as the novel progresses and as the priests come closer and closer to discovering his identity.

Batacan’s novel explores the complex issues concerning crime in Philippine society. The novel chastises the state of Philippine criminology for its lack of data, equipment, training, and professionalism, epitomized by the deceitful and uncooperative Benjamin Arcinas. At the same time, by including the killer’s thoughts and focusing on criminal profiling, the novel emphasizes, albeit a bit simplistically, the social, psychological, and economic factors that lead to criminality.

Smaller and Smaller Circles has been recognized as one of the first Filipino procedural crime novels and a successful bridge between the popular and the literary. Throughout the novel, Batacan uses short paragraphs to maintain the relentless rhythm necessary for crime fiction. The novel is fast paced and engaging, and a literal page-turner from cover to cover.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
Published 2008. Author, Jose Y. Dalisay. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Shortlisted for the Man Asian Literary Prize, 2007.

The very first chapter of the novel describes in great detail what the woman in the box underwent before her body was sent home to the Philippines. This chapter signals what the reader can expect from the rest of the novel, which depicts the country’s gritty realities. The sometimes step-by-step descriptions of the processes that people undergo just to retrieve a dead body is labyrinthine and often ends in confusion—a recurring theme in the novel.

The novel begins in the complicated systems in place at the capital and shifts to the more complex relationships that people in the provinces have to navigate in order to get what they want or what they need. The primary plot belongs to Aurora and how she has to go to Metro Manila to retrieve her sister’s body. A policeman tasked to give her the notice must also accompany her. They then embark on a road trip, which is the narrative form that will fill out the details of their lives while providing a running commentary about the state of affairs in contemporary Philippines. But the complications Aurora and the policeman go through in their provincial town are nothing compared to the jungle that is Manila. The sequence of events is arranged to show that the complexities in a small town like Paez is simply a symptom of the disease. As one gets closer to the center, the world becomes more difficult and confusing.

The woman in the box, who is the problem that initiates the plot, weaves in and out of the narrative and, though dead, the shadow she casts over the other characters’ lives looms large. Her story is given in small snippets. The readers are given glimpses of her life as an overseas contract worker (OCW) and the actions that led to her eventual death. By the end of novel, the plot steadily devolves into a comedy of errors. The body goes missing, the thief gets his just desserts, and the mystery behind the death remains unresolved like many of the mysteries in this country.

There are minor characters who pepper the landscape of the novel. Some of them even include the usual stereotypes of Philippine society: the martyred OCW, corrupt policemen, lazy security guards, the self-righteous thief, the world-weary policeman looking for redemption, the lecherous vice mayor. These are the realities that Filipinos have to face every day.

The novel offers several statements about the state of the Philippines. A rather easy task like retrieving one’s deceased sister and transporting it to her hometown becomes a complicated matter because of the complicated state of the country. Filipinos leave their families behind in search of better fortunes and end up in even more dangerous environments. Even when the OCWs are not around, their influence upon the lives of those they have left behind remains strong, and often dictates how their lives are led. The novel is very much like the country and people it aims to represent: quirky, complicated, and annoyingly confusing.

Finally, an impressive aspect of this novel is how the author manages to talk about the grimy things in society in beautiful prose.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
Published 1988. Author, Ninotchka Rosca. New York: W.W. Norton and Co.; Manila: National Book Store, 1988.

The novel begins with a festival on the island of K—. Three friends, Anna Villaverde, Eliza Hansen, and Adrian Banyaga make their way to the island. Anna is a survivor of political detention and torture. Eliza is the daughter of a famous Manila courtesan and lover of Anna’s torturer, the sadistic Colonel Urbano Amor. Adrian is the grandson of the country’s richest man and heir to the Banyaga fortune. Anna and Eliza are best friends; Adrian and Anna are lovers. All three, it is later revealed, are the descendants of a Capuchin friar. In the midst of the festival, a revolution is being planned; a bomb is planted under the stage where important political figures are to make their appearance during one of the festival’s shows. Eliza herself is planning to murder her lover, Colonel Amor, in order to avenge her best friend’s torture.

The novel then moves back in time to the late 1800s. A Capuchin friar takes Maya, his cook’s wife, as his own “wife.” Maya has seven sons by the friar, six of whom roam the world. Carlos Lucas de Villaverde, the seventh, sets up a distillery with the help of his partner, a German chemist. Soon after, Carlos Lucas marries Mayang, the daughter of his mother’s maid. Mayang bears three children: two daughters by Carlos Lucas and a son, Luis Carlos, by her lover, the German chemist. When the German chemist leaves the country and takes the name Chris Hansen, Mayang devotes her life to her son. During the Philippine Revolution of 1896, Luis Carlos decides to join the revolutionaries; Mayang follows him to the hills. When Luis Carlos returns to Manila after the war, he finds that all the Villaverde property has been bought by Andres Banyaga. Luis Carlos marries a young Chinese woman from Hong Kong; their only child is Anna Villaverde.

The novel returns to the festival where the uprising erupts. The bomb explodes. Adrian becomes an invalid. Eliza is killed, and the fisherfolk of the island make wind chimes out of her bones. Anna takes refuge in the hills where she gives birth and raises her son, Ismael Villaverde Banyaga.

Rosca, in State of War, represents 400 years of Philippine colonial history, which she depicts as the source of the Filipinos’ lack of a sense of identity. This is symbolized in the major characters’ having mixed racial roots and in their being in a perpetual state of war against foreigners and against themselves. State of War uses magic realism. The novel is peppered with dreams, curses, and predictions that come true; people who appear and disappear; and fabulous characters like Maya, a faith healer and intercessor who, for a fee, forces the saints to grant supplications by whipping their statues.  Written by Maria Trinidad Pineda

text:
Published 1999. Author, Antonio Enriquez. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Mindanao is usually identified with the Muslims. As Antonio Enriquez’s historical novel shows, however, among the often forgotten people of Mindanao are the Subanon, who have suffered horrific atrocities.

The novel is divided into three parts. In the first, Datu Amado Bualan, the last living king of the Subanon, has to confront the problems wrought by martial law. The first scene of the novel foreshadows the fate of the Subanon. One of Datu Amado’s men is being tortured by the military on the mere suspicion that he is a spy for the New People’s Army. The datu’s stature is no longer enough to secure him the captive’s freedom, and he begs for the man’s release. That night, the Communist rebels attack the Subanon village. They kill all the dogs in retaliation for the Subanon’s defaulting on the so-called revolutionary tax.

Datu Amado finds himself and his people trapped between the proverbial rock and a hard place. He tries to find a middle ground even as his people abandon the once-proud village, but ultimately the Communists put him on trial for being an enemy of the people. With his death, dies, too, the last vestige of royalty and political influence of the Subanon.

The second and third parts of the novel deal with the “zoning” operations of the military. Though originally conceived as a way of relocating people caught in the war zone to a safer place, “zoning” has become a means for the military to label everyone a Communist. To make matters worse, the local officials, who harbor deep hatred for the Bualan clan, accuse their political and business enemies of being members of the Communist Party. What ensues is the near extermination of the Bualan clan, signified by the death of the town’s vice mayor.

The novel is a microcosm of the national experience under military rule. The sufferings of the Subanon reflect the consequences of allowing the military to rule the land, including massive corruption and oppression, the eradication of entire communities, and the disruption of the family unit.

In the final scene, the Subanon shaman retrieves the slain vice mayor’s body, which the soldiers have left in the village plaza to rot as a warning to those who would stand against them, and carries it up to the mountains to give it a proper burial. The stench dissipates, but it has already seeped into the very wood of the houses—symbolic of the persistence of corruption and oppression even with the lifting of martial law.

The supernatural way by which the shaman retrieves the body is a counterpoint to the grim realism of the novel. The scene suggests that, by forgetting who they once were, the Subanon are almost exterminated; but, as the shaman’s act shows, if they are aware of who they are, then they, their culture, and their beliefs may yet survive.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(Super Winner Sounds!). Published 2011. Author, Lourd de Veyra. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

The novel follows the rise and fall of the country’s most prominent rock and roll bands. The author takes all the stereotypes found in the rock and roll music scene—the drugs, the poverty, the political activism, the corruption of the music industry, the desire for artistic purity—and blends them all in a cacophonous novel strung together by musical metaphors and running commentaries on Philippine society.

The novel explores the lives and times of the members of the rock and roll band Super Panalo Sounds! and their endless struggle to rise to the top of the music scene through the creation of a musical style that no one else could come up with. There are misadventures, given the clashing personalities of the band members, and their predilection for shabu—a drug that keeps its users awake and allows them to be creative, or that simply dulls the pain of their successive failures. As the characters are stereotypes, character development is hardly at the center of the novel, but, for those who are knowledgeable in the politics of the music industry and the lives of the actual musicians, this novel is a dark mirror to the state of music in this country. Even the legendary Pepe Smith makes a cameo, and in him, one can foresee the fate that will befall the more prominent members of the struggling band.

The author employs various storytelling schemes. While the main narrative is in the third person, he jumps to second-person drug-addled stream-of-consciousness sections, first-person reflections, and even short music reviews—perhaps a testament to the many dimensions of music. The author also makes gleeful use of musical metaphors in shaping the narrative of the novel. It begins with the assertion that the saxophone is the saddest instrument, and how it stands for the loneliness that most musicians undergo as they attempt to break through the glass ceiling without compromising their integrity.

There is a scene with a National Artist who has to make ends meet by playing the piano in a seedy bar. This is in contrast to the well-kept, mascara-wearing musicians who manage to land record deals and who win the adulation of the masses. Thus, the saxophone metaphor not only speaks of the melancholy that engulfs these musicians but also the bitterness that comes with being rejected. It thus becomes a polemic about the nature of art—another dark mirror to the broken lives of many of this world’s artists.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(The Star at Panghulo). Published 1913. Author, Patricio Mariano. Manila: Imprenta at Litograpya ni Juan Fajardo. Reprinted, Manila: Aliwan, 1947; Manila: R. Martinez, 1972.

The narrative unfolds a series of narratives set in the 1870s until the early years of the American colonial regime. Like other Tagalog novels written at that time, it has, on the surface, love between members of opposite social classes as its theme, complicated by interrelated subplots, a gallery of characters, and long poetic passages describing the beauty of the countryside.

Berta, a 16-year-old vendor of native cakes and pickles in Panghulo, meets and develops feelings for Luciano, a dashing man-about-town who lives in a well-furnished room in a house in Sta. Cruz. She feels jealous of Lucia, Luciano’s former sweetheart, now married to Tinong, a wicked man and an inveterate gambler. In fact, when Lucia pleads with Luciano to take her back, he refuses.

While Luciano and Tinong are out hunting, the villainous Tinong shoots Luciano, because he mistakenly thinks that Ineng, the woman he fancies, has fallen for Luciano. Berta hears the shot and comes to Luciano’s aid. As he convalesces in her hut, the reader is then made privy to the contents of a diary that Sinay, Berta’s mother, has left her daughter. When she was young, Sinay fell in love with her childhood friend, Pedro. Because he could not lay claim to great wealth, Kapitang Lino disapproved of him. That notwithstanding, Sinay eventually got pregnant, but her father had managed to have Pedro arrested. With her lover gone and with little prospect of changing her father’s mind, she ran away from her house and found refuge with Sula, who took care of her and her daughter.

When Berta leaves for Manila to get Luciano his clothes and money, she meets Mang Pedro, Luciano’s landlord. Things come to a head when Mang Pedro discovers that Berta is his child and that she has not only inherited some money and jewelry from Sinay but has also become the sole heir to the great fortune he has amassed. Luciano demurs from pursuing his love for Berta, fearing that he would be accused of loving her for her money, but with Mang Pedro’s intervention the lovers surmount all obstacles.

Years later, the newspaper runs an article about a prostitute killed by her estranged husband who has discovered her perfidy. The couple turn out to be Lucia and Tinong.

Mariano, a well-known labor leader whose other novels directly dealt with labor problems, wrote a love story shaped by his own awareness of the way in which class difference could determine the course of love. Lovers must suffer, as countless Tagalog novels insisted, because the world of the rich differed from the world of the downtrodden. Defending herself from Mang Pedro’s niece who is also in love with Luciano, Berta celebrates the self-sacrificing love of her kind against the shallowness and selfishness of the woman from the city.

The novel is notable for its strategic use of concrete historical moments—the aftermath of the 1872 execution of the martyrs of Cavite and the coming of the American colonizers in Manila in the 1900s—to demonstrate how history shapes destiny. Mang Pedro, accused of a crime he did not commit, is exiled with his countrymen who have risen in revolt, and for this reason, he is separated from Sinay and his daughter. Lucia represents the numerous Filipino women who turned to prostitution, with Filipinos and American soldiers as their clients, in a city that was witnessing the proliferation of cabarets. Luciano, the free spirit and sophisticate, a man of the world and an aesthete, is a representation of the emerging affluent Filipino in the first two decades of American rule.  Written by Soledad Reyes

(Old Basio Macunat). Published 1885. Author, Fr Miguel Lucio Bustamante.

This collection of narratives was aimed at attacking progressive ideas and instilling in the indio or colonized native not only a sense of inferiority but also an acceptance of their condition in the order of things—that is, acquiescence in and contentment within the colonial system. The writing of this pamphlet may have been intended to prevent or counteract the spread of liberal ideas among the people.

Bustamante assumes a condescending attitude toward the native’s intellectual capabilities. The narratives in Tandang Basio Macunat are rendered by various fictitious persons, who serve as the conduit for the friar’s thinking. An unnamed general narrator is presented as making a decision to visit various rural places outside the city of Manila. In the course of his peregrinations, the narrator meets an old farmer named Gervasio Macunat. Macunat literally means “wizened,” “grown tough and resilient with age,” and figuratively means “stingy,” “not liberal,” and “miserly.” The farmer recounts to the narrator his early life, which had been dominated by two authority figures: the native teacher who proved to be an effective educator, despite the fact that he had not bothered at all to go to the city for enlightenment, and his peasant father who had demanded complete obedience of him. While largely uneducated, for there are limits to what the indio peasant is allowed to learn, old man Basio considers himself a simple man leading a simple contented life, not having absorbed strange ideas coming from the city.

The narrator then introduces another story, this time revolving around a cabeza named Andres Baticot, his wife Maria Dimaniuala (literally, “incredulous”), and their children Pili and Proper. Meanwhile, Basio’s father has assumed the role of first-person narrator, who continually intrudes upon this chronicle, interjecting, commenting, posing questions, assuming an omniscient stance. Andres has decided to send his son to Manila for studies, over the hearty objections of Proper’s sister, Pili. The parish priest has an explanation for Andres’s dream of sending Proper to school: this is a form of arrogance, for he simply wishes to show off that he has the money to support his son. The priest further claims that because he has little intelligence, Proper will not prosper in the city, but instead will fall victim to wickedness which is rampant in that place. Baticot eventually sends Proper to Manila, where Proper soon wallows in a life of vice, progressively dissipating until he uses up the wealth of Andres and Maria, who become paupers.

The thesis begins to take shape: education, or the yearning for it, can only bring the young indio to grief, and is not suitable for him. In the guise of presenting socioeconomic realities faced by the colonial subjects in their pursuit of knowledge, the narrator of the stories builds around the theme that seeking in the city what is forbidden to be learned in the outbacks can only be rewarded with disillusionment. Proper must be punished for his desire to go to the city to learn: he is destroyed, and he dies without being forgiven.

This prose narrative was roundly criticized by several critics generations apart. Jose Rizal adverted to Bustamante’s thesis several times in his own writings; and decrying its obscurantist purpose, savaged its quality as a piece of clerical propaganda. Marcelo H. del Pilar also attacked the piece and retorted with his own works exposing the abuses of the clergy. Teodoro Agoncillo would later dwell on what he considered the work’s central theme: the denigration of the indio in order to create the myth of native inferiority.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Aka La Teresa: Dialogo cun Pagpolong-polong sa Usa ca Familia cun Banay sa Maong Ginicanan, nga Nagatudlo sa Daghanan nga Catungdanan nga Uala Maila sa Daghanan nga mga Bisayang Cristianos (La Teresa: Dialogue or Conversation of One Family or Brood of the Same Parents, That Teaches the Many Duties Which Are Not Known by Many Visayan Christians). Published 1852. Author, Antonio Ubeda de la Santisima Trinidad. Manila: Imprenta de los Amigos del Pais. Reprinted, Cebu: Imprenta del Seminario de San Carlos, 1906.

The first edition of La Teresa was anonymously published. It was so popular among Visayan readers that it is considered to have achieved marvelous results in the matter of Christian teaching. The novel is set in Bohol, where Ubeda was a missionary from 1831 to 1867, and uses the frame of a dialogue to inculcate lessons in Christian conduct, such as proper behavior in church and at home, intra-family relations, the evils of superstition, and—of special interest—the Christian view of usury. The dialogue is framed by a simple “plot” situation: the visit of Uncle Juan to his hometown in Bohol after years of being away in Manila, and his meeting with relatives and imparting to them Christian lessons he learned from his saintly wife, Teresa, who never makes an appearance in the narrative. A minimal plot provides the frame for the exercise in the pedagogy, which is the book’s main motive.

La Teresa is of interest principally for historical reasons, unintended documentary value, and demonstration of the use of Cebuano as a medium for a long prose narrative.   Written by Resil Mojares

 

Sources

Mojares, Resil B. 1975. Cebuano Literature: A Survey and Bio- Bibliography. Cebu: San Carlos Publications.

Sadaba del Carmen, Francisco. 1906. Catalogo de los Religiosos Agustinos Recoletos de la Provincia de San Nicolas de Tolentino de Filipinas. Madrid: Imprenta del Asilo de Huerfanos del Sagrado Corazon de Jesus.

(Freeman/Serf). Published 1953. Author, Agustin C. Fabian aka Angel Fernandez. Manila: Liwayway Publishing. Reprinted, with an introduction by Liwayway A. Arceo, Manila: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1990.

This was the first Tagalog novel of Fabian, who had started out as a writer in English. It is the story of Andres Talon, son of a timawa or serf in a Philippine barrio. The word “timawa” has ambiguous connotations. In precolonial society, it referred to vassals who rendered service to an overlord by paying feudal dues in the form of agricultural labor. But they were neither serfs nor slaves since they enjoyed a measure of freedom. In Fabian’s novel, the stigma of his lowly social class forces Andres to leave for the United States. He works at odd jobs and eventually makes it to medical school. His unhappy childhood experiences drive him to excel in everything he sets his mind on. Hardened, he deals with two fellow Filipino students in a very businesslike manner. He demands payment from both Alfred, a rich Filipino medical student, and Estela, the daughter of a rich family, for everything he does for them. This exploitation leads to arguments between him and Alice, an American girl who loves him, and between him and Bill, another classmate in school. Neither seems to understand why Andres is so rude and opportunistic in his dealings with rich Filipinos. World War II breaks out, and Andres enlists as a member of the US medical corps. He proves himself a capable surgeon and risks his life to save soldiers. He returns to the Philippines as a much-decorated major of the US Army. His American friends do not know this, believing he has died in an explosion. Andres returns to the barrio. His prestige confers on him a privileged status, even in the house of the rich woman who used to call him and his father timawa. Alice decides to devote her life to helping Andres’s fellow citizens. She builds a hospital with the money Andres left in trust. The two separated lovers finally meet after a series of complicated events, which include Andres’s being afflicted with amnesia and ending up for treatment in the hospital built by Alice. The novel ends with Andres regaining his memory. His many deeds of generosity are revealed to those who have been benefited by him.

What makes this novel different from other stories about characters returning to exact revenge and instead turning out to be redeemers is the complex characterization Fabian gives to his protagonist. He is not the sentimental, weeping hero nor the arch villain common in Tagalog fiction, but a complicated person who has a will to succeed, an obsessiveness that makes him ruthless, and a tremendous ability to constantly examine himself in terms of changing situations. Andres Talon was the first in a series of protagonists that Fabian would create who would depart from the usual mold of heroes, by being confident, self-reliant, ironic, witty, tempered, but in the end, committed to give themselves to others.  Written by Soledad Reyes

Published 1963. Author, Edilberto K. Tiempo. Serialized in Weekly Women’s Magazine, 23 Nov–8 Mar 1963. Published as a book, Quezon City: New Day Publishers, 1972. Chapters 6, 11, 12, and 13 originally appeared as individual short stories with the following titles: “Omnia Tempus Habent,” “The Election,” “Daughters of Time,” and “ToBeFree.”

Chronicled in To Be Free is the life of the ilustrado (educated native) Alcantara family, beginning with Capitan Lucas and his sons, Hilarion and Lamberto. The time span runs from 1892 to the 1950s, with shifts in locale from Nueva Vizcaya to Manila. The theme of freedom runs like a thread in the novel, as can be seen in the Filipinos’ struggle for independence during the Spanish, American, and Japanese regimes. There is also economic imperialism, foisted by Japan’s Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere during the war and by the United States.

Another form of freedom—or non-freedom—that the novel dissects is the tradition of servitude in a Gaddang society. This servitude can also mirror the other form of servitude in Philippine society: that of women. But the novel provides ruptures that show the subtheme of change and impermanence, even of long-held traditions. Freedom also limns the choices made by the characters. Hilarion becomes an ivory-tower philosopher; Lamberto, a flexible realist. Lamberto’s freedom is the freedom to act and to face the consequences of his actions, whereas Hilarion’s is the freedom to abide by such abstractions as principle and integrity. Thus, To Be Free seems to say that freedom is paradoxically the “submission of the self.”

Tiempo describes the characters in rigorous detail. The character of Lamberto is one of the most fully fleshed out in contemporary Philippine fiction. Competence in language prevails in this work. Particularly powerful is the jungle scene, with its mythic resonances. The writing turns evocative when the old Lamberto joins the guerrillas in the Sierra Madre, even as he lapses into dreaming about the past, because he is already too old to carry a gun. Acidic wit flickers in the aside on Tamayo, the Japanese puppet governor: “His stomach was larger than his chest and he looked like an indulgent seahorse.”  Written by Danton Remoto

[TRESE SERIES]

 

MURDER ON BALETE DRIVE

Published 2008. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.

 

UNREPORTED MURDERS

Published 2008. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.

 

MASS MURDERS

Published 2009. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics. National Book Award for graphic literature, 2010.

 

LAST SEEN AFTER MIDNIGHT

Published 2011. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics. National Book Award for graphic literature, 2012.

 

MIDNIGHT TRIBUNAL

 

Published 2012. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.

 

In Alexandra Trese’s Metro Manila, the aswang and the manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) are syndicates often involved in turf wars; the tigbalang (half-human half-horse creatures) are owners of real estate conglomerates; the dwende (gnomes or trolls) are data gatherers in the national archives; the santelmo (dancing ball of fire) can be summoned by dialing the date of the great Binondo fire. And Alexandra Trese is in charge of keeping this underworld and its troubles from spilling over into the human world.

This is an alternate version of Metro Manila, a place both familiar and strange. Here, a small band of heroes is fighting the symptoms but are not quite sure of where the heart of darkness lies. In these five volumes, Tan and Baldisimo have created a world complete with its own rules and characters, yet is so much in sync with the world we live in.

Murder on Balete Drive, Unreported Murders, and Last Seen after Midnight are episodic in structure. Trese and her allies, the Kambal, are called upon by the police to investigate and solve strange cases in the city. The episodic nature of these volumes helps introduce the reader to the dark world Trese inhabits, and lays out the parameters by which this world works. There are engaging touches of local color: the dwende love chocnut, the Mercury Drug symbol can be used for healing, morgues are routinely visited by the aswang for their feeding.

Trese relies on the skills that she learned from her ancestors to solve these crimes. There are times, though, when even her skills and her knowledge are not enough to bring about justice for the victimized. In some cases, Trese has had to punish those who have broken her law even when they were seeking righteous justice. The world created by Tan and Baldisimo is a dark reflection of our world. These supernatural beings represent the many denizens of the capital city’s underworld—the corrupt politicians, the gang lords, the smugglers, the dirty cops—and we find them all entwined with the monsters.

Two standout stories in these three volumes are “Our Secret Constellation” in Murder on Balete Drive and “Fight of the Year” in Last Seen after Midnight. In “Our Secret Constellation,” Tan and Baldisimo pay tribute to Mars Ravelo’s classic creation, Darna. The story shows how even one of our enduring legends can be broken by an increasingly corrupt world, and how even her quest for justice has to give way to Trese’s own code. It is a bittersweet story about how the city can crush the dreams of even the simplest people, and how strong family ties are what keep us together.

“Fight of the Year” mythologizes the country’s premier boxer—Manny Pacquiao. The story is set in General Santos City, not Manila, and the Pacquiao-like character is revealed to be a hero who for one night fights 12 different monsters all in an effort to keep his city safe.

Mass Murders is an origin story. The episodes collected in this issue shed light upon Trese’s initiation into the otherworld depicted in the series. It also gives the backstory of the mysterious Kambal—the children of Talagbusao—the native god of war. This is a myth-heavy story that manages to find its anchor in the realities of Metro Manila.

Midnight Tribunal introduces Trese’s most dangerous foe yet and promises a story arch that could encompass several future volumes. It appropriates the story of Captain Barbel, another of Mars Ravelo’s creations. In the story, Trese has to hunt down the heirs of Captain Barbel’s powers as they have turned into vigilantes and wrecking havoc all across the capital city. article.value: [TRESE SERIES]
MURDER ON BALETE DRIVE
Published 2008. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.
UNREPORTED MURDERS
Published 2008. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.
MASS MURDERS
Published 2009. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics. National Book Award for graphic literature, 2010.
LAST SEEN AFTER MIDNIGHT
Published 2011. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics. National Book Award for graphic literature, 2012.
MIDNIGHT TRIBUNAL
Published 2012. Author, Budjette Tan; illustrator, Kajo Baldisimo. Pasay: Visual Print Enterprises and Alamat Comics.

In Alexandra Trese’s Metro Manila, the aswang and the manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) are syndicates often involved in turf wars; the tigbalang (half-human half-horse creatures) are owners of real estate conglomerates; the dwende (gnomes or trolls) are data gatherers in the national archives; the santelmo (dancing ball of fire) can be summoned by dialing the date of the great Binondo fire. And Alexandra Trese is in charge of keeping this underworld and its troubles from spilling over into the human world.

This is an alternate version of Metro Manila, a place both familiar and strange. Here, a small band of heroes is fighting the symptoms but are not quite sure of where the heart of darkness lies. In these five volumes, Tan and Baldisimo have created a world complete with its own rules and characters, yet is so much in sync with the world we live in.

Murder on Balete Drive, Unreported Murders, and Last Seen after Midnight are episodic in structure. Trese and her allies, the Kambal, are called upon by the police to investigate and solve strange cases in the city. The episodic nature of these volumes helps introduce the reader to the dark world Trese inhabits, and lays out the parameters by which this world works. There are engaging touches of local color: the dwende love chocnut, the Mercury Drug symbol can be used for healing, morgues are routinely visited by the aswang for their feeding.

Trese relies on the skills that she learned from her ancestors to solve these crimes. There are times, though, when even her skills and her knowledge are not enough to bring about justice for the victimized. In some cases, Trese has had to punish those who have broken her law even when they were seeking righteous justice. The world created by Tan and Baldisimo is a dark reflection of our world. These supernatural beings represent the many denizens of the capital city’s underworld—the corrupt politicians, the gang lords, the smugglers, the dirty cops—and we find them all entwined with the monsters.

Two standout stories in these three volumes are “Our Secret Constellation” in Murder on Balete Drive and “Fight of the Year” in Last Seen after Midnight. In “Our Secret Constellation,” Tan and Baldisimo pay tribute to Mars Ravelo’s classic creation, Darna. The story shows how even one of our enduring legends can be broken by an increasingly corrupt world, and how even her quest for justice has to give way to Trese’s own code. It is a bittersweet story about how the city can crush the dreams of even the simplest people, and how strong family ties are what keep us together.

“Fight of the Year” mythologizes the country’s premier boxer—Manny Pacquiao. The story is set in General Santos City, not Manila, and the Pacquiao-like character is revealed to be a hero who for one night fights 12 different monsters all in an effort to keep his city safe.

Mass Murders is an origin story. The episodes collected in this issue shed light upon Trese’s initiation into the otherworld depicted in the series. It also gives the backstory of the mysterious Kambal—the children of Talagbusao—the native god of war. This is a myth-heavy story that manages to find its anchor in the realities of Metro Manila.

Midnight Tribunal introduces Trese’s most dangerous foe yet and promises a story arch that could encompass several future volumes. It appropriates the story of Captain Barbel, another of Mars Ravelo’s creations. In the story, Trese has to hunt down the heirs of Captain Barbel’s powers as they have turned into vigilantes and wrecking havoc all across the capital city. In the end, it is not Trese who solves the problem, but the mysterious Madame—an Imelda Marcos-like figure—who manipulates the tigbalang into taking action into their own hands. Most important of all, it gets the reader to look more closely at the people, places, objects, and events in the capital city, because as Trese consistently suggests, everything (and consequently, everyone) in this city, is not what it seems.   Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Ang Tundo Man May Langit Din
text:
(Tundo Has a Heaven Too). Published 1959-60. Author, Andres Cristobal Cruz. Serialized in Liwayway, 22 Jun 1959–16 May 1960. Reprinted as a book, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1986.

This novel is set in Tundo (or Tondo), an area in Manila which has had a reputation for being a place of crime and neighborhood violence, grime, and poverty, where people are afflicted with vices and live a life of desperation. Tundo has produced a virtual culture of its own, much of it portrayed as being the underworld variety. The literary and social stereotypes about Tundo have painted a very negative image of it, even among those who live there. The novel of Cruz succeeds in endowing Tundo with a certain humanity, and makes the place alive with purposeful human activity that is worth saving.

It is as savior of his benighted place that the novel’s protagonist perceives himself. Victor del Mundo, literally meaning “the world’s champion,” is a working student in one of Manila’s universities. He decides to take up a course in history, which he believes will come in handy when he starts a teaching career in Tundo. Nothing escapes the critical eye of Victor—not the miserable state of education in the country, the various degrees of corruption wreaking havoc on society, the unreliability of the law, nor the widening gap between the rich and the poor. He sees and feels deeply for the plight of Tundo’s impoverished and unemployed. He deplores the stench, the ignorance, the outbreaks of violence, the manipulative ways of politicians, and their petty ward leaders.

All these are interwoven into a narrative that revolves around human relationships—between Victor and Alma Fuertes, a rich girl who has learned to love him; between Victor, his brother Lucas, and their mother; and between Victor and Flor, a girl from Tundo who tries to escape a bleak future and ends up with a married man. Victor meets various kinds of Tundo people, whose dreams and struggles lead him to conclude that even in this living hell, a kind of heaven is still possible. The novel ends with the simple marriage rites uniting Victor and Alma. They face an uncertain future with courage and dedication as teachers of Torres High School.

The novel is significant for the panoramic view it presents of contemporary Philippine society, which is the whole context against which the characters move and interact. Realistic details reconstruct a world that is familiar to many readers: Manila in the postwar years. Using realist techniques, the author depicts with deep compassion a world he fully knows, having grown up there himself.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1992. Author, Ninotchka Rosca. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. American Book Award, 1993.

Twice Blessed explores and critiques the backdoor mechanisms of power and personality that permeate Philippine politics. It follows the rise to power of incestuous twins Hector Basbas and Katerina Basbas Gloriosa, a rise that teeters between consolidation and collapse when Hector’s victory at an election is challenged by the incumbent president.

Rosca’s novel constructs politics and government as the playgrounds of the rich. Neither side of the presidential race espouses a platform or an ideology, a fact that is not acknowledged as a lack, since no one even bothers to think about it. The sole routes to victory are showmanship, the orchestration of images, and many backdoor dealings with businessmen, military, religious sects, and other politicians. The masses are merely objects to be controlled and manipulated, and only once in the novel—in the brief appearance of Aurelio Aureus—are they ever given an actual human face.

Much of these themes are emphasized by the extensive use of 20th-century political and presidential mythology. Twice Blessed deliberately fashions major plot elements out of key moments in Philippine politics, such as the plane crash of Magsaysay and the Jabidah massacre. Sudden and inexplicable occurrences in the novel—occurrences that might otherwise seem outlandish, insufficiently developed, or crudely ex machina—are given verisimilitude because they echo real moments in Philippine history. These events are not reconstructed accurately or even chronologically but are instead twisted into new forms to critique Philippine politics. For example, a crucial mutiny of marines in the novel that clearly alludes to the 1986 coup is presented as the machination of an ex-captain to ensure the Basbas team’s control.

The novel suggests that this system is perpetuated by both those within the system and those outside of it. The Philippine elite is portrayed as insular, superficial, and oppressive, especially to those whom they do not see as being one of them. It is significant, therefore, that the main characters are all in some sense outsiders: Hector and Teresa are orphans; Teresa is ugly, dark-skinned, and female; Armand, Katerina’s legal husband, belongs to a clan disgraced, at least before his politically opportune marriage. It is this exile status that fuels the twin’s desire for power. It is power alone, they believe, that will bring about both security for themselves and the ruin of those who hurt them. Ironically, then, their hatred for the system fuels their desire to head it, a condition which then leads to their becoming the epitome of the system they hate.

There are, however, a few instances in the novel when the characters glimpse a way out of this cycle. These are brief and quiet moments that are quickly subsumed by the demands of the campaign and power. Nevertheless, they provide Twice Blessed with its greatest emotional depths. Because the novel is written in a primarily satirical, tongue-in-cheek, and magical realist style, its rhetorical impact is strongest in its brief and hopeful silences: in the doubts of Katerina and the letters of Aurelio, in the climactic meeting between Hector and Blackie Dominguez. While the twins still give way in the end to the baroque reality of politics and power, the intensity of their original yearning remains, suppressed but unmistakable, haunting the reader well beyond the work.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
(Slave to Promise). Published 2006. Author, Elaine Grace Lape. Serialized in Bisaya, 8 Nov 2006–24 Jan 2007

This novel is set in Asturias, a coastal town in Cebu. Zam Yñigo teaches martial arts. One day, a young writer named Onina arrives and asks that he train her.

At first, Zam refuses, but Onina persists, engaging Zam in philosophical discussions about gender politics, the nature of fear, and the Romantic poet Byron. Eventually, they reach an agreement: Zam will train Onina; in return, Onina will teach him how to write poetry.

Onina and Zam appear to have an unconventional romantic relationship, but the novel shifts gears, gradually revealing that Onina has vowed to avenge herself on a man she has long been searching for.

During their lessons, Zen and Onina reveal more about themselves to each other. His eldest daughter who died 13 years ago would be as old as Onina. Onina dropped out of school and her mother worked as a domestic helper.

One day, Onina asks Zam to shave her head bald. At first, Zam refuses, but when he finds Onina naked by the seashore, he reluctantly obliges. Zam does not realize that he is taking part in a ritual that will lead to his entrapment. Neither does he see that through his martial arts lessons, he is training Onina to fight him.

During a drinking session with some of his students, a tipsy Zam regales the group with the story of his womanizing “friend” named Jeremiah. Jeremiah, he recounts, had gotten a woman pregnant and then shirked all responsibility. At a shopping mall years later, he chanced upon the woman and the daughter he had spurned, a little girl covered in sores.

In the novel’s climactic scene, Onina steals Zam’s samurai sword and squares off with him on the beach. Zam proves too strong, retrieves the weapon, and cuts off Onina’s left hand, the hand she uses to write. His victory is short-lived, however, when he learns Onina’s true identity.

In this work, Lape turns the serialized novel on its head. She presents a rare figure in contemporary Cebuano fiction: a complex heroine who asserts her position in the house built by a smug and negligent father. In a genre dominated by male writers, Lape finds her rightful place.  Written by John Bengan

text:
(Urbana and Feliza) aka Pag Susulatan ng Dalauang Binibini na si Urbana at ni Feliza na Nagtuturo nang Mabuting Kaugalian (Letters between Two Maidens Urbana and Feliza, Which Teach Good Conduct). Published 1864. Author, Fr Modestode Castro. Reprinted, Manila: J. Martinez, 1907; edited by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Quezon City: Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, University of the Philippines Press, and National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 1996. Translated into Bikol, Ilocano, and other languages.

This slim volume is a conduct book, because it teaches good manners and correct social behavior. During the Spanish period, conduct books were popular reading material, together with works written primarily for religious instruction, such as catechism, novenas, spiritual exercises, and sermons. The book is written in epistolary style, an exchange of letters among the characters, who become the channels for the author’s discourse on Christian virtues a person must possess to be considered exemplary and upright.

The book was dedicated to Filipino young men and women, to equip them with a knowledge of proper social decorum. In his introduction (here rendered in English translation) the author declares that action, manner, and speech must not offend God and people: “knowing this rule is the jewel of a young girl, an honor and an ornament to a young man—a beauty and loveliness that, with good manners, constitute twin virtues that captivate the heart.”

The author’s ideas are expressed through a fictitious Tagalog family in Paombong, Bulacan, made up of a father a mother, and their children named Urbana, Feliza, and Honesto. The names are symbolic. “Urbana” suggests urbane, characteristic of one who is refined and polished in rearing and in manners. “Feliza” suggests a happy and tractable disposition. Honesto is described as an upright, honest, and God-fearing boy. The moralistic teachings are contained in 34 letters. Twenty-three are written by Urbana to her sister Feliza, and six by Feliza to Urbana. One letter is from Urbana to her mother, in which is enclosed a letter from a priest advising mothers how to safeguard the purity of their daughters who are of courting age. There are also letters written by a priest to newlyweds Feliza and Amadeo (a name suggesting a “God-loving” quality). The letter-within-a-letter device is resorted to by the author to provide some relief from the monotony of the exchanges.

The author prescribes conduct under three categories: toward oneself, toward God, and toward others. In some letters, Urbana advises Feliza to teach Honesto habits of cleanliness and neatness, poise and dignity in his bearing, decency in his speech, and moderation in his clothes. Other letters prescribe correct behavior in church, in the homes of other people, in school, in conversations, at social gatherings, at meals, and at places of entertainment. Drunkenness is condemned. There is priestly advice on how to choose one’s life partner, the duties of husband and wife to each other, and how children should be raised and helped in finding their vocation. The last two letters describe a happy and peaceful Christian death and teach us how to accept death, how to mourn for the dead, and how to behave when visiting a family in mourning. Politics and public service are not overlooked. A letter comments (here in English translation) that “public office is like a crown which is not given except to the one who is worthy of it, so it should not be sought but refused, if one cannot do honor to it.” Similar aphoristic statements are made regarding other topics such as friendship: “A friend serves and comes to the assistance of the other in time of need and emergency … is known in prison, in sickness, and in death … friendship is a delightful golden chain that binds two hearts, but it is difficult to find, for it is a precious chain.”

Urbana at Feliza is perhaps the most significant prose work of the Spanish colonial period, based on its own literary merits, as well as on its later influence. Fr Modesto de Castro, according to Epifanio de los Santos, best represented classical Tagalog prose of the 19th century. Although this work was written as a conduct book, it is also considered the precursor of the Tagalog novel, because it uses a fictional narrative device.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

 

Sources

Alejandro, Rufino, and Juliana C. Pineda. (1948) 1950. Ang Ating Panitikan. Manila: Bookman.

Mojares, Resil B. 1983. Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel: A Generic Study of the Novel until 1940. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

article_title: La Vida Secreta de Daniel Espea
text:
(The Secret Life of Daniel Espeña). Published 1960. Author, Antonio M. Abad. Manila: Phoenix Press.

This last novel of Abad is a medieval morality tale dressed in 20th-century narrative garments. David Evangelista is a hardened criminal, wanted by the law for a variety of crimes. To deceive the agents of the law, he changes his name to Daniel Espeña. As Daniel Espeña, he is a hacendero, with a pious wife, Eleuteria (Teria) Mangabut, and a son, Miguel. Miguel wants to be a priest, but Daniel objects. Only after a foreboding nightmare does he concede to his son’s wish. Daniel is a changed man after the nightmare. He becomes pious and generous. Later, his wife dies of cholera, and he himself dies of a stroke. Miguel abandons the seminary to administer his father’s wealth. Eventually, he marries Luisa de Guzman and has four children: Claudio, Teresa, Mariano, and Silvia.

Each of the children undergoes tragic experiences, the consequences of which Doña Luisa bears. Claudio (Caloy) is a libertine who fathers illegitimate children. He starts to change only after a series of mishaps, including the loss of his business. A flood destroys his house and ends his life. Doña Luisa is left to look after his children. Teresa marries Sisenando de los Santos, a seemingly respectable man, who in truth already has a wife. He leaves Teresa penniless and humiliated. She breaks down emotionally, contracts typhoid fever, recovers, but loses her mind; then, she succumbs to meningitis. Once more, Doña Luisa is left to care for her grandchildren. Mariano fares better, working at an advertisement office. But just as it seems that the remaining Espeñas will live happily, a flood sweeps across the town. Trying to save his wife who falls into the flood, Mariano gets pneumonia. He dies, leaving his mother to care for his children. Silvia grows up to be a very beautiful girl. She almost becomes a victim of the playboy Dodong Latorre, who has gotten another woman pregnant. In the end, Silvia decides to enter the nunnery.

In this novel, Abad has changed from the political philosopher of La Oveja de Nathan (Nathan’s Sheep), 1928, into a mystical theologian much more concerned about the purgation of a soul who had the impiety to oppose resolutely the will of God. The desire to keep his story anchored in a definite time and place, specifically the late Spanish period to the early American period in the Visayas, motivates Abad to describe customs and manners in great detail.  Written by Florentino Hornedo

This last novel of Abad is a medieval morality tale dressed in 20th-century narrative garments. David Evangelista is a hardened criminal, wanted by the law for a variety of crimes. To deceive the agents of the law, he changes his name to Daniel Espeña. As Daniel Espeña, he is a hacendero, with a pious wife, Eleuteria (Teria) Mangabut, and a son, Miguel. Miguel wants to be a priest, but Daniel objects. Only after a foreboding nightmare does he concede to his son’s wish. Daniel is a changed man after the nightmare. He becomes pious and generous. Later, his wife dies of cholera, and he himself dies of a stroke. Miguel abandons the seminary to administer his father’s wealth. Eventually, he marries Luisa de Guzman and has four children: Claudio, Teresa, Mariano, and Silvia.

Each of the children undergoes tragic experiences, the consequences of which Doña Luisa bears. Claudio (Caloy) is a libertine who fathers illegitimate children. He starts to change only after a series of mishaps, including the loss of his business. A flood destroys his house and ends his life. Doña Luisa is left to look after his children. Published 1965. Author, Bienvenido N. Santos. Manila: Erewhon Publishing. Reprinted, Quezon City: New Day Publishers, 1986.

Alfredo Medallada, the novel’s central character, grows up in Sulucan, Tondo, where Villa Magdalena reigns over the sensibilities of the people surrounding it, provoking awe, resentment, sometimes even pity. Alfredo’s father is Martin, a proud man who declares defensively that he is not a relative of the villa’s don even if they share the same family name. Modesto Buan, an evangelist, sets up his church right beside the villa, frustrating the don’s plan to buy the land. Solomon Gomez runs away with Isabel, a married woman who is a niece of Doña Magdalena.

Don Magno, a leather entrepreneur, takes Fred under his wing, bringing him up from houseboy to student and family driver to company employee. Through it all, Fred is a bright learner doing exactly what is expected of him and developing an instinct for knowing where his limits lie. The don’s paternalism allows him to finally be an in-law and heir apparent to the business. World War II sinks the enterprise and weakens the don, but Fred revives the company. Ironically, he fails to revive his marriage with Nora.

It is through Alfredo that the lives of the other characters are richly interwoven, although he is hardly the catalyst. The don counterpoints Alfredo’s character even as Alfredo himself becomes the villa’s don in the end. Alfredo’s reaction to Solomon’s decision disgusts his childhood friend. His opportunism with Manang exposes him to himself; Nora shows him his inborn limits, which are those of his class; and Elisa awakens him to his potentials but also to his desperation. The many narrative strands find a locus in Fred’s drive for acceptance into a class and an inheritance, neither of which is his own. Counterpointing his ambition are Doña Magdalena’s rejection, whose insanity is wrought lucid, and Pat’s simple constancy in her love for Don Magno.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

 

Sources

Galdon, Joseph, SJ, ed. 1972. Philippine Fiction. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Majid, Abdul Bin Nabi Baksh. 1970. “The Filipino Novel in English.” Philippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review 35 (Mar-Jun).

Published 1965. Author, Bienvenido N. Santos. Quezon City: Alemar-Phoenix. Reprinted, Quezon City: New Day Publishers, 1986.

In this novel, Santos explores the barriers between cultures. The story begins in 1928, when Dr Paul Hunter, an American medical missionary, arrives in Bicol with his family. They spend the next 30 years with the local community, especially with the Barrios family with whom they seek refuge when the war breaks out. The Hunter children, Junior and Florence, and the Barrios children, Tito and Badong, become fast friends. Dr Hunter is helpful and sympathetic to the community during times of crises, such as volcanic eruptions and typhoons. However, his comradeship with the Filipinos is motivated by his desire to succeed in his evangelical mission, and not by the conviction that all people are equal. This becomes clear when he cannot accept Badong as Florence’s husband.

The novel reveals the paradoxical situation of Dr Hunter: while he believes in equality as an abstract principle, he is unable to live out this belief in concrete terms. In turn, the Hunters are accepted as friends by the Barrios family, but they are rejected by the larger community after the war.

The novel is characterized by simple style and technique, typical of Santos’s fiction. The unilinear plot, relieved by a few flashbacks, is matched by one-dimensional and static characterization. This deliberate “artlessness” serves to reveal gradually the theme of psychological, moral, and cultural hollowness. Serving as foil to Dr Hunter is Don Vicente, the Spaniard, who lives a more natural, hence volatile, life than Hunter. However, he suffers from a kind of gangrene that causes his leg to be amputated. The volcano referred to by the title is Mayon Volcano, an entity which is both alive and dormant, self-generating and destructive, a natural force that throbs with life and energy. But it is also Junior’s imitation volcano, which matches Hunter in its hollowness and artificiality. The cadang-cadang, a pest that eats the interior of coconut trees, reminds one again of Hunter’s hollowness and also of Don Vicente’s moral disease. It may symbolize the Filipino as well, which may appear whole and healthy but is actually sick.  Written by Lourdes H. Vidal and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

 

Source:

Majid 1970.

Published 1998. Author, Alfred A. Yuson. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Centennial Literary Prize, third prize co-winner for the novel in English. Second edition, Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2003.

Alfred A. Yuson’s second novel, while less experimental than his first, also adopts the playful tone, short episodic chapters, and nonlinear plotting of Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, 1987. Voyeurs and Savages uses the Philippine exhibition at the Saint Louis World Exposition of 1904 as a central point from which various narrative threads leapfrog into past and future, tracking several American and Filipino characters and their descendants from the turn of the 20th century to the late 1990s as their lives intersect and intertwine. Its chapters are sequenced according to an allusive logic that juxtaposes various time periods with each other. Over the course of the plot, motifs echo one another and accumulate, substituting the layering of signification for conventional escalation and climax.

The novel’s “cyclic conceit” is to take the core situation of Filipino “savages” being observed by Americans at the Expo and dramatize its reversal and deconstruction in various ways: a tribesman on exhibit peeps up the skirt of a hapless female Expo visitor; Americans offer commentary and analysis of the Philippines; and a Filipino scholar in America ironically annotates his research on the Expo. The novel’s primary, rather heavy-handed symbol is an elaborately constructed beach resort that hides a web of private corridors in which its Filipino owner can peep on guests foreign and local. Everyone is a voyeur, everyone is a savage, and no one is spared, not even the reader, who is party to the crime by implication.

The novel pieces together its narrative from the lives of a handful of central characters. Among these are Cornelius James, a member of the American team selecting specimens from the Mountain Province for the Expo; Wilson Cangbay, a Mountain Province guide who assists James; Armando Aguinaldo, the shady Filipino entrepreneur who builds the Blue Wave beach resort; and his son Meynard, history scholar at Washington University in Saint Louis. The Aguinaldos are descended from the first Philippine president. Cangbay eventually marries the daughter of a tribal chieftain, and their grandson later becomes bodyguard and henchman to Aguinaldo père. Aguinaldo fils maintains a romance with James’s granddaughter, whom he takes to his father’s resort in the Philippines, where his father watches their lovemaking through a two-way mirror.

Several chunks of the novel consist of quotations from various historical references, documents, manuscripts, news articles, letters, bulletin board service messages, and e-mails, most of them actual and factual, with dates and names unredacted. The bricolage is consistent with the novel’s metafictional tendencies and contributes to its thematic intent by allowing reader and characters (especially historian Meynard) to apply critical hindsight to and contextualize history. The technique also fragments the novel unevenly, drawing attention to these sections’ disparity with the more causally developed, albeit nonchronologically sequenced, plotlines.

Voyeurs and Savages was tied for third prize (with Azucena Grajo Uranza’s A Passing Season, 2002) at the competition commemorating the proclamation of the Philippine republic in 1898. As a “centennial novel,” its cheery thesis seems to be that time has blunted and equalized the injustice of the Philippines’ American colonial experience, and that Filipinos have always been able to match the empire, gaze for gaze and savagery for savagery.  Written by Vicente Garcia Groyon

text:
(Eight Muses of the Fall). Published 2009. Author, Edgar Calabia Samar. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. NCCA Writers’ Prize Award, 2005. English translation, Eight Muses of the Fall by Mikael de Lara Co and Sasha Martinez, Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2013.

Samar’s first novel is divided into 44 parts, where 27 are numbered chapters and the rest are occasional interludes containing anecdotes or commentaries. It is about an aspiring writer, Daniel, writing his story. This kunstlerroman, or coming-of-age narrative of an artist, is thus also metafictional, being a self-aware narrative commenting on itself and on the details of how it was written.

The life of the protagonist begins in his hometown of Atisan, which he wants to use as the setting of his planned novel. In the book’s introduction he is at the brink of death after being lured by a tiyanak (changeling). He receives an e-mail from Glen, who speculates on the possibility that they and their hometown of Atisan may just be products of Daniel’s imagination.

The nonlinear narrative takes us back and forth in time to show Daniel’s development as a person and as a writer. Back in primary school, he tells his classmates stories about the dwarf that he later calls “Delka Linar,” an anagram of his full name, “Karl Daniel.” He cherishes three childhood friends: Erik, his very first friend; Michael, who defends him from bullying classmates; and Glen, who shares his interest in literature.

Daniel’s story is published in Liwayway magazine, and he is determined to finish the next great Filipino novel. He begins by observing the people of his hometown, and he asks his Uncle Tony to tell him stories, which include those about Domeng. Domeng is their ancestor who was the first to clear Sapang Ligaw (Lost Lake) and to build the first nipa hut there. He took a wife and had numerous children before he disappeared.

Daniel regularly meets Teresa, a prostitute who can read minds at nighttime. Daniel has introduced himself to her as “Karl.” She calls him “Karl Kabute” because of his mushroom-sized ears, a mark, she says, of a short life. Teresa tells Daniel a story about Atisan, the muse. Once upon a time, Atisan sees Domingo’s need for love. She appears to him, who appreciates her but eventually forgets about her. Atisan’s spirit disappears.

Teresa prevents Daniel from looking at her. The day before, she offered to accompany Daniel on the horror train. Daniel agreed, because it would be their first “date.” He would be able to see Teresa in broad daylight, instead of meeting her at night, he as a customer and she a prostitute. Daniel arrives at the rendezvous but sees someone resembling Orange, his first love, who denies being her. Daniel loses track of her, and again sees Teresa only after the sun has already set.

Orange is one of triplets in Daniel’s hometown, the other two being Apple and Peaches, so named because her family owns a fruit stand. After Daniel takes her virginity, they part ways. Later, Daniel learns that Orange is in Japan, married to a Japanese.

Uncle Tony tells Daniel stories of their hometown but is taciturn about family matters. Daniel’s ignorance about his family prevents him from writing concretely about Arcangel, the protagonist of his novel in progress. Arcangel is an albularyo (faith healer) like Daniel’s father. But Daniel knows very little about his father, and his mother is dead. There is a physical resemblance between Daniel and Tony, who later admits to being Daniel’s father. A lengthy family history follows. Tony gives Daniel a photograph of his mother.

The novel is about to end when Daniel learns his mother’s name: Olivia. Daniel goes to Boracay to find his mother, who, according to Tony, starred in a “bold” (pornographic) film. Daniel muses that he has lived a “normal” life, unlike his father who, he guesses, went underground during martial law. Daniel sees Michael in Boracay and they engage in existentialist conversation.

One night Daniel meets two intoxicated teenagers, to whom he shows his mother’s photograph. The taller lad snatches the wallet but Daniel quickly restrains the other one. He demands that his captive lead him to his accomplice and return the photo. Daniel ends up falling off a cliff; it is the same scene in the introduction where he thinks he is being pushed by the tiyanak. Thus, Samar’s novel comes full circle, and all the fragments in between are scenes from Daniel’s life flashing before him.

Samar makes considerable use of Philippine folklore even as he acknowledges his foreign literary influences, including Haruki Murakami and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. In drafting the character sketch of Daniel, who in turn drafts the character sketch of Arcangel, Samar shows us how a novel may be woven into a complex, multilayered narrative that feeds and nurtures itself.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

Published 1947. Author, Stevan Javellana. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. Reprinted, Quezon City: Alemar-Phoenix, 1976.

The title is taken from a character’s speech in Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, 1887. Usually classified as a war novel, Without Seeing the Dawn does not actually begin with the story of the war. The first part, titled “Day,” depicts prewar farm life in a barrio and then city life in Panay; the second part, titled “Night,” depicts the effects of war on this barrio. Ricardo Suerte is the central character. He metamorphoses from a gentle, passive farmer to a bitter, violent man as he is buffeted by the social injustice of landlordism, the hostile forces of nature, the corruption in the city, and the atrocities of war. His character is likened to that of a carabao, which will endure patiently until, goaded by a series of blows, it finally fights back.

In the beginning, life for Carding and his bride Lucing seems idyllic as they build their new house and await the coming of their baby. But there are auguries of the sorrows that will soon befall them. Their baby is stillborn, a “monkey child.” The first serious rift between Carding and Lucing occurs when the landlord’s son, Luis Castro, comes for a vacation in the barrio and seduces Lucing. Having caught them, Carding beats up Luis; consequently, the Suerte family loses the right to till the land. Carding and Lucing then move to Iloilo City, where people must harden themselves in order to survive. Carding becomes a stevedore and finds solace in Rosing, a prostitute who falls sincerely in love with him. Lucing leaves him and returns to the barrio. Carding is unwillingly dragged into unionism, whose leadership is based on patronage system. Disillusioned, Carding follows Lucing back to the barrio and tries to start farm life anew. Once again, he is foiled, this time by natural elements. After a huge flood destroys the farm, Carding decides to join the homestead program in Mindanao. But the war breaks out.

The novel’s second part begins with Carding’s return home after having survived the Death March. Although he is determined not to get involved in the guerrilla movement, he is inexorably drawn into it when he learns that his family has been brutalized while he is away. Carding becomes a verdugo, the executioner of war collaborators. He is so notorious for his cruelty and ruthlessness that he is condemned by his own community. He intends to kill Lucing’s baby, whose father might be a Japanese soldier, but it is stillborn. Carding is regenerated at this moment, when he realizes that he could not have killed the infant anyway. He now joins the war in earnest. Just before a suicidal mission, Carding returns to Lucing and asks for her forgiveness.

The novel is a rich, moving dramatization of events, rural folk life, and characters who are familiar but not stereotyped. Critics have acknowledged it to be the most artistic and compelling narrative of the Filipino war experience. Santiago, a movie directed by Lino Brocka in 1970, was based on the novel.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

 

Sources
