article.value: Published 1947. Author, Stevan Javellana. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. Reprinted, Quezon City: Alemar-Phoenix, 1976.

The title is taken from a character’s speech in Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, 1887. Usually classified as a war novel, Without Seeing the Dawn does not actually begin with the story of the war. The first part, titled “Day,” depicts prewar farm life in a barrio and then city life in Panay; the second part, titled “Night,” depicts the effects of war on this barrio. Ricardo Suerte is the central character. He metamorphoses from a gentle, passive farmer to a bitter, violent man as he is buffeted by the social injustice of landlordism, the hostile forces of nature, the corruption in the city, and the atrocities of war. His character is likened to that of a carabao, which will endure patiently until, goaded by a series of blows, it finally fights back.

In the beginning, life for Carding and his bride Lucing seems idyllic as they build their new house and await the coming of their baby. But there are auguries of the sorrows that will soon befall them. Their baby is stillborn, a “monkey child.” The first serious rift between Carding and Lucing occurs when the landlord’s son, Luis Castro, comes for a vacation in the barrio and seduces Lucing. Having caught them, Carding beats up Luis; consequently, the Suerte family loses the right to till the land. Carding and Lucing then move to Iloilo City, where people must harden themselves in order to survive. Carding becomes a stevedore and finds solace in Rosing, a prostitute who falls sincerely in love with him. Lucing leaves him and returns to the barrio. Carding is unwillingly dragged into unionism, whose leadership is based on patronage system. Disillusioned, Carding follows Lucing back to the barrio and tries to start farm life anew. Once again, he is foiled, this time by natural elements. After a huge flood destroys the farm, Carding decides to join the homestead program in Mindanao. But the war breaks out.

The novel’s second part begins with Carding’s return home after having survived the Death March. Although he is determined not to get involved in the guerrilla movement, he is inexorably drawn into it when he learns that his family has been brutalized while he is away. Carding becomes a verdugo, the executioner of war collaborators. He is so notorious for his cruelty and ruthlessness that he is condemned by his own community. He intends to kill Lucing’s baby, whose father might be a Japanese soldier, but it is stillborn. Carding is regenerated at this moment, when he realizes that he could not have killed the infant anyway. He now joins the war in earnest. Just before a suicidal mission, Carding returns to Lucing and asks for her forgiveness.

The novel is a rich, moving dramatization of events, rural folk life, and characters who are familiar but not stereotyped. Critics have acknowledged it to be the most artistic and compelling narrative of the Filipino war experience. Santiago, a movie directed by Lino Brocka in 1970, was based on the novel.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: The Woman Who Had Two Navels
text:
Published 1961. Author, Nick Joaquin. Manila Regal Publishing House. Reprinted, Manila: Solidaridad Publishing House, 1972; Makati City: Bookmark Inc, 1991. Originally a novella of the same title included in Prose and Poems, with an introduction by Teodoro M. Locsin, Manila: Graphic House, 1952, and later included in Tropical Gothic, Queensland: University of Queensland Press, 1972. The novella was serialized as The Woman Who Had Two Navels in This Week, 10 Jul–17 Jul 1949, and as The Woman Who Had Two Navels in Partisan Review 20 (Jul-Aug 1953).

The novel, which won the Stonehill Award in 1960, is divided into five sections, each containing a flashback into the lives of the key characters: Paco, Macho, Concha, Connie, and Dr Monson. The chapters venture into these character’s thoughts and perceptions of events while constantly keeping Connie in focus. This use of a revolving point of view highlights a central theme of the novel: the difficulty of distinguishing between right and wrong, truth and falsehood, illusion and reality. Other themes are the middle-class Filipino’s search for identity and roots, the Filipino’s sense of alienation, and the inaction that arises from an individual’s failure to distinguish between the illusory world and the real world.

Set in Hong Kong and Manila, the story revolves around two women: Connie Escobar and her mother, Concha Vidal. Both women are complex, mysterious, and obsessive. Connie, tormented by painful realizations about her family, her marriage and her past, takes refuge in a lie; she insists to all who would listen that she has two navels. The illusion enables her to set herself apart from other people and thus retreat into a world where she need never make moral choices nor assume responsibility for anything. Concha, for her part, is obsessed with her past and her youth, and constantly seeks self-renewal in her affairs with younger men. The arrival of the women in Hong Kong quickly causes upheavals in the lives of the people all on self-imposed exile there and whom they encounter: Pete, a veterinarian; his priest-brother Tony; their homesick, dying father, Dr Monson; Paco Texeira, the bandleader who had brief affairs with both Connie and Concha during his stint in Manila; Mary, Paco’s wife; and Rita Lopez, with whom Pepe has been going around for a long time.

The novel opens with Connie requesting a mystified Pepe to surgically correct her imagined defect: the two navels. Later, Pepe meets Concha who proceeds to contradict everything her daughter has told him. In a kind of ripple effect, this initial entry of the two women into the small, tight world of exiles causes the latter to reexamine their own relationships, their conceptions of right and wrong, truth and lies. In the end, Connie runs away with Paco, an act which takes her out of her world of illusions into a complex reality, and starts a string of reactions and realizations among all the characters.

The novel is rich in symbols. The two navels can represent life’s dualities: Connie’s dolls Minnie and Biliken represent the safe and secure, because illusory, world she has built around herself; the encounter between Connie and Dr Monson represents the meeting of present and past; and Connie’s four “deaths” (by earth, water, air, and fire) parallel Connie’s spiritual deaths at various stages in her life, and the rebirth she comes to crave and later attains.  Written by Ma. Teresa Wright
